author: jhorsley@zamp.com
body: Hey team! Was talking with Matt today about the QBO integration. We noticed that when we load in and create an invoice, the first one is taking around 5 minutes to get tax in QBO and post to the Zamp Site . Issue: QBO transactions seem to have a 5 minute delay on first invoice. In tested we have seen that there is about a 5 minute delay from Save & Close to tax showing on the invoice in QBO and posting to Zamp Admin. The second and third test we did the time dropped to 2 minutes then on the FOURTH the time dropped to under a minute. Is this expected behavior? If so, anyway we can reduce the time it takes on the first few invoices? Seems it resets back to the 5 minute delay after awhile. If this is intended, what is the duration? TESTING First Invoice: 12:45 - Clicked "Save & Close" 12:50 - Showed up on Zamp Admin 12:50 - Showed up in QBO as a line QBO log timestamp - 2025-09-29T19:50:45.8614392Z Second Invoice: 12:53 - Clicked "Save & Close" 12:55 - Showed up in Zamp Admin 12:55 - Showed in QBO as a line QBO log timestamp - 2025-09-29T19:55:06.5986541Z Third Invoice: 12:56 - Clicked "Save & Close" 12:57 - Showed up in Zamp Admin 12:57 - Showed in QBO as a line QBO log timestamp - 2025-09-29T19:57:48.524Z Fourth Invoice: 1:00 - Clicked "Save & Close" 1:00 - Showed up in Zamp Admin 1:00 - Showed in QBO as a line QBO log timestamp - 2025-09-29T20:00:10.903Z Let me know if you have any questions! John

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Stephen, Thanks for sharing this example with us and for your continued patience. Regarding the 2nd address: Which was: 2449 E Genesee St, Syracuse, NY, 13210-2223 On our end, we are showing that the primary or house number, 2449, is invalid here. According to USPS data and Zamp's address data, this is confirmed. This page from Smarty provides additional details. Here's where we can see that the address is invalid: Regarding the 1st address: Which was: 20 W 34th St, New York, NY 10118-0114 This address presents a slightly different story, as further investigation reveals it to be a valid address; however, it is missing an apartment or suite number, which leads to a different determination overall. Smarty's evaluation of the address also indicates a missing apartment or suite number. The USPS shows on this page that there are as many as 5 different address possibilities here: Next steps: This is something that we will raise with our engineering team to explore potential solutions for. As soon as we have more information or an improvement is released, we'll follow up promptly. Our engineering team has been working through a process to improve how invalid or incomplete addresses are handled within Zamp; it's top of mind here. In the meantime, we recommend (if you haven't already) ensuring that your checkout or purchasing process allows orders to proceed in these scenarios. I hope this is helpful to you. Please let us know if you have any questions. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Stephen, Thanks for your patience with this! We're still investigating this situation and hope to have an update soon. Overall, it appears that this is happening due to this address not being present as a valid address within Zamp's address data, which includes USPS data. This can happen from time to time, and we'll share more detail as soon as we're able! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Reena, Thanks for your patience here! We're working through the differences you've noted, and it's likely due to the nature of Zamp's exports, which are line-item-level files rather than order-level files. We should have an update and another version of these files for your review soon. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - We'll try to look into this soon. The difference is likely caused by these exports containing repeated amounts across each row in the CSV file, as they're what we call a 'line item file'. If they add the tax or other amounts starting with 'transaction', it will be larger than the actual tax collected. The transaction-level amounts: Line item amounts (differ from transaction-level): Here's an example: The yellow is one transaction with multiple lines, and we can talk about this today or this week. :) We'll know more as we get a chance to look into this with the Zamp Camp stuff and travel.

author: jhorsley@zamp.com
body: Hey team! Found an issue with a variable product in the WooCommerce connector. Confirmed it does not happen if the Zamp plugin is disabled. Environment: Clean WooCommerce install with the following plugins active: WooCommerce WooCommerce Stripe Gateway (for test credit cards) WooPayments (test check and COD payments) ZampTax for WooCommerce Product: Variable product with a $20 and $10 price on each, both set as physical products. Shipping set to standard class. Test: Create product -> save Load admin product page -> see error (attached) in price column. Load store page Add variable product to cart -> error appears on front end. Warning: Undefined array key "line_total" in /Users/jhorsley3/Sites/Zamp/wp-includes/class-wp-list-util.php on line 170 View cart -> Tax calculates, no errors Proceed to checkout -> no errors Place order Behavior: The errors only happen on the admin product page and when you add the product to the cart. The website allows you to proceed through to checkout. Thanks! John

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Robert, Thanks for the response here! Great! So, we're all set regarding the initial tax calculations for the transactions. If we do that, how do we remove the tax from next months calculation for Maryland so we don't pay it? To remove the tax, we would want to create a couple of transactions to offset the tax and ensure it is not paid to the state of Maryland, since the tax was refunded and shouldn't have been collected now that we know the customer is tax-exempt. We can do this in either of the ways noted below: This can be done via the Zamp API (see the attached example JSON files) as these API calls can be sent through the current integration or as one-off transactions using a tool like Postman. I can create transactions by importing the attached CSV file if Bag Borrow or Steal's Zamp integration doesn't currently support doing this via the API. Which of the two paths would you or the team prefer? Please let me know if you have any questions! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: robert.treves@bagborroworsteal.com
body: It is ok - we send you the net number in the amount line so the discount is already accounted for. The other question we had was about refunding the tax for this transaction. The customer has supplied us with their resale certificate so we want to refund the tax on their 2 transactions (this one and 8173260). If we do that, how do we remove the tax from next months calculation for Maryland so we don't pay it?

} In addition, this customer informed us that they have a resale certificate and will be sending that in. What is the process in Zamp for removing the tax collected from the order if we refund the customer the tax? We shouldn't be sending in a tax payment we didn't truly collect. For this refund, we recommend creating a full refund via Zamp's API, if your integration supports this, and then recreating the transaction without tax. The purpose value can be set to RESALE. If the above isn't possible here, we could delete the existing transaction within Zamp and recreate it without the tax, ensuring that the tax that wasn't collected is not remitted. Which of the above options works best for you all? Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Robert, Thanks for reaching out about this! Zamp does have sales tax and state-specific built-in rules within our API for the handling of tax calculations when discounts are involved. We're reviewing the details associated with this order and the API calls. We hope to have an update soon! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: amelia@zamp.com

author: robert.treves@bagborroworsteal.com
body: Hello, We had a customer tell us that we calculated the Maryland tax on the 'Amount' of the order instead of the 'Amount less the Discount'. You can see the details below, but we only charge/receive the amount less the discount (or in our system we call it the 'discounted amount').  If this is true, it needs to be fixed immediately for any state that is calculating (and remitting) this way.  If true, it is possibly why we are meeting the thresholds so quickly because we generally sell items at an average of a 23% discount. In addition, this customer informed us that they have a resale certificate and will be sending that in.  What is the process in Zamp for removing the tax collected from the order if we refund the customer the tax?  We shouldn't be sending in a tax payment we didn't truly collect. Thanks, Robert

Ciao, Bobbi Ferrell RAVELLA Executive Assistant 304.531.1100 bobbi@shopravella.com www.shopravella.com On Fri, Sep 12, 2025 at 6:37 PM The Zamp Team < support@zamp.com > wrote: Hi Jason and Bobbi, A quick follow-up here as we head into the weekend! We were able to roll forward a few refunds from July 2025 into the August 2025 filing period, but many will need to be carried into future filing periods, and we're keeping track of this. Additionally, the approximately $100 difference between the Zamp Transaction's tax total and our tax-due estimate is due to additional refunds resulting in negative amounts in other local jurisdictions; we're keeping track of those as well. We'll continue to carry or roll these forward as we have done the last few months. I've also confirmed that the ShopMy orders all show $0 tax in both Shopify and Zamp as we expected. Zamp's Shopify integration continues to account for voided orders partially and adequately account for partial refunds. Any discrepancies with partial refunds were manually accounted for. I've attached two files: The transaction-level and totals for the tax-due estimate review. The work and supporting transaction file, along with notes for the usual month-to-month order edit and partial refund process. Please let us know if you have any questions. Have a great weekend! author: connectors@zamp.com

author: connectors@zamp.com
body: Hi John, Thanks for the input and we will update the logic and check on how to handle the random characters. Apart from this question below, please can you provide your inputs Should we set the recalculate parameter as false while performing transaction sync? Thanks Sandeep

author: jhorsley@zamp.com
body: Hey! In the historical sync I think only completed or refunded should be processed over. This is the current logic when the connector is live as it doesn't save over to the ZAMP side until it's moved to a completed status. For the historical sync we should be taking the data as is from their WooCommerce instance, as the assumption is that these have already been paid so adding tax to them wouldn't be helpful. With this, and the inclusion of the random characters after the WC order number, if you resync the same period of transactions you get duplicates posted to the Zamp side. We need some sort of checking on this to avoid duplicates. Thanks! John

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: @john Sending your way!

author: connectors@zamp.com
body: Hi John, We haven't worked on transaction sync, We need to work on the same. Please let us know if our understanding is correct. As you mentioned above fetch processing, completed, refunded, or pending payment in historical /transaction sync. transactedAt should be date created when sending transaction to Zamp For Completed and refunded status , first perform tax calculation using /calculations endpoint , store taxDue amount and perform /transactions call with taxDue as taxCollected value. If Orders which are in completed or refunded Status - We cannot update anything in WooCommerce as the document are locked If Orders are in any other status like processing or pending payment , perform tax calculation using /calculations endpoint and update tax values back in wooCommerce - We need to verify if we can update tax back in WooCommerce. Should we consider PTC? Apart from this let us know in case of any other information that can be useful. Thanks Sandeep

author: jhorsley@zamp.com
body: Hey team! In the new 2.0 connector in testing a transaction sync the sync is pulling over the date of the sync and not the date of the transaction. Issue : Transaction sync pulls date of sync and not of order. All orders are synced, regardless of order status. Environment: Clean WooCommerce install with the following plugins active: WooCommerce WooCommerce Stripe Gateway (for test credit cards) WooPayments (test check and COD payments) ZampTax for WooCommerce (2.0) Test: Sync previous orders over to Zamp. Navigate to WooCommerce -> Settings -> ZampTax -> Transaction Sync. Set the date range for the transactions to sync, click Start Sync. Behavior: Transaction Sync pulls over orders with status processing, completed, refunded, or pending payment (note: doesn't sync cancelled, failed,) and sets the transaction date to the state or the sync and not the date of the order . Thanks! John

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Kay, Thanks for taking the time to meet with us earlier this morning! I've attached the file we reviewed and worked with during our call today. The 'Transaction Subtotal' amounts and formulas we discussed are in columns AA and AB. I've also updated the formulas on the 'Instructions' sheet. A few items we discussed, and I said I would share via email: The transactionSubtotal (column ' G ') should be the combined (summed) total of all line items on the invoice; it can be repeated across each row. 🙂 Columns AA and AB , along with the instructions sheet, can help with this. If an item has a discount on an invoice, let's include this discount in column ' U ', labeled ' lineItemDiscount '. We want to ensure we don't include the discount in column ' H ' for ' transactionDiscoun t' to avoid duplication. If shipping and handling (freight) charges are associated with an invoice, let's include that amount in column ' F ' for ' transactionShippingHandlin g'. We also want to ensure we don't include the shipping/handling amount in column ' W ' for ' lineItemShippingHandling ' to avoid duplication. For installations, we want to include the R_SRV_INSTALLATION tax code in column ' Y ' for ' lineItemProductTaxCode '. The discount amounts should be positive for invoices and negative for refunds. All amounts for an invoice (in each row and column) should be positive . All amounts for a refund (in each row and column) should be negative . I hope this is helpful! Please let us know if you have any questions! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: caroline@zamp.com
body: Hi Kay, Thank you for sending all this over! I am copying Chris Ralph (he works out of the support@zamp.com inbox), so we can get his feedback on this! Thank you, Caroline On Tue, Sep 16, 2025 at 5:13 PM Kay Dreaden < kdreaden@ironlionentries.com > wrote: Hello Caroline, During our 9/9/25 Zoom meeting, we discussed actions and timing of transferring responsibility of preparing and filing our Sales & Use taxes from my team to ZAMP. System Comparisons: We determined that QB was the best source for accurate tax calculations and any small variance from what is reflected in SalesForce was immaterial with the general understanding that less than 5% variance was in the realm of tolerable and reasonable.  This being said, I have reviewed data in each system and can confirm QB is the correct data source. ZAMP template: ZAMP was to send me a detailed template and be available for a call if needed.  I do not recall receiving the template.  If sent, please resend.  In the meantime, I ran a report in QB that I think provides the information you need to calculate and file our Sales & Use taxes.  Please see attached CSVs: QB REPORT - 2025-08 This report is in its raw form directly from QuickBooks.  You can see that there are duplications that will skew the taxes, etc. ZAMP - Sales & Use 2025-08 This is a cleaner version of the QB report with duplicate data removed, etc.  The "Ship via" column is actually the method of transferring the product from ILE to the customer.  "ILE Installation" equates to taxes assessed on COGs or purchase price.  Any other classification under "Ship via" (i.e. Customer Pickup) equates to taxes assessed on the sale price.  Some items, such as storage fees and trip charge, are not taxable, so there is no value in the "Taxation Target" column. Once provided, I can fill out the template with necessary codes, etc., but I hope this data gives you some idea of what we might provide in our steps to make the transition of responsibility for preparing and filing taxes.  I recall you mentioning that you are working on an integration with QB, but it is not yet ready.  In the interim, I am hoping we might do manual exchanges to get the ball moving in the right direction. Please consider and advise.  Please share with others (i.e. Chris Ralph?) as needed. Best regards, Kay Kay Dreaden Accounting Manager Iron Lion Entries, LLC (931) 494-4965 -- Caroline Cassell Onboarding Specialist 866-438-9267 caroline@zamp.com zamp.com LinkedIn Help Others Discover Zamp Share How We Simplified Your Compliance

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes from the call: They use PayPal as an express payment provider, and it opens PayPal; then PayPal handles the entire process. PayPal doesn't have a way to share address information and tax info via the Express integration or APIs. There's a hidden state-specific tax rate configuration option that must be set up manually, and it only allows single rates. Ultimately, Gus noted that they will likely decide not to use PayPal as a payment method, but they will discuss this internally with their team. Either way, they will send all transactions to Zamp, and if they do use PayPal, they will be under-collecting tax and paying the difference out of pocket because of PayPal's limitations. Cc: @taryn @john

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Snoozing this one to look into further tomorrow. Notes from investigation with @nick : Vetchy isn't using any tags on orders with returns or exchanges through Rich Returns - I'll likely ask them to configure this just in case it's necessary in the future. Rich returns documentation: https://support.richreturns.io/en/articles/9272102-shopify-sync#:~:text=Add-,a%20tag%20to%20the%20order,-%2C%20which%20can%20be We'll likely want a call with them to confirm their Rich Returns settings within that app/separate site's Dashboard and settings: https://support.richreturns.io/en/articles/9272487-exchange-orders-shopify-sales-statistics-analytics I spot-checked various refunded and partially refunded orders and found: Rich Returns is using Shopify's built-in return/exchange functionality. Zamp is capturing these orders, both the order and the refund. The refunds can sometimes span pretty large date ranges: V2389481 - Order on 7/7 but return on 8/29. V2375531 - Ordered on 7/5 but returned on 8/29. V2172421 - Ordered on 5/29 but returned 8/3. We may want to review the FAQ and other Rich Returns support articles here: https://support.richreturns.io/en/collections/9390062-faqs https://support.richreturns.io/en/ We're handling partial refunds, full refunds, and returns/exchanges correctly here. In the past, we may not have been aware of these changes, as they were released between June and July 2025. We'll likely encounter issues with negative amounts in a filing's local jurisdictions fairly regularly, especially from July through September.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes from the call today: NY - Large difference but not due to refunds - order edits, or something similar? Other states - lots of refunds, specifically - GA, OK, LA, SC and VA. Order edits? They rarely make changes - someone in customer care/support might do something. Sometimes they have a manual order, where they issue an express shipping to the customer. they do not change orders like this. Loop or return/exchange apps: They don't use third-party apps. Returns specifically: They have plenty of returns and exchanges. They have close to 20% on returns, from orders/sales. Sizing issues and other various reasons. They want to make sure when we file, that we're accounting for those. Return policy is usually ~18 days - they say 2 weeks, and they usually give 18. With returns - it's 30-days. They have a seasonal business July is a peak season and in August they have a lot of returns. Returns are more than gross sales in August, but it's up there. A lot of retunrs in general, so August is still the highest - not above gross sales but close to. They use a platform called RichCommerce - https://apps.shopify.com/rich-returns They sync with Shopify -

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Manu and Team, A quick follow-up: thank you again for your continued patience! In this situation, we'd recommend a few different strategies that might help improve load time: Caching the sales tax rate after the initial API call to Zamp, instead of making additional API calls as items are added. One way to do this could be: Storing the taxDue amount from the Zamp /calculations API response and dividing it by the cart's initial amount to obtain the tax rate. Sum the tax rate available as a taxRate property within the Zamp API response's taxes array. Make an initial API call to /calculations to obtain the tax due and present it as an 'estimate', then make the final calculation at Checkout before the payment is processed. Implement a debounce mechanism on cart updates to ensure the API is only called after the user has not interacted with the cart for 500 milliseconds to 1 second. A similar approach could be to batch cart changes into API calls made to Zamp's /calculations API endpoint when the user is idle in the cart or site, or immediately before they proceed. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Manu, Thanks for your patience! We're exploring options for improving this situation and the cart behavior, while minimizing delays in the checkout process. At this time, Zamp is unable to provide a list of tax rates by zip code or state; however, we'll discuss this further internally to confirm if the information has changed.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Katelynn, Thank you for the great question and for your patience. For filing purposes, the Zamp QuickBooks Online app can be installed at any time. If the app was installed on Monday (9/15/25), we want to ensure that a 'Historical Data Sync' is run for the period from 9/1/25 to 9/15/25 to capture all invoices. This means that the setup could be completed at any time in September 2025. At the latest, we'd want it set up by October 3, 2025, to ensure timely filing for the returns processed in October 2025. However we approach this, we'll want to ensure that we know the date the app was added and can then sync any missing invoices to fill the gap. I hope this helps! Have a great weekend! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jimmy, Thanks again for your continued patience! We investigated this further and found that Zamp's tax collected amounts (and the amount for the tax-due estimate that was remitted) align closely with both the Vargo POS and Shopify tax collection for North Carolina and South Carolina. I'll share more details about why this is the case below. The Shopify Report I used is the 'United States Sales Tax' Report , filtered to NC and SC here . The first cause of this difference: Zamp's system had some background processes involved in our internal tax calculation process (to build our filings and estimates) that were slightly backed up in early to mid-September. Our Engineering team resolved this situation after the tax-due estimate was sent. We've also had various internal conversations about improving this situation and ensuring we catch these before our tax-due estimates are sent out. The tax-due estimate for NC has been updated to $ 13,723.65 , which is the amount that was filed and remitted to the state of NC. Another cause of the difference here: Another cause of the difference is that TES Operating LLC's Florida filings are submitted quarterly. This means that the $314.20 in tax collected in FL would be remitted with the Q3 2025 filing, due in October, along with the tax collected in July and September. Within your Zamp account, the Tax Collected Report can be used to view tax collection across various date ranges, sources, and states, which shows $11,180.32 in tax, categorized as 'CSV', representing the Varago Sales Tax. The remaining NC and SC amounts total $3,189.66 in tax, which matches Shopify when filtering out Florida. One other small item to note is that there may be some variance in tax-due estimates from Zamp and Shopify due to time zone differences, timely filing discounts (such as those in Florida), and other factors mentioned in this article . I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Scott, Thanks for following up and for your continued patience. We've been investigating this and found that this address is showing up as an 'Unknown address' within our Address Validation service. This means that it is an address not present in the USPS address data, along with other address data we utilize. Using a separate address validation tool , I was able to confirm the above. When I enter the street number and name separately, the address below is displayed; however, it's marked as an invalid address within USPS data and our own records. 2071 Kimberton Rd, Phoenixville, PA 19460 That said, the above address will validate with Zamp's Address Validation API endpoint. In a situation like this, we recommend using an address nearby or asking the client for an address that is available to receive US Mail (as this should validate on our end). We also recommend ensuring that Zamp's address validation does not prevent invoices from being created and processed if the zip code is valid or the address is validated using an alternative method. While this isn't perfect, it would be a way to allow invoices/orders to proceed. Addresses that don't validate with our endpoint should be rare, but we occasionally encounter them from time to time. Zamp is currently exploring various ways to improve the handling of addresses in these situations, and I'll be sure to bring this scenario to the attention of our product and engineering teams. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

body: Hi Jason, Thank you for the follow-up and for your continued patience. This past week, the Zamp Team attended our annual in-person off-site, and our response times were delayed. After reviewing New York, we've confirmed that we can recalculate the tax that should have been collected in New York for the New York fiscal quarters (Q4 2024 and Q1 2025). From what we've been able to review on the NY Transactions, I do not see any tax collection from Shopify for the kits and accessories (a Bamboo Whisk and a bottle on the wholesale site). With our current level of access in Shopify, I'm unsure if this is occurring because the 'Charge taxes on this product' box is unchecked on the product(s). I'm also going to review the other Shopify stores in more detail, as I noticed one or some are related to B2B/Wholesale transactions; we'll likely want to exclude those here. Would you like to schedule a call to discuss this and the best path forward, or would email be better for you? For now, I will work on recalculating only the kit and accessory items on your Shopify NY Transactions from December 1, 2024, to May 31, 2025 (NY Q4 2024 through Q1 2025). Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Katelynn, Thanks for your patience here! After further examination of the Gross Sales, it became apparent that the 'Tax Amount' was included in the 'Amount' listed for each invoice. So, I subtracted the 'Tax Amount' from the 'Amount' and re-imported the invoice data. The tax amount has remained the same. Now, the Gross Sales for August 2025 total $646,157.42. Next steps: Do we have your approval to proceed with filings this month?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Katelynn, Thanks for reaching out about this! We're looking into this and confirming the gross sales amounts; we'll follow up as soon as possible. Regarding the tax collected for Colorado: We show a total tax collected amount of $11,934.19 in CO. The $221.71 difference is due to what we call a timely filing discount in CO, and the CO Department of Revenue calls this a "Service Fee". In other words, the difference here is expected, and it essentially represents a "discount" offered by the state for filing on time. Timely filing discounts like this are (in most states) already accounted for within Zamp's tax-due estimate amounts. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: jhorsley@zamp.com
body: Hey team! In working with some customers we come across some interesting behavior with the address validation button. If you sell a digital product in WooCommerce , you only see the Billing Address displayed, but we still get an address validation button for validating the shipping address . Two asks here: 1)  Can we update this to if the address validation options are showing on a digital product it validates the billing address and the verbiage reflects this? 2) In addition would it be possible to add a configuration to hide/show address validation for digital products ? We have a customer who sells physical and digital and they don't want to validate for digital products as they say it confused their customers. Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification. Thanks! John

author: jhorsley@zamp.com
body: Hey team! New issue with the WooCommerce plugin. When you disable address validation, the option stays on check out. When you click the button it tells the user that address validation is disabled. Can we update this so if address validation is disabled the box to validate does not display? Thanks! John

author: donotreply@amazon.com
body: Deadline: 2025-10-06 Select one of the options below to view this email in another language: 中文 | 日本語 | Português | Türkçe | more Hello, We value the critical role you play in supporting Amazon sellers, which is why we're reaching out about urgent updates to your account security. Our records indicate that your Solution Provider Portal (SPP) registration is incomplete, resulting in immediate account restrictions. Current Status of Your Account Effective immediately, you cannot be added as a secondary user to any new Seller Central accounts. You have 30 days until 2025-10-06 to complete your registration and avoid losing access to all existing Seller Central accounts. Required Actions to Reinstate Full Access Complete these steps to remove current restrictions and protect your account access: For Service Provider Business Owners/Administrators, Virtual Assistants, or Freelancers : Register on Solution Provider Portal using your Seller Central secondary user email. Complete Identity Verification . Important : Your identity must be verified before you can invite any employees. Invite your Employees through the User Permissions Page in SPP using their Seller Central secondary user email. Add your Service and be approved for your required Seller Central roles. For Service Provider Business Employee : Accept the invitation . Complete Identity Verification . For Direct Employee of a Seller : Complete this form , external to amazon.com. Your responses are confidential and subject to Amazon's Privacy Notice . Once completed, you will: Have the current restriction lifted within 2 business days, allowing you to be added to new Seller Central accounts. Maintain access to all your existing Seller Central accounts. FAQ Who needs to meet the 2025-10-06 deadline? Only Service Providers who received this specific email. What happens if I miss the 2025-10-06 deadline? All existing Seller Central account access permissions will be removed. You will be unable to access any seller accounts in the future. Your selling partners will be notified of potential service disruptions. How long does processing of my Service and Seller Central Roles take? You need to submit your roles by 2025-10-06 with processing taking up to 10 business days. Why do I need to use my Seller Central secondary user account email when setting up my SPP account? When you sign up, use the same email linked to your Seller Central secondary user account. This helps us confirm you've completed all required steps and keeps your account active. Using a different email might limit or block your Seller Central secondary user account access. Are the required actions for Invited Employees different from the primary SPP account owner? Yes. Primary SPP account owners must: Setup the SPP account. Successfully complete identity verification. Submit the service(s) their business provides along with the Seller Central roles required to provide the service(s). Invited employees must: Accept their SPP invitation Successfully complete identity verification Do I need to migrate all my current Seller Central Secondary User account permissions to Solution Provider Portal by 2025-10-06? No, you are not required to migrate your current seller central secondary user account permissions to Solution Provider Portal by 2025-10-06. At this time, we only require these next steps: Set up primary SPP account. Complete Identity Verification. Invite and verify employee accounts. In 2026, you will be required to move all client permissions to Solution Provider Portal. We'll send you early warnings and step-by-step guidance before this happens. We recommend to start preparing for this change now. Need Help? If you have any immediate concerns, please check out our support resources: Understanding Solution Provider Portal Account Setup Registering as a New Service Provider Identity Verification Process Adding a Service to the Service Provider Profile Selecting Seller Central Roles SPP Frequently Asked Questions SPP Support Amazon Solution Provider Services team Report an issue with this email If you have any questions visit: Seller Central To change your email preferences visit: Notification Preferences Copyright 2025 Amazon, Inc, or its affiliates. All rights reserved. Amazon.com, 410 Terry Avenue North, Seattle, WA 98109-5210 SPC-USAmazon-897203630124719

body: Hi Bryan, Thanks for the quick response! author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, Thanks for the updates here! 1) Great! We'll import this data on Monday (10/6). 2) This is good and helpful to know, thanks! 3) I understand! Some systems are tricky. Yes—this report works for September! A couple of quick questions: Do we know the zip code for the Apex Human Performance invoice (HS-1032)? Do we know the zip code for the Rippling - Gabriel Ginorio invoice (HS-1025)? Without at least the city and state, or zip code, we would be unable to import the invoice into Zamp, as we use the address data to ensure proper state/jurisdiction reporting. Hopefully, the sales folks provide the addresses or zip codes for the two missing. Otherwise, we can include those in filings for October that are processed in November 2025. Have a great weekend! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: allie@handwrytten.com
body: Hi Chris, For September: 1) All of our normal September invoices that we discussed waiting until the ~6th to process, are entered. 2) We began syncing HubSpot and QuickBooks invoices on 10/1, so any invoices created in HubSpot should still show on your invoice report, as normal moving forward. 2) I could not for the life of me manage to export useful data from HubSpot to send you for sales tax purposes for September. Big learning curve here for me. :) I've entered any invoices created before the sync as sales receipts, and attached a report here. Does this work for September? These invoices are all for service or design, so none of these sales included sales tax. Although if you need more information let me know. I'm still waiting for a response from two salespeople if they have addresses for the two missing.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, Thanks for confirming, and once again (the millionth time) for your patience. We (Zamp) were at a company-wide annual offsite for most of this week, and our responses have been delayed more than ususal. 1) Noted and understood. We'll make sure that this is reported. 2) OK, this makes sense, and it may have been a miscommunication or something missed on our side; thanks for your understanding here. I vaguely recall this conversation, but I may be confusing it with discussions with other clients we work with. I've put multiple notes, reminders, and "triggers" of sorts into our monthly data process to ensure we wait to import Handwrytten's data until the 6th of each month. We won't need anything else to make this happen, as it's a process item on our end. I appreciate the offer! 3) Regarding Hubspot: This makes sense considering that the invoices have already been paid via HubSpot. Our current process for importing a custom invoice-list-based report wouldn't capture this. But maybe you or we can create a sales receipt report that we'll also import? We usually use this custom Zamp Sales Tax Report , and could include the 'sales receipt' record type. I just want to ensure it's accurate and does not include non-HubSpot data we'd like to avoid importing. I didn't see any sales receipts in QBO currently, and am just being extra cautious here. Does the data appear more reliable (including proper amounts, addresses, dates, etc.) within Hubspot or within QuickBooks Online? What would be the most efficient path forward for you in this situation? Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: allie@handwrytten.com
body: Hi Chris, 1) Invoice 9979 is finalized and paid, no updates needed, just needs to be reported. 2) We invoice clients monthly on the 1st of the month, for the previous month. These are always entered on the 1st but sometimes carry over a few days, or if the 1st is on a Saturday or Holiday, it may carry a few days late. I thought we had already discussed waiting until around the 5th of the month, but I could be having déjà vu. I would say that we definitely need to implement that delay in Zamp reporting, or our manual invoices from those clients will continue to be missed. Let me know if you need anything else from me to make that happen! Backtracking on the HubSpot question, we are most likely going to enter HubSpot transactions as sales receipts after they've been paid through HubSpot, rather than invoices in QBO to avoid the issue we keep having with paying tax on unpaid invoices, or sales reps mis-recording or lacking billing data. Do you see any issues with implementing the connection this way? Will Zamp still be able to pull that from QBO or should I just plan to share the HubSpot report with Zamp each month? Thank you again for all your help. -Allie

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, Thanks for the response here! So, ultimately we need to connect Hubspot invoicing to QBO in order for Zamp to report invoiced sales? Correct! This is likely the simplest or path of least resistance, but HubSpot's QuickBooks Online integration is one that I don't yet know much about, although it appears to be a well-built integration. The other option here would be for someone outside of Zamp to build a custom integration (with our API) between HubSpot and Zamp. Regarding #2 and #3 —you're right, and thanks for catching that! I was clearly writing too quickly. The only question left there would be why Zamp didn't pull that one invoice and I will include it manually in our monthly csv for September if you are unable to find record of it. (I wasn't able to find it searching for 2025 transactions in the Zamp portal). After reviewing the transactions in Zamp, the timestamps in our database, and the QuickBooks Online Audit History for invoice 9979, I'm not entirely sure what caused this issue. That said, my running theory is that although I exported Handwrytten's QuickBooks Online data on August 1, 2025, it may have been before the invoice was added at around 2:40 PM EDT. I can import a CSV file to account for this invoice (9979) using the invoice details in QuickBooks Online, as shown here . This way, we can keep track of this and keep one more thing off your plate. :) Questions: 1) Is invoice 9979 up to date, or are any changes needed to be made? 2) When are your or others' changes to invoices within QuickBooks Online typically complete? We could add a note to our process to remind us to wait until the 5th or 6th (at the latest) each month to import Handwrytten's QuickBooks Online invoices. In the past, we typically didn't reach the point of importing this invoice data until the 5th or later in the month. However, we've implemented several process improvements over the last approximately two months, which have led to this typically happening on the 1st-3rd of each month, unless otherwise noted. Please let me know if you have any questions. Have a great weekend! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

The only question left there would be why Zamp didn't pull that one invoice and I will include it manually in our monthly csv for September if you are unable to find record of it. author: allie@handwrytten.com
body: Hi Zamp Team, Hoping to reach Chris here or someone that can help with integration questions. We are switching our CRM platform from Pipedrive to HubSpot. We are beginning to send invoices through HubSpot and still will be sending invoices through QBO as well (currently still have QBO linked to Pipedrive only as we are all learning HubSpot). We had a minor issue come up with sales tax on one invoice and that led to some questions. 1) Does Zamp integrate with HubSpot? 2) We recreated a HubSpot invoice from one that existed in QBO already (9979 dated 7/31) - I thought this would cause an issue with us having filed tax on the invoice already, but we haven't. Any idea why this transaction was skipped in our integration? It works out in this case but just curious. The invoice wasn't paid through QBO yet but per our previous discussion sales tax was being reported on accrual basis, when the invoice is opened, not paid. 3) The new HubSpot invoice was paid today, but we forgot to include sales tax on the invoice. It looks like we should be able to void the original QBO invoice 9979 without reporting it to Zamp since it wasn't included previously? Then we can create another HubSpot invoice to charge the sales tax only? As always, thank you for your help! Allie Stone Bookkeeper Handwrytten (602) 603-5137 handwrytten.com allie@handwrytten.com 9280 S. Kyrene Rd #134, Tempe, AZ 85284

Jess Jess Ouellet, CPA Group Finance Manager realisationpar.com From: Jessica Ouellet <jessica@realisationpar.com> Sent: Thursday, August 28, 2025 6:44 PM To: David Wells <david@doubleq.com.au> Subject: Re: Partially Refunded Order Tax Report Hi David, Sorry this got lost in a flurry of emails! Jen reminded me to look for it ;) I added a couple comments below. Thank I appreciate you already calculating the delta for us. Only question is how are you calculating the tax refund isn't that a direct data point? Thanks! Jess Jess Ouellet, CPA Group Finance Manager realisationpar.com From: David Wells <david@doubleq.com.au> Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2025 1:02 PM To: Jessica Ouellet <jessica@realisationpar.com> Subject: Partially Refunded Order Tax Report Hey Jess, Have reviewed available data and here's the proposed detail of data points, example data, and logic. We would filter and present only orders that are partially refunded (and thus affected by the tax calc issue), that is to say we will not show: - Line-item level refunded orders - Whole order refunded orders - Orders 'refunded' by store credit Agree I only want to see "Order Level Refund". "Partially Refunded Order Tax Report" Direct Data Order Level "id": 218, "total_ex_tax": "64.5300", "total_inc_tax": "69.8400", "total_tax": "5.3100", "payment_status": "refunded", "refunded_amount": "0.0000", YES I will use this to understand the proportionate refund and tax to be refunded. "tax_provider_id": "BasicTaxProvider", Product Level (used to exclude line-item level refund orders) "is_refunded": true, "quantity_refunded": 1 Calculated Data Partial Tax Refund Owed Yes based on "Total Tax" X "refunded amount" / "Total Ex tax"? Partial Tax Refunded How is this calculated is it not a direct data point? Delta Partial Tax Refunded / Owed Amazing Cheers, DW -- David Wells DoubleQ m/ +61408319807 w/ doubleq.com.au

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tzippy, Thanks for your patience; I hope your weekend was enjoyable. I've imported all of the partial refunds (late discounts), created adjustments for the issue where Shopify shouldn't have charged tax, and ensured the GMA transactions were properly accounted for. While reviewing the ReturnGo transactions (one by one, in Zamp + Shopify), I realized that we wouldn't need to make any adjustments because Zamp has the original (unchanged) transaction with tax broken out separately, and any refunds associated with returns were also properly accounted for. I'm happy to show you how we sorted this out; if you'd like to h op on a call sometime , I'd be glad to do so. This is similar to how Zamp works with Loop transactions, although it's trickier to tie together because the ReturnGo exchange and return transactions each have an ID separate from the original order; there wasn't an ID tying them all together. I will have a tax-due estimate in your hands within the next few minutes. Please let us know if you have any questions! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tzippy, Thanks for the updates! I'm reviewing the transactions and there are a few non-taxable transactions that Shopify collected tax on. I am refunding the sales tax on my side. How will you adjust from taxable to non-taxable? In these scenarios, we would need to create a couple of transactions to fully account for this change and create a clear accounting line of separation: A complete and separate transaction, which is a refund of the entire order's amount (including tax). A separate order transaction without tax and likely a 'Purpose' value of 'RESALE' if the transaction was a resale/wholesale transaction, otherwise we also have the supported tax-exemption reasons noted in this article . As long as we know the Order IDs associated with this situation, we can make an exception to create the transactions on our end. In the future, it would be helpful to have these details in a CSV file. We share how to mark customers as tax-exempt within Shopify so that Zamp automatically recognizes this in this article. This helps for future Shopify orders or scenarios where you know ahead of time that the customer is tax-exempt. Regarding the CSV files: We'll work on importing the GMA Transactions today. I'm glad to hear that the ReturnGo issue has been fixed; that's great news! Can I set up a call to review the transactions with someone tomorrow? Sure! I appreciate your patience with us. We can schedule a call to review these transactions using this link . Most available time slots will be in the afternoon or later evening (EST). We have more time available tomorrow (9/10/25) if these time slots won't work for you.

Thank you, Tzippy Tzippy Schloss Next Step Group 681 Fifth Avenue, FL 14 New York, NY 10022 (212) 273-2614 tschloss@nextstepgroup.com

author: jason@shopravella.com
body: Hi Chris, For the next set of filings, can you double-check there are no sales taxes being charged for orders under the customer name "SHOPMY". This is a platform for influencer gifting, and they are free gifts (i.e. $0 orders; 100% discount), so there should not be any sales taxes ultimately. There will be about 30-50 of these Shopmy orders per month -- all should have NO SALES TAX. Below is an example -- in our account if you search "ShopMy", it will show all of these orders to the customer "ShopMy, Inc.": Below is an example order: Thanks, Jason On Thu, Aug 14, 2025 at 10:10 PM The Zamp Team < support@zamp.com > wrote: Hi Jason and Bobbi, A quick follow-up here! First, we appreciate your patience and flexibility as it took longer to get to this during this month than expected. I've attached the supporting exports and working files for the filing this month; I ensured we kept the partially refunded adjustments in place. The amounts align closely, except for in the states noted below, and that reason is primarily due to refunds from previous periods causing negative amounts in local jurisdictions. We can move these forward into September or October 2025, as we have done in the past. California, Colorado, Illinois, and Virginia. Ideally, we'll have your approval or sort out any questions by the end of the day tomorrow (8/15) or Saturday (8/16) to ensure timely filing. We can flex until Tuesday (8/19) in these states, as their due dates are later in the month: Arizona California Massachusetts Please let me know if you have any questions! I'm also available to schedule a call , or I can be reached at 513-504-1463; I'm sharing this in case you need a quick review for questions, and making sure filing is timely. Next month, this should not happen so late in the month, as our team has grown and additional improvements are on deck to be in place before September 2025. Next steps: Would you like us to roll the refunds forward that are needed to be, and ensure that tax is recovered? Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp On Thu, Aug 14, 2025 at 10:03 PM Zamp Filing Notice < support@zamp.com > wrote: 🗓️ Returns due in August Hi there! author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Thomas, A quick follow-up here: we appreciate your continued patience. After reviewing the data further and revisiting this situation, I agree that the issue here is related to QuickBooks Online invoices being voided, modified, or having their addresses updated; it may also be related to missing Credit Memos. Next steps and questions: 1) Could you or your team provide us with an invoice list export from QuickBooks Online containing the data noted below for the date range of 6/1/24 through 8/31/24? Most importantly, the period from 8/1/25 to 8/31/25 is crucial, as it allows us to ensure that Micromart's filings are progressing smoothly this month. The invoice details we would need: Date Num Amount Tax (or Tax Amount) Ship To 2) Would you or your team be able to and comfortable with providing us with accountant access to Micromart's QuickBooks Online environment so that, in the interim, we can manually obtain the invoice data and better ensure the changes you've noted are captured in the future? Important: Please note that we're currently holding Micromart's filings while we investigate this situation and verify their accuracy. We will need to ensure that the filings are processed soon, preferably by tomorrow (9/17/25), to facilitate timely filings. I want you to know that I aim to help resolve this situation, find a path forward for future filings, and ensure we find a way to reconcile any past differences. We're also happy to discuss this on a call, which can be scheduled using this link .

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Thomas, You're welcome; thanks for your continued patience! What you're sharing here makes sense to me, and some of these reasons are likely the root causes. We'll look into it as soon as possible and follow up with an action plan. For now, I've attached an export of all of the transaction data within Zamp for Micromart. The situation here could be resolved in the future with our recently improved and released QuickBooks Online integration. Someone from Zamp will reach out about this separately.

author: thomas@micromart.com
body:
Hi,

Thank you for replying so quickly.

We have located the most likely source of 90% of the problem, it's to do with the initial QBO shipping addresses not filled with deposit invoices and we are working on addressing it internally first.
And I think it's also meaningful for ZAMP to look at the problem when QBO's invoices are voided/modified/address updated, our investigation shows those are not picked up and updated on ZAMP.

But in the meantime, we would like to review and potentially revise our state taxes filings from prior periods and for August.

Currently, there isn't a function in ZAMP to manually adjust the taxes being filed?

Would you please send me the ZAMP's sales taxes data stating the following? (from the beginning of time to Aug 31, 2025) Date Transaction invoice number Transaction invoice amount Tax amount State I have attached the comparison file put together by our team for the sampled period.

Thank you,

body: Hello Thomas and Team, Thanks for reaching out about this! This is interesting to hear, and we'll definitely help sort out the cause of this difference. For now, and until this is sorted out, we're holding Micromart's sales tax filings for August 2025, which are due this month. We'll keep a close eye on the state filing deadlines and work together to ensure this is resolved on time. To schedule a call, please use this link , and if the available times won't work for you (or your team), please share dates and times that will work for you. A quick question: When you or your team have a moment, could you please add Zamp ( integrations@zamp.com ) as an accountant user within your QuickBooks Online account so that we can export data for our review? If you prefer not to do this, please share an 'Invoice List' export from QuickBooks Online with the additional columns and invoice data. Date Num Amount Tax (or Tax Amount) Ship To We're also happy to discuss this on a call. Having an export of the invoices from QuickBooks Online will help us compare and identify the root cause of the differences, and share our thoughts on the best path forward.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes: Gemini notes are here for John and me. Important: We found that tax calcs in WooCommerce were using WooCommerce's standard rate tables with mostly state rates listed. This resulted in tax calculations in FL, where they shouldn't have been collecting. We disabled all standard rates and enabled Zamp tax calculations, while also ensuring their correct nexus states were listed. —- They use MyWorks to sync Woo orders to QBO. All of their orders come from WooCommerce, and QBO is just used to generate revenue/sales summaries, and they're starting to use QBO to balance/reconcile sales tax (but their process isn't super detailed.) Currently, Sandy has to manually edit QBO orders to fix the tax because QBO calculates only state-level taxes (or something) while Woo calculates more. Eventually, Sandy wants to avoid having to adjust QBO manually. We'll need to figure out: If they should sync directly from WooCommerce or QuickBooks Online. If they're a good fit for our QBO integration (might not be a path, considering ERP pricing.) They want to use the liability report, but it doesn't account for annual/semi-annual/quarterly state tax due/filed amounts if the filing period is still in progress (or not "over"). For now, they'll use the filing page in Zamp until improvements come to the liability report. The liability report is expected to be improved (through this initiative ) before Sandy needs to reconcile sales tax/accounts again. Also related: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/41295310/card_tables/cards/8960393548 NSAF follows a fiscal year, which spans from April to March, and this is when they need to reconcile taxes and ensure the books in QBO match. Next steps: 1) Delete QBO Transactions from the Alloy sync. 2) Sync transactions manually via CSV. 3) Send Sandy an updated estimate. 4) Check with Matt G, Carie, and Ashley about possible new QBO integration usage for NSCAF.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thanks again for your patience! After further investigation, we identified the cause of the missing Ketchum, ID Jurisdiction. Our engineering team let me know that we currently expect a 6% rate to be returned for all orders within Idaho because Zamp does not yet support the local city tax rates (sometimes called "home rule" cities), as we're currently unable to support filing in those cities due to the nature of the individual registration and filing. This means Zamp does not currently support local sales tax scenarios in Idaho. This is something that is on Zamp's radar to support. Next steps: Our recommendation here would be to hard-code the local city tax option for the Idaho cities listed here , along with the corresponding tax rate. If you'd like to take this path, please let us know. We can help you find these local ID city tax rates if you'd like. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: tiana@paragonprintsystems.com
body: Good morning Team, Following a thorough review of Idaho's sales tax regulations, we have confirmed that retailers without a physical presence in the state are not required to collect or remit any local sales tax. Therefore, the application of the 6% state sales tax rate on the order shipped to Ketchum, Idaho, was accurate. No further action or changes are necessary at this time. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Heather, You're welcome, and I'm glad to hear it! Let's tackle each of the variances here, and we'll ensure we're all on the same page. MA: the variance seems to be HOS4524727618 where Shopify reflects this as NY vs Zamp reflected it as MA. This variance is expected due to a known limitation in Shopify's tax calculations and reporting (it can also be expected depending on when the address was changed) when an address is changed on an order. Here, the tax amount and jurisdiction are not updated, and this is likely due to the payment already being processed at this point. Reviewing HOS4524727618 in Shopify, I can see that the address was changed on 9/2/25: Question —Would you like us to change this transaction in Zamp back to the NY address or leave it as MA? Typically, we recommend leaving the address as the updated address, since that's technically the correct shipping location; however, the tax collected may be slightly too high or low for the updated address. NY: Shopify for the quarter totals 19,451.62 which is a 31.11 difference now. Part of it being the line above. I am curious why we do not see the $200 discount in Zamp's figure. For New York, the difference is likely due to time zone differences (Zamp files in EST, while Shopify reports in PST for House of Spoils), and possibly a bit of sales tax rounding. We provide more details about the causes of these minor differences (less than 1%) in this article. The difference for NY shouldn't be related to a discount here. The $200 difference was initially caused by our system not yet incorporating the ~$200 in adjustments made, and I sent the tax-due estimate (and updates) too quickly. In Zamp, we see a tax collected amount of $19,483.06 : Our tax-due estimate and the Zamp Liability Report now show a similar amount, $19,482.73, for NY Q2 2025: We're certainly happy to dig into this further and trace the exact root cause, and at this point, we'll need to know if we can proceed with filings or not to ensure timely filing (NY and other states are due by 9/19-9/20). If we find that the root cause of the difference for NY is not what I suspect (time zones or rounding), we can help correct for it in the subsequent filing as well. I hope this is helpful! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Laura, Thank you for checking in and for your continued patience. This is still on our radar for investigation, and we've started an initial comparison between Zamp and Shopify. We hope to share more details within a few days. Please note that, based on our experience and research, Shopify's United States Sales Tax Report (this version, linked here , is filtered to states being filed this month) tends to align more closely with Zamp when considering the items highlighted in this article. This is partly because sales tax in the US is typically bucketed based on the shipping region (Ship To) rather than the Shopify Billing region. Zamp's Transactions page, filings, and various reports automatically adjust for each state's specific time zone when accounting for the transaction date, whereas Shopify utilizes a single time zone. I'm still noticing a slight difference, and we're working to determine the root cause. We'll follow up as soon as we can!

body: Hi Stephen, You're welcome, and thank you for the update! This is interesting to hear and see. I've long had a suspicion that there is a delay between Shopify's reporting (especially the tax-related reports) and actual orders. Still, I've been unable to find exact proof of this. My guess here is that in this situation, the differences previously seen may have just been to delays and timing issues (utilizing different time zones.) Usually, variances between Shopify and Zamp's reporting of 2% or less are due to time zone differences. We appreciate you approving the filings! Regarding Shopify access: Thanks for the collaborator code! I've requested access with the minimum permissions necessary for Zamp to assist in review situations like this thoroughly, and for us to continue providing our fully managed service (e.g., reviewing tax settings, installing the Zamp Shopify app/connection, etc.). Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Stephen, Thank you for checking in, and again, for your continued patience! I've been looking into this further, and I don't yet know the root cause of the difference, as it doesn't appear to be related to a timezone difference or other common reasons noted in this article . Please note that Zamp's tax-due estimate should cover the period from August 1, 2025, to August 31, 2025, as the New York Department of Revenue has assigned Tocco Leggero a Quarterly Prepay filing frequency, and Zamp makes prepayments in the months when a return is not filed. Our estimate accounts for the following total tax in NY and prepayments: Total Tax Due Estimate for Q2 2025 (6/1/25-8/31/25): $26,491.97 . Prepayment 1 - July 2025: $7,511.24 . Prepayment 2 - August 2025: $9,002.19 . Remaining tax estimated due: $9,978.54 . A few questions: 1) When you have a moment, could you please share a screenshot or export of the report that you're using to compare within Shopify? This is helpful to ensure we're all on the same page, and can help confirm if the report in question includes Point of Sale Transactions (as some do not). 2) Could you also please provide the Tocco Leggero (Luke's) Shopify store Collaborator access code to us? This will enable us to regain access to our expired login and review and troubleshoot further. Shopify expires this access after a specific period, and we occasionally need to request it again. This is separate from our integration and the automatic sync of Shopify sales data. 3) Do you know if anyone on the Tocco Leggero Team manually edits Shopify orders or uses a third-party app to do that? This involves making changes such as adding or removing items from an order, issuing order-level partial refunds, or adjusting amounts on the order, among other actions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Saumil, Another follow-up here! We investigated the address validation further and found that the address noted below (from your screenshots) is either invalid or unknown according to the address data Zamp has access to. Part of this data includes address information from the United States Postal Service (USPS), which considers this address invalid. The portion of the address found to be invalid or unknown, with no potential address matches, is the house number, '300'. The Zamp API endpoint powering the address validation feature is documented here . The address: 300 N Madison St, Fortville, IN 46040 Additionally, we found through further research that this address appears to be located on a bridge within Fortville, IN, and isn't associated with an actual house or delivery location. This is based on what I found through a Google Search here . Related details to share: While reviewing our API logs, I found successful address validation API calls from your WooCommerce store to Zamp for the address noted below. 1 Apple Park Way, Cupertino, CA 95014-0642 We'll also start internal discussions with our Integration Team to explore ways to improve the address validation feature in the future. If you have any questions, please let us know! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Research for the address validation piece: Smarty views this as an invalid address: The 'Coordinate Precision' is too low (Zip9) and the 'DPV Match Code' is N: Zip9 means the address is valid only to a Zip9 level, the other address portions are invalid: https://www.smarty.com/docs/cloud/us-street-api?_gl=1*1by11td*_up*MQ..*_gs*MQ..#precision An 'N' for DPV Match code means that the address is not confirmed and does not exist within the USPS data: https://www.smarty.com/docs/cloud/us-street-api?_gl=1*dm2vky*_up*MQ..*_gs*MQ..#dpvmatchcode One other useful detail is that the 'DPV Footnotes' value of 'AAM3' means: AA - The street name, city, state, and zip are all valid. M3 - The address' house number (primary number) is not valid - this is the '300' portion. https://www.smarty.com/docs/cloud/us-street-api?_gl=1*1s2vjga*_up*MQ..*_gs*MQ..#dpvfootnotes We're using Smarty behind the scenes here, and this documentation is related.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Saumil, Thanks for your patience with this! We're going to start diving into this now and hope to have an update ASAP. To help expedite the process, could you please provide us with access to a staging or test version of your site? The staging/test site must have the same theme, customizations (e.g., within the theme's functions.php file), plugins, and overall configuration as the live site. Regarding setting a tax code and questions #1 and 2: Our Integration Team is planning and will soon be working on an improvement for the tax code setting situation and handling. Currently, they're finishing up some upgrades to Zamp's sales tax calculation handling and caching. The Tax Code setting on products and a few other items is next up on the list. For now, you should be able to set tax codes for your products by navigating to WooCommerce --> Settings --> Zamp Tax --> Tax Codes . You can assign the correct tax code as shown here: There is also a 'Bulk Tax Codes' option once you're within the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin settings. Regarding Address Validation and #3: This is the one we're investigating further, and having access to a staging/test site would be helpful. I hope to have an update about this tonight, but at the latest by tomorrow (9/4).

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Amy, Thank you for reaching out and for your patience. Zamp might need to know the details associated with these refunds by having the Pro's Closet Team share a CSV file that matches the guidelines outlined in our article here . The essential and minimum details we would need to know are: The amount refunded, excluding tax. The tax amount that was refunded. The Ship To address (minimum of a 5-digit zip code). The original Order ID. The date of the refund. That said, and to ensure we're on the same page, could you please confirm whether the refund is being processed as an order-level, partial refund, a line-item-specific refund, or separately through the payment processor? We're also happy to review some examples if you have Shopify Order IDs that can be shared as examples!

author: erik.weibel@keylight.com
body:
Hi Rangi,

Thank you for the update around point number 1. Regarding the other topics I can update as well. The address validation hook is optimized on SBX https://pronto-marketing.sbx.keylight.com/configuration/hooks/ag8mlu8m5h16jgzqzp1a8usf/actions/60kzw6yusenfp1h9bl2o2x4b
It does exclude addresses outside the US in order to not validate them for Zamp. In addition the script fills up the zero's in order to make the Zip consistent.

If we now look at the hook code, you will see starting from line 64 three options configured:
Lines 64 - 73, this function just throws the error, also per default
Lines 75 - 88, contains a function that could push a status to a custom field that could be created and added into the code.
Lines 90 - 100, here is a similar functionality but this could be used to tag the account with a tag accordingly if the validation failed.

These three methods could also be combined. If you now just take this hook code to production, it would perform the first option, showing a generic error.

You could use this as a basis now to be tested and implemented further for prod.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Regards,
Erik

Am Mi., 17. Sept. 2025 um 10:17 Uhr schrieb Rangilei Bernardo <rangilei@prontomarketing.com>:

Hi Erik,

I have a few updates and follow-ups we'd like to discuss with you: 1. Bad Debt & Commission Products: After internal discussion, we've decided to add the R_SRV code to both commission and bad-debt products, and we'll also change how we handle bad-debt orders. So for now, we can hold off on making any API change to stop these products from pushing to Zamp. 2. Address Validation Hook & Integration: I pushed this to production earlier this week. However, a new client attempting to sign up couldn't save their billing address, as the Client Portal returned a "Something Went Wrong" error. Disabling the Hook and Integration resolved it. The client's address is in the UK. Could you advise how we can re-enable this integration while ensuring clients are able to save their addresses without encountering errors? Integration: Zamp (Validate Address) Hook: Verify with ZAMP 3. Invalid Zip Codes (Zamp requires 5-digit zip codes): Do you have any updates on the configuration your team have been working on to ensure Keylight adds leading zeros to ZIP codes?

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Regards,
Rangi

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi PoM and Team, Thanks for your patience here! We have excluded the transactions you asked for in your Zamp account. This removes them from any reporting and economic nexus analysis; it also prevents the transactions from being recreated later. These were the transactions in the ' 1. Remove from Zamp (22 Jul - 26 Aug 2025) ' file. We have also imported the missing transactions from the file ' 2. Need to add into Zamp (22 Jul - 26 Aug 2025) '. To ensure commission expenses and bad debt are properly excluded from sales tax reporting, do you have any suggestions on how we can implement this within the API integration? We would recommend consulting with the Keylight Team to figure out the best path forward, since this will depend on configuration, customization, or other factors within Keylight's system. For example, is there a specific tax code, hook, or API condition we can use to exclude these types of transactions from being synced to Zamp? Zamp does not have tax codes for commission expenses or bad debt because these are not sales, orders, or transactions involving the sale of a service or product to a customer. From Zamp's perspective, we recommend excluding these transactions in a way that prevents them from syncing. If Keylight has different record types that can be used, we recommend using one that can be configured not to sync with Zamp. I hope this helps!

author: pom@prontomarketing.com
body: Thanks for clarifying, Christine! Dear Zamp and Keylight team, To ensure commission expenses and bad debt are properly excluded from sales tax reporting, do you have any suggestions on how we can implement this within the API integration? For example, is there a specific tax code, hook, or API condition we can use to exclude these types of transactions from being synced to Zamp? Your guidance on this would be very helpful. Regards, PoM

author: christine@zamp.com
body: Hi PoM, Yes, the default tax code for all items without a specified tax code is R_TPP which represents Tangible Personal Property. These items are fully taxable in every state. Regarding your second question, if the transaction only includes commission expenses and bad debt, we would want you to exclude these transactions entirely from the sync to Zamp. Let us know if you have any other questions. Thanks, Christine

author: christine@zamp.com
body: Thanks @chris ! She asked at the end if these should be excluded from the sync entirely. I'm just going to respond letting her know that we wouldn't want these in the sync.

I'll research this more tonight/tomorrow and see if we were ever told which Keylight transactions sync to Zamp, and when. I'd bet that the Pronto team is recording commission expenses and bad debt incorrectly, or Keylight may not fully support that. There's a wide range of things it could be!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Zoya, Thanks for your patience with this. 1) Regarding your first question: Why did we file $0 returns then? We looked into this further and found that the reason $0 filings for August 2025 are set to be processed for Science on Call in New York and Virginia is that your products (Technical Support Services) are tax-exempt in these two states. Additionally, it appears that the tax collection you're seeing (nearly $8,000) was collected in Texas and Nebraska. All of Science on Call's other state sales tax registrations are assigned Quarterly or Annual filing frequencies. In other words, most of those states won't have a filing due until October 2025 (for Q3 2025) or January 2026 (for 2025). The Quarterly states, such as FL, CA, NC, VT, IL, and NY, where Zamp has filed so far, did not have any tax collection in Stripe. Texas has a quarterly filing frequency. Nebraska has an annual filing frequency. Important note —we're investigating what happened with Science on Call's Q2 2025 Texas filing. The sales tax collection we're seeing within Stripe and your Zamp account is primarily within Texas and Nebraska: The above screenshot is a pivot table created from the Stripe Sales Tax Report that you shared, and this is close to what we see in Zamp on your Taxes Collected Report as well. Here's the total I see on your Zamp Transactions page: 2) Regarding your 2nd question: Aren't you using Stripe as your source of truth? Yes—Zamp uses Stripe as our source of truth by using Stripe's APIs and system to sync transaction data over to Zamp. Meaning, Zamp builds its own reports and transaction records based on details automatically synced from Stripe. 3) Regarding your third question: Are we sitting on $8K of Sales Taxes that need to be returned to customers? No—to our understanding and review, the tax that has been collected will be remitted. I'm investigating a few items regarding Texas, and we may need to escalate this to our Engineering Team for further review. A quick question for this month's filings: Do we have your approval to proceed with Science On Call's NY and VA filings, which are due this month?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Team! Thanks in advance for your assistance here! I have a bug to report for the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin that John Horsley and I confirmed today. I've also attached a JSON file with an example API call to Zamp. The issue we're seeing: Discounts are being applied at the item and order levels on WooCommerce orders once they are synced to Zamp, resulting in a discrepancy of $18.80; essentially, an extra item-level discount is being applied in Zamp. The shipping and tax amounts are correct. Within WooCommerce: An order is placed with a coupon that appears to offer a $92.20 discount at the order (header) level. The discount appears to be applied at the item level, and the total after discount is $77. The coupon is noted at the order level for $92.20. The order total is $93.73. Within Zamp: The order shows a unit price of $188.00 The unit discount is $18.80. The order-level discount is $92.20. The Order total is $112.53. The WooCommerce order: The Zamp order: Steps to reproduce: Install the Zamp Tax plugin v1.0.5 with at least these additional plugins: WooCommerce v10.0.4 WooCommerce Stripe Gateway v9.7.0 WooCommerce Subscriptions v7.7.0 Buy Once or Subscribe for WooCommerce Subscriptions v5.1.1 Configure a simple product that is taxable with the following settings: Subscriptions —> Interval: every month. Subscriptions —> Discount %: 10 Enable a recurring product discount under Marketing —> Coupons for a set amount: Assign the coupon to a specific product: Within the Zamp Tax Settings: Enable Arizona as a nexus state. Ensure the Default Product Tax Code is R_TPP. Enable tax calculations. Place an order utilizing this discount. We also have access to this specific customer's staging WooCommerce site, and I've made the login available for 7 days; it expires after the first view. The login can be viewed using this link . An example of this behavior is Order ID 1409 on the staging site. If another login is needed or there's a more preferred, secure way to share it, please let us know.

author: amit@multisoft.com
body: Hello, In the case of Colorado (and some other states), if deliveries are made by motor vehicle to a Colarado address when the transaction includes at least one taxable item then you need to collect Colorado's Retail Delivery Fee (RDF) of $0.28 per retail delivery. Retailers with less than $500,000 in Colorado sales during the previous year are exempt. Deliveries where all items are exempt from Colorado sales tax are not subject to the RDF. Colorado law mandates that the Retail Delivery Fee must be shown separately on the invoice or receipt, labeled specifically as "retail delivery fees", and distinctly separated from the price of items and any sales tax or other charges Currently on Shopify, for example, they combine it in the tax total though the reports shows it separated. Etsy shows it separately on invoices. So its clear that proper support is not consistent across all platforms yet but was required as of July 1, 2025. So in essence an additional tax for delivering anything taxable in Colorado. Does Zamp account for this in any way? Thanks, Amit Amitabh Dey CTO MultiSoft LLC +1 239 945 6433 amit@multisoft.com [url=//www.multisoft.com]www.multisoft.com 1859 Excise Ave, Ontario, CA 91761-8525 Cainta, Rizal, Philippines

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Roldan, Thank you for reaching out and sharing these details! A quick question to ensure we're on the same page—is the delivery fee for this tangible product the same as shipping or handling? If so, we recommend using the line item associated with this delivery fee as the shippingHandling value sent to Zamp for calculations or transaction creation, instead of a separate line item. This can be seen on our transaction object documentation here . Zamp's API and overall system are designed to either treat shipping as taxable or tax-exempt, depending on state rules, and this is done in a manner entirely separate from a transaction's line items. Which also means that Zamp does not have a tax code specifically for delivery, shipping, or handling. If you're referring to something separate from shipping or handling, please let us know, and we can explore other options.
