author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Lee, Thanks for the response and great question! So I am clear, if i go to the advanced pricing and select tax free and enter this code R_SRV_ADMISSION that product will be tax free? In many states, yes, the R_SRV_ADMISSION tax code for the product would cause the product to be considered tax-exempt by Zamp's API. That said, our Tax Research Team's current research and taxability determination for this code and admissions within New York would treat this product as taxable (not tax-free). We can discuss this further during our call today, but if you are aware from your own research that these products (registration/admission) should be tax-exempt in NY, the tax code R_TPP_GIFT-CARD could be used as a workaround, as it is tax-exempt in all states.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Lee, Thank you for reaching out and for your continued patience. We have an item that we want exempt from sales taxes, and although we set it up that way in bigccommerce, ZAMP is overriding it and adding tax, how do we exempt those sku's Ashley and I discussed this situation a bit earlier, and we also received the outreach through one of our contact forms. A product in BigCommerce can be exempted from tax by assigning a Zamp Tax Code from this list to a product in the section shown below: We share some details about this in our article here . The product setting can be found under BigCommerce Admin —> All Products —> the specific product —> Pricing —> Advanced Pricing —> Tax Provider Tax Code . A couple of quick questions: 1) To help us better offer suggestions or guidance, what is the specific product involved here, and how/why is it exempt? 2) If a tax code is already assigned, could you please let us know the specific product, tax code, or an example Order ID so that we can review it further? We can help see if we have a tax code that fits here, or recommend an alternative that would achieve your expected taxability results. We're also happy to schedule a call if that would be helpful!

body: So as I was investigating the Texas tax collection option question, I discovered that many of our orders that should have had tax calculated within BigCommerce has a tax of $0. You are calculating it correctly on the Zamp side, but the tax isn't getting relayed properly back to BigCommerce. As a result, we aren't collecting the tax from the customer when they pay. This is a big problem. I am not sure how far back it goes, but now I have to research it. I need to know that Zamp Tax has been configured properly. I'm compiling a list of transactions where this is the case. Thank you, Jacob Gorny Independent Consultant Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America Direct Line: 646-519-6573

author: amelia@zamp.com
body: Hi Jacob, Yes, we have you registered in Texas so you will want to make sure sales tax collections are turned on in BigCommerce for Texas. I am not seeing any immediate support articles that specify how to turn on a state, so let me get back to you with instructions on how to do so. Thanks,

author: jgorny@goarch.org
body: Hey there, I was wondering where we needed to enable this in BigCommerce? I decided to do a spot check and found that order coming through for Texas don't appear to be getting taxed. I'm looking at order 24589 where a personal order was placed with a texas destination and no tax was collected. Thank you, Jacob Gorny Independent Consultant Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America Direct Line: 646-519-6573

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi PoM and Team, An update here! After further investigation, I've confirmed the details below, and the good news is that we're still seeing sales tax calculations occur as of today (8/19/25). Transactions were successfully created within Zamp (using our /transactions API endpoint) from Keylight until August 11, 2025. There are very few errors when creating transactions between 8/6/25 and 8/11/25; it has decreased since 8/5/25. A log export from our side is attached, showing these errors. The majority of these errors are related to missing required details, such as a Ship To Zip Code, or invalid zip codes. I found logs of calculation requests sent to Zamp from Pronto Marketing for today, with the latest log creation at August 19, 2025, 10:25 AM GMT. The above means that calculations are working, but for some reason (possibly something within Keylight's system), transaction creation (successful or attempted) has not happened since 8/11/25. Please let us know if you have any questions. I will be following up on our other email threads today, and we look forward to speaking with you tomorrow morning (8/20).

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David, Thanks a ton for putting together those details! I'm still combing through those logs, and I will be sharing the timeouts and 5** server error situations with our Integration Team, as I believe those warrant additional investigation. Regarding the missing transactions: I finally remembered to look at the various BigCommerce system logs, and found my way to the "Staff Action Log" area and noticed the below setting being enabled: It looks like this change was made by me (reviewing the IP address, which is blurred out above), but I did not have any notes about this on my end. Usually, I'll make a note and share the finding/update with you. We will do better about this in the future. We also found some documentation improvements that will help catch this better in the future. What this means: To me, this means that the transaction sync (order commit) to Zamp likely wasn't enabled before 7/29/25, and the orders/refunds/adjustments that were synced before that date, probably had a payment change or something, that triggered the sync with Zamp. I couldn't find an example of that setting being enabled or disabled before 7/29: Next step questions: 1) Does the above make sense to both of you? 2) Jessica—are you OK with taking the approach noted below? We'll handle these steps. Export all data in BigCommerce (for all states) that covers the date range of 6/1/25-7/29/25. Exporting the same date range from Zamp. Compare the transactions for any missing items. Import the missing transactions into the August 2025 filing period via a manual CSV file. I would be able to have this done by EOD my Monday (8/25/25) if not earlier in the day.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: The troubleshooting/discussion with Blayzer is in a Basecamp 2 project they own, here: https://basecamp.com/2362279/projects/19420111/messages/110945128 Some useful details from Rusty (who I think was heavily involved in building this integration): Whether or not a payment is authorized is handled on BigCommerce and the Payment provider's end. We have certain required endpoints put in place and registered that BigCommerce then hits when they need to calculate, commit, adjust or void a transaction. I'm noticing the database on our end contains order transactions from 7/28/2025 and on to even today, but none from before that. The Zamp Tax Integration toggle that says "Send your transaction reports to Zamp" needs to be toggled on in order for the orders to be reported to Zamp and in order to have the transaction information saved to our transaction table. The setting in the Tax Provider section is BigCommerce related we don't control that. I did see some orders in August that were sending from Texas to other states such as New York that are not part of their Taxable States. These states won't even calculate tax unless they are included in the Taxable States array In response to someone toggling sync/provider reporting buttons on/off: It does sound like a possibility Chris. And here is the response from BigCommerce on that endpoint { "data": { "tax_entered_with_prices": false, "price_display_settings": { "show_inclusive_in_control_panel": false, "control_panel_price_display_strategy": "EXCLUSIVE", "invoice_price_display_strategy": "ZONE" }, "fallback_strategy": "BASIC", "should_subtract_store_tax": false, "should_use_geolocation_to_determine_guest_shopper_tax_zone": false, "guest_shopper_tax_zone_id": 1, "store_tax_zone_id": 1, "document_submission_strategy": "ON_PAYMENT_CAPTURE", "rounding_strategy": "RATE_RESULT_ROUNDING" }, "meta": {} } From Brandon (Blayzer): I see no rules in our CloudFlare for Australia, but I've whitelisted it anyway

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Akikio, Thank you again for your patience and understanding. After running through various comparisons of transactions within Zamp and Shopify, we realized that Shopify's documentation about the "United States Sales Tax report" has a bullet point consideration noting only to use this report to see Shopify tax data after 7/1/2024: The above details led us to believe that Shopify's United States sales tax report is only accounting for taxes from 7/1/24-12/31/24 in this screenshot: The above total is $144,722.69 when combining the 'Total Item tax amount' and 'Total shipping tax amount', which is close to what we see in your Zamp Transactions page for 7/1/24-12/31/24: Zamp is within 2.8% of the Shopify tax amount for the same date range , at $148,764.44. Shopify's documentation directs us to use the Shopify 'Taxes' Report instead, and the Shopify Taxes Report for 2024 for ACDC Apparel shows a tax collected amount that aligns more closely with Zamp's amount: Shopify's 2024 Taxes Report shows a total of $230,000 in tax collected when filtering by 'US' as the tax country and a 'Not filed' filter for 'Filed by channel' (meaning Shopify, Amazon, or another marketplace remitted the tax on your behalf). Zamp's tax collected amount was $236,000 on your transactions page , and Zamp's filings for ACDC Apparel last year were less than that amount, likely related to timely filing discounts. The above details indicate that Zamp is very close to the tax amount listed in Shopify, within 2.6%. There are some common reasons (we've shared before) that can cause slight differences like this. This also means that we do not believe Zamp paid more in tax for ACDC Apparel than was collected. That said, please let us know if you have any questions. We're also happy to schedule a call if that would be preferred, and I can coordinate with Amelia to ensure we're all involved in the conversation. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Marjorie, A quick follow-up here! I've made the adjustments this month based on the variances you noted. Please note that most are as close as we're able to get them at this time, due to refunds causing local jurisdictions to become negative (which no state, to our knowledge, allows.) This is something we can discuss, and I can share examples of it if we schedule a call. Ideally, we would have approval to proceed as soon as possible, to ensure timely filing and avoid any penalty or interest in states with due dates on 8/20/25. We can assist with additional investigation and adjustments (for refunds, especially) in future months. We aim to resolve this and ensure a smooth process in the future. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Marjorie, Thanks for letting us know. We'll start diving into this tonight. Please note that the minor percentage differences under 5%  (e.g., CT, GA, or OK) appear to be related to expected (and normal) variances tied to time zone adjustments, rounding, etc. That said, we can adjust for these as we did last month, to ensure timely filing. Zamp is utilizing MST, EST, and CST time zones for all of the states involved, while Shopify utilizes a single time zone (likely PST as Vetchy is based in Los Angeles, CA) when reporting transaction and tax data. The states with larger differences are interesting, and we'll figure out the cause. Those states are AR, CO, GA, LA, and RI. Although I don't see any Shopify third-party apps in use that appear to be the root cause, this could happen if Shopify orders are edited directly within the Shopify Admin's view of an order. We've seen this happen with returns, exchanges, or one-off customer requests (e.g., retroactively applying a discount.) For this month, I'll start working on making these adjustments and follow up as soon as possible. Next steps, toward resolution: 1) Could we schedule a call with Ashley and me to discuss potential causes and items that relate to this scenario? Ideally, we would sort this out and ensure we agree on a month-to-month action plan before filings start in September 2025. If a time that works best for you isn't open on my schedule, please let me know, and I'll see what can be moved around. 2) When you or your team have a moment, could you please share your Shopify Collaborator Access Code with us? This will help us regain login access (separate from our integration's sync with Vetchy's store) and significantly accelerate our review and resolution. This code can be found under Settings —> Users —> Security within your Shopify Admin.

body: Hi Chris, Sorry! I was out yesterday and couldn't check on this quickly. We are liable only if we haven't already paid tax on this client's Quickbooks invoice in 2024 (before we discovered the duplicate issue). They are currently using credits to place bulk orders that they prepaid for in November 2024, Invoice 8879 (11/01/2024). If we did not file this one as tax-exempt, then the API transactions should be tax-exempt until their prepaid credits are depleted (assuming we filed the correct sales tax for November 2024). Looking at the transactions in the Zamp portal I believe that this was included in our Nov-2024 Colorado filing, so the API transactions should be voided from the July return. Thank you, Allie

body: Hi Allie and David, A quick follow-up here! While preparing to file in Colorado, our filing team noticed a significant discrepancy between the tax amount collected and what Zamp would expect to file for CO. This difference is related to a large API (Website) transaction, and the ID for it is f0ceb5573174230a11fc24933e59e768b47d. Usually, larger transactions like this one are tied to QuickBooks Online, as the API transactions tend to be for smaller amounts. This is what we see for this transaction: Questions: 1) Should we delete this transaction if it should not have been created within Zamp? 2) Or should this transaction be treated as fully tax-exempt? We're attempting to determine if this transaction should have had tax collected. Unfortunately, it's tricky to decide on the intent based on the information and API logs we have. I'm available after 3 PM EST to hop on a quick call, and I can also be reached directly at 513-504-1463.

author: donotreply@amazon.com
body: You must complete Solution Provider Portal registration by 8/27/2025. Hello, We're contacting you because you haven't completed the required registration on the Solution Provider Portal despite multiple notifications. As a result, effective immediately, you can no longer be added as a secondary user to any new Seller Central accounts. To ensure business continuity for sellers who rely on your services, we'll be notifying them about potential service disruptions. These sellers will be informed that your access to their Seller Central accounts may be blocked if you don't complete the required registration process. Please take immediate action to prevent the loss of all existing Seller Central account access permissions and to minimize any impact to your business relationships. You must complete all required steps within the next 30 days to remove the restriction and maintain existing permissions. Why did this happen? You haven't completed the mandatory survey and, where indicated, the registration process, which includes the following: Completing the role confirmation form Following the instructions specific to your role Registering on the Solution Provider Portal, if required by your instructions If you don't complete the required steps within 30 days, all of your existing Seller Central account access permissions will be removed, and it won't be possible for you to be added as a secondary user to any accounts in the future. To restore full access, follow these steps: Complete this role confirmation form. This form is hosted on Qualtrics, external to amazon.com. Your responses are confidential and subject to Amazon's Privacy Notice . Follow the instructions specific to your role. If indicated in your instructions, register on Solution Provider Portal before 8/27/2025. To register on the Solution Provider Portal, the following actions are required: Creation of an account on the Solution Provider Portal. Successful completion of identity verification. Submission of at least one service category with Seller Central roles, status Pending , through your Solution Provider Portal account. The 30-day deadline applies only to service provider who have received this email. You're only required to submit your registration before 8/27/2025. The processing time (up to 10 business days) can extend beyond the deadline date. Support resources: Solution Provider Portal frequently asked questions Solution Provider Portal Support About Solution Provider Portal Amazon Solution Provider Services Team Report an issue with this email If you have any questions visit: Seller Central To change your email preferences visit: Notification Preferences Copyright 2025 Amazon, Inc, or its affiliates. body: @ashleyD - Yes, that would be part of it, at least for the calculation piece. Zamp doesn't yet support sales tax holidays either, so if they do configure their source systems (Shopify/Xero) appropriately, we'd report the correct tax. Still, the filings (taxable/gross sales) wouldn't correctly account for that piece either. For Shopify, it looks like they'd need to use Shopify Tax: https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/taxes/shopify-tax/choose-tax-service I don't know much about tax collection in Xero, but here's a very basic article about it: https://central.xero.com/s/article/How-automatic-sales-tax-works#Howratesarecalculated

author: chris@zamp.com
body:
Hi Roldan, Thanks for your patience here! I looked into this test API calculation you shared and found that a 0 taxDue amount was returned because the Zamp Tax Code R_TPP_FOOD-BEVERAGE_HOME-CONSUMPTION (which was replaced by Z-FBV000 recently) is treated as tax-exempt in Florida. A taxDue will be returned if no productTaxCode is provided or if R_TPP ( tangible personal property, fully taxable) is used instead. Here's an example of an API call that will return a tax due amount: {
  "id": "123",
  "name": "INV-123",
  "total": 23,
  "discount": 2,
  "isResale": false,
  "subtotal": 18,
  "lineItems": [
    {
      "id": "LI-123",
      "amount": 10,
      "discount": 0,
      "quantity": 2,
      "productSku": "SAMPLER-100",
      "productName": "The Ultimate Sampler",
      "productTaxCode": "R_TPP",
      "shippingHandling": 0
    }
  ],
  "transactedAt": "2023-07-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  "shipToAddress": {
    "zip": "33101",
    "city": "miami",
    "line1": "120 SW 10TH AVE",
    "line2": null,
    "state": "FL"
  },
  "shippingHandling": 5
} I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

body: Seller Central Invitation Become an authorized user for Begin Health! Dear Zamp, We use the Seller Central website to manage our Begin Health business in the Amazon store. I would like to invite you to become an authorized (that is, trusted) Seller Central user. The process is simple, just follow the steps below. Once complete, you'll have access to Begin Health's Seller Central account. Please note that this invitation will expire in 30 days. To start using Seller Central, complete the following steps: Open to the following URL in a new browser window. Be sure you're not already logged into an Amazon account. https://sellercentral.amazon.com/invitation/accept?globalAccountId=A2X1WBC3IPZWDD&invitationId=892a4104-cee9-491f-94ae-37bdbe4f69f9 You'll have to log in now. If you have an existing Amazon account for work, use that. Otherwise, create a new user account with your work email and a password. If your Amazon account uses the email address or phone number used in the invitation, you'll automatically get basic access. Otherwise, when you've successfully accepted the invitation, you'll see a message that you're waiting on my confirmation. Let me know you're waiting if I'm slow to approve you. Once I approve you, you can start using Seller Central at https://sellercentral.amazon.com . In order for you to do anything in Seller Central, I need to give you permissions to certain functions. If you can't access what you need to do your work, let me know, and I'll give you the right permissions. Thanks! author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - Another follow up! We can definitely help with this. We can export from QBO and maybe look for invoices with a date in the past but were created after we would've filed. It'll take a bit of finagling and we'll want to confirm with LizAnn. I think Cloud Ninjas TechTrade would also be a good fit for QBO. That said, we'll want to confirm how the integration will handle back-dated invoices, especially since filing periods aren't locked at Zamp. It may be better for them to hold off on using the new QBO integration until we have locked periods, if they don't want to change the back-dating invoice practice (e.g., invoices added after the 5th of the month that are back dated, would still be missed...) Or, the QBO integration will work if LizAnn provides us with a list of invoice IDs that were back-dated, then we can manually use the transaction update/edit tool to move them into a future filing period.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - We should be able to get to this with more detail next week (Monday is a ticket day for me, between naps while traveling). I think that we can bring in the invoices that were "missed" in prior periods into a future period as long as she shares a date range or even better, a list of invoice IDs. We can compare against Zamp and figure out what happened there. Yes—I think they'd be a good fit for our new QBO integration because it places taxes on an invoice as a line item, which is what she's used to doing already. I don't believe they're multi-channel, so it should be a good fit.

author: simon@sbcdynamicserp.com
body:
This is how we need to configure this for BC:- If tax has been calculated and filed by the marketplace, BC will not upload the order/invoice to Zamp This is how we have implemented the API by default. If tax has been collected from a platform and it needs to be uploaded for filing, upload to Zamp recalculate is set to false so that Zamp consumes and reports on the tax amounts as-is for sales tax amounts that were charged outside of Business Central API will be whatever ID the client choses for these transactions We will also use this option if the client starts using Zamp in the middle of the quarter or month and needs to upload invoices to reporting only. Regards,

Simon Kimani

Dynamics 365 Senior Solution Architect

Direct Call: 1-818-617-4665

Email: simon@sbcdynamicserp.com

author: kyle@zamp.com
body: There is a big difference between a Marketplace designation and an Ecommerce platform. A Marketplace designation means that no tax is collected and the transaction is treated as if the tax was collected by the marketplace provider and therefore you are not required to remit and file the tax for those transactions. A Shopify transaction may or may not have a marketplace designation so we do not combine marketplace and ecommerce platforms in the api options. Those options are exclusively for marketplace designation.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Betty and Simon, Chris here with Zamp Technical Success, chiming in real fast! We would highly recommend using the method Matt mentioned below. We'd recommend using the API name field for the original ID # from the source platform, and this way, the SBC Dynamics ID can be retained as the transaction's id (this might help avoid confusion with various clients). As long as you're passing the original ID # of the transaction, that should be sufficient (for customer reconciliation) and all of the orders from Shopify, Bigcommerce, Adobe/Magento, Shopware and Stripe can be passed as API transactions. The important requirement we talked about is passing them with recalculate set to false so Zamp consumes and reports on the tax amounts as-is for sales tax amounts that were charged outside of Business Central. Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: matt@zamp.com
body: Great Simon. To note, for Marketplaces, the most common we'll encounter are Amazon, Walmart and EBAY. Others we see once in a while are Faire, Etsy and TikTok.

author: simon@sbcdynamicserp.com
body: We will use OTHER for platform and make the other changes as described. Regards, Simon Kimani Dynamics 365 Senior Solution Architect Direct Call: 1-818-617-4665 Email: simon@sbcdynamicserp.com

author: matt@zamp.com
body: Hi Betty, The platforms you listed are not marketplaces like Amazon. The importance of the Marketplace designation is to confirm when no sales tax is required for remittance to the states (Amazon files it for their sellers per the requirements of the Marketplace Facilitator laws). As long as you're passing the original ID # of the transaction, that should be sufficient (for customer reconciliation) and all of the orders from Shopify, Bigcommerce, Adobe/Magento, Shopware and Stripe can be passed as API transactions. The important requirement we talked about is passing them with recalculate set to false so Zamp consumes and reports on the tax amounts as-is for sales tax amounts that were charged outside of Business Central. Kyle, John H or Chris - If you have any additional thoughts, please share. This is for ecommerce orders that have sales tax charged outside of Dynamics 365 Business Central and imported into Business Central for reporting. If they should use another field where they can flag the original platform (eg Shopify), it does provide customers an extra filter for reconciliation. Thanks, Matt

author: kyle@zamp.com
body: Regarding the 2 lines returned for CA freight it looks like you're hitting 2 different jurisdictional rules. If you note the compositeCode varies between the two return lines. In this case that is because you told us you shipped a line item that cost $0 but shipping cost was $100. We're returning the data accordingly and telling you that your $0 line item has $0 in tax for the sake of the line itself and a second entry to tell you what the shipping tax implications were for that line. If you followed a more traditional payload example where the shipping/freight cost was associated with the line item that is being shipped the return data might be a bit clearer. This is an intentional degree of denormalization. Regarding your second question about the registration data. I was able to query that endpoint using your token and it returned the data properly. What does your query request look like? Are you including filters?

author: betty@sbcdynamicserp.com

author: kyle@zamp.com
body: Catching up here on the thread it looks like there are 2 questions for me: 1. FreightShipping support: This is a month or two out from full support. When it is fully supported we will update the API docs with the details. Until then we only support a flat ancillary rate for shipping and handling. 2. Tax total aggregation values on the api response This is an intentionally generic response body. We have many customer who want to control their aggregation logic and opted to not aggregate the values for you. Instead we put this in your hands.

Regards, Betty Chebet Too Dynamics 365 Senior Developer Email: betty@sbcdynamicserp.com

Talk soon, Carie

author: msprague@zamp.com
body: Hi Joe, Thanks for sending this over! I'm including our tech success team as well for visibility. As a heads up, I am unable to open that sheet, but I'm assuming it's the orders from checkout champ with bad addresses on them. As we discussed, the reason that this is occurring is that the orders have bad data(incorrect address) and are not being updated in Shopify. We wouldn;t want to consume orders where the address is both incorrect and for the wrong state as that will change numbers. Additionally, if there is no sales tax being collected that could lead to further discrepancy. Our recommendation is to add address validation to your checkout champ/TaxJar integration to eliminate this issue from occurring on future orders where your customers are providing bad data. As an additional step, for orders where this has already occurred, you could send our team a CSV of those incorrect orders with the updated, correct address for our team to aggregate with your sales flowing into Zamp. We would want your team to have this sent over ASAP since we are approaching filing deadlines. Matt On Thu, Aug 7, 2025 at 12:27 PM Joe Bunag <joe@loveinfaith.life> wrote: Hi Matt and Taryn, Hope you're both doing well. As discussed, we've identified a number of transactions that are not flowing through Zamp. After checking, it looks like these orders were not taxed by TaxJar due to address inconsistencies during the checkout process in Checkout Champ, where customer addresses weren't corrected properly. While we're working on a fix from our side, we've attached a sample Excel file with the affected transactions. I'd really appreciate any input from your data team that could help us better understand or resolve this. Let us know if you need anything else. Thanks, Joe Bunag Sales Tax and Business Compliance Analyst ﻿ E: joe@loveinfaith.life W: www.loveinfaith.life ﻿ Faith is always in style

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chris, Another update! Overall, our recommendation here would be to adjust by the full amount remaining (of the duplicate tax) as the risks should be low due to the entity change and filing these returns as 'final' where we're able. This prevents a remaining credit/adjustment being necessary. So that you know, the details below won't be included in the tax-due estimate I will be sending out soon because they are states where Koio Collective has an annual or quarterly filing frequency. Although Zamp will be filing these as soon as possible (likely this month), Ashley or I will follow up to confirm. Our system won't include the tax-due estimate because the filings aren't usually due this month for annual or quarterly filing frequencies. There are two states where there will be a leftover duplicate tax amount (NJ and PA). Please let us know if you have any questions or would prefer to take a different approach.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chris, You're welcome, and I will! For now, I've attached a spreadsheet detailing the amounts that have been adjusted so far, an approach of adjusting by 50% (instead of the 10% adjustment percentage), and the amount and percentage we'd adjust by if you prefer we take the full remaining amount. There are four tabs/sheets within this file: July 2025 Tax-Due Estimate Amounts with adjustments by percentage. The Remaining Duplicate Tax Adjustment Amounts. The total duplicate tax to adjust for, by state. The existing adjustments that were made throughout 2025. I'm syncing with Ashley about this soon, but wanted to keep you in the loop, as we'll want to ensure these filings are moving through the process by the end of the day tomorrow. Please let us know if you have any thoughts or questions. I'll be following up soon as I'm jumping on a call with Ashley right now.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Namtarn and Team, You're welcome; I'm glad we could work together to sort it out! Yes—I've confirmed that the transactions within Zamp match the original file. A bit of background about what caused the difference: For a while, Zamp had a CSV data-specific import limitation, which only supported 10 line items per transaction. This has since changed, and we reverted changes we made that should have broken up transactions with 11+ line items into multiple. A few of the transactions (the 14 unimported invoices) had invalid addresses with incorrect city names, but Zamp missed this, and the error was silent; we're escalating something to our engineering team to improve the handling of this in the future. The invoices with "New York, NY 11232" should have been "Brooklyn, NY 11232". The invoices with "Cardiff-by-the-Sea, CA 92007" should have been "Encinitas, CA 92007". We'll look forward to speaking with you all soon!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Sandeep and Team, A quick follow-up here! I met with the customer yesterday for an hour or two, to troubleshoot further. First, I'd like to note that this customer is using version 1.0.5 of the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin (this is noted in the Sytem Status Report shared yesterday.) We tried the below steps in an attempt to isolate the cause of this duplicate tax issue, but the issue persisted: We switched the WooCommerce theme from 'the7' and it's associated custom code (within functions.php) to a default WooCommerce theme, 'Twenty Twenty-Four'. There was no custom code in the functions.php file, when this default theme was in use. We disabled all WooCommerce-related plugins, including: Additional Order Filters for WooCommerce: by Anton Bond – 1.22 AfterShip Tracking - All-In-One WooCommerce Order Tracking (Free plan available): by AfterShip – 1.17.17 The7 Elements: by Dream-Theme – 2.7.2 GAT Custom WC Error message for Rare Breed Triggers: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 DEV - GAT Checkout Boxes for Rare Breed Triggers: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 GAT Custom Functions for Rare Breed Triggers: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 GAT Remove WC Additional Info for Swag.: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 Mailchimp for WooCommerce: by Mailchimp – 5.4 The7 CLI: by Dream-Theme – 1.0.0 Theme My Login: by Theme My Login – 7.1.12 ELEX Stamps.com WooCommerce Extension (USPS): by ELEXtensions – 2.4.0 WooCommerce Conditional Shipping and Payments: by WooCommerce – 1.14.5 (update to version 3.0.2 is available) WooCommerce UPS Shipping: by WooCommerce – 3.4.1 (update to version 3.8.7 is available) ShipStation for WooCommerce: by WooCommerce – 4.5.2 (update to version 4.7.5 is available) WooCommerce Smart Coupons: by StoreApps – 7.1.0 (update to version 9.47.0 is available) WP NMI Gateway PCI for WooCommerce: by Pledged Plugins – 1.2.5 They updated the WooCommerce plugin to version 10.0.4. We removed and added 'Florida' back as a nexus state within the Zamp Tax settings. We still saw behavior with duplicate tax occurr like this: Additionally, we noticed some interesting behavior: The tax was displayed once (not duplicated) in their cart, and during checkout. Once the order was fully placed, the checkout confirmation displayed duplicate tax. The order in admin (the screenshot above) still showed duplicate tax. Interestingly, the duplicate tax was removed when the test order was canceled (this happened in 7+ test orders). An urgency update: This customer was delaying a large product launch (which needed to go live Wednesday, 8/6.) Instead of delaying further, they are reverting their WooCommerce store to it's configuration and state before installing Zamp Tax; disabling Zamp for now. They hope to have this sorted out by 9/1/25, if possible (~3 weeks.) They will be setting up a stage/testing site by Tuesday (8/12) and will share those credentials with me; I can pass along via one-time secret. I hope this helps and please let us know if we can share any additional information!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Sandeep and Team, Thanks for following up here! It's interesting to hear that the issue could not be reproduced, but it makes sense if it's tied to custom code or a specific WooCommerce plugin. Regarding the source code: I've attached the custom code that the customer noted they have running. This is the 'THE7-Active-Theme-functions.php.zip' file, which is attached and can be accessed after being unzipped. The WooCommerce Theme they're using is called the7 , but it is a purchased theme; I don't see an easy way to share this. I've also uploaded version 1.0.5 of the Zamp WooCommerce plugin they're using to the Google Drive folder here . Steps to reproduce the issue: 1) Install version 1.0.5 of the Zamp WooCommerce plugin. 2) Ensure the WooCommerce, WordPress, Database, PHP version, and other environment items match the details noted in the attached 'SystemStatusReport' file. This may not be 100% possible, but I'd imagine the items noted above would be a minimum necessary to see similar behavior. 3) If possible, attempt to have similar or the same plugins installed as noted in the 'Active Plugins' section of the attached 'SystemStatusReport', I think these would need to be checkout or tax-related plugins, which are: Additional Order Filters for WooCommerce WooCommerce Conditional Shipping and Payments Zamp Tax for WooCommerce 4) Add the code from the 'THE7-Active-Theme-functions.php' file to the WooCommerce store's theme function.php file by going to Appearance —> Theme File Editor —> select 'functions.php' on the right-hand side under 'Theme Files' 5) Place an order for a product that is set to be taxable and is located within a nexus state. This would be configured within the Zamp plugin's settings as noted here . From reviewing Indisea's test Zamp environment, I see that all US states with tax are enabled. I'd recommend testing this with Florida, as that is the state where we saw this behavior happen previously A quick question: Would it be helpful if I shared a login to the specific WooCommerce website in question here? This is a production site, so no changes should be made when logging in and reviewing. If yes, how would you prefer I share the login details with you? Would using One-Time Secret be OK with you? I'm also checking again with the customer about any other custom code because the plugins noted below sound like custom plugins that might be related to the issue here: GAT Custom WC Error message for Rare Breed Triggers: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 DEV - GAT Checkout Boxes for Rare Breed Triggers: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 GAT Custom Functions for Rare Breed Triggers: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 GAT Remove WC Additional Info for Swag.: by Joseph Simoneau - GAT Marketing – 0.1 object-cache.php: Redis Object Cache Drop-In

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Team, First of all, thanks for your help with this situation and on many other fronts! We are running into a situation with a new customer using the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin where the sales tax on an order is duplicated at the order-level and seems to be occurring at the line-item-level 3-4 times. This issue is likely caused by custom code, but we (and the customer's technical resource) are having difficulty untangling it. Tomorrow (8/6/25), the technical resource will try disabling all custom code and troubleshooting from there. Here's an example of what we're seeing: Troubleshooting Notes: Troubleshooting for duplicate/triplicate tax issues on WooCommerce orders in admin (the order confirmation email shows this as well): We ensure the Zamp tax settings were correct - the API token, nexus states, and the 'Default Product Tax Code' were set to 'R_TPP', and the Diagnostics page showed the message "Configuration looks good!" Their Woo tax settings looked fine: All prices and display options are set to "excluding tax". Shipping tax class set to "Standard". The 'Display tax totals' set to "As a single total" (the behavior persisted with this setting set to "Itemized" as well). We ensured the product in question (shown in the screenshot below) was: Set to taxable. The tax class was 'Standard'. No Zamp tax code was configured as the product is taxable. We first deactivated the AvaTax plugin as it was still enabled, and then completely deleted it. The customer's technical resource disabled some custom logic within the store's theme that was affecting the cart and product quantity. After that, we tested the following. Zamp's API logging showed the tax calculation requests coming across properly, and the taxDue returned was $36.33. An export of the logs is attached. The Zamp Tax logging in WooCommerce also appeared fine. I will ask the client's technical resource for a copy of this, as they had to end their day (they're based in India). We cleared or deleted the following under WooCommerce —> Status —> Tools: Delete All Tax Rates. Clear Transients (cached data). Manually removed all Tax Rates from WooCommerce —> Settings —> Tax —> Standard Rates. Still, tax is showing up 3-4 times on the item, and twice on the order-level tax lines. I let the technical resource know that Zamp's plugin calculates tax and stores it in the store's cache for 5 minutes; it is cleared when the item, a coupon, quantity, or address changes. Additionally: The cart cache is cleared when our plugin notices these hooks being updated: woocommerce_cart_updated woocommerce_checkout_update_order_review woocommerce_applied_coupon woocommerce_removed_coupon Questions: 1) Are there any items or settings that we should also check? 2) Do you know of any WooCommerce database methods/actions/queries that we should run to specifically clear any tax rates, cache, or items related to AvaTax after deleting the plugin? 3) Are there any hooks or classes within WooCommerce or the Zamp Tax plugin that could be causing this behavior or interfering with Zamp's plugin logic? 4) Does any of the behavior occurring here align with areas of improvement already found by the Indisea Team? Please let me know if you have any questions or if any additional information could be helpful here.

body: Hi Mary Beth, You're welcome, and thanks for sharing another request! I need to be able to print a PDF of the Transaction Report for each month, quarter, 6mos, or year, that shows all of the info on the Transaction Screen and if there are multiple pages, all of them need to be included. The CSV Report is cumbersome and not print friendly, nor does it show the Total $amount for the time period. Subtotaling by State would also be helpful, and it would correspond to the State filings Currently, Zamp does not have a report that matches precisely what you're looking for. That said, I will share this request with our team and we'll follow up once we have an update. This kind of request aligns with some items our Product & Engineering Teams have planned for later this year. One of these upcoming features is a state-specific sales tax filing report that would include these amounts. That said, I've shared this request with our team. For now, a way to do this would be within Excel, summing the amounts in the 'transactionSubtotal' column or by creating a Pivot Table in Excel. I've attached an export from your Transactions page doing this, and the Pivot Table is on the 2nd sheet. I've modified this report a bit, to be accurate and clearer because our export from the transactions page includes repeated rows for a single invoice, which is how our previous QuickBooks Online integration would display transactions (Each row was a line item on the invoice.) Please let us know if you have any questions!

Our Tax Research and Engineering Teams also released (very recently) some significant improvements that fully support the tax calculation and reporting for the Ohio sales tax holiday. We've also released support for the following clothing-item-related holidays: Connecticut : eligible clothing less than $100 during 8/17/25–8/23/25 Florida : eligible clothing ≤ $100 during 8/1/25–8/31/25 Maryland : eligible clothing ≤ $100 during 8/10/25–8/16/25 We'll also keep this on our radar, and our teams have roadmap items in queue to ensure the applicable sales tax holidays (for scenarios and product categories/taxability we support) are accounted for. Have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, Thanks for your patience here! I've confirmed that the route noted previously would need to be taken to cause BigCommerce to bypass Zamp's tax calculations essentially. This would apply during the sales tax holiday in Ohio, and these are the steps: Navigate to Settings —> Tax —> "Edit" next to 'Zamp Tax'. Instead of "one or more countries," select "One or more subdivisions" under 'Provider Targeting'. Select all states, except for Ohio. Save the change. Utilize the existing 'OH Sales Tax' Zone and update it to use a 0% rate, or create a new Zone. Save the changes. Then, this would need to be changed back to the usual setup (using Zamp Tax) on August 15, 2025. We can also discuss this during our call tomorrow, but please let me know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, On behalf of Ashley, you're welcome! We're currently investigating a potential solution for this because at the moment, Zamp does not yet support sales tax holidays. Still, I may have found a way to force BigCommerce to use a 0% rate in Ohio (using a combination of Basic Tax manual rates and Zones , along with the provider targeting noted here to unselect/turn of OH for Zamp.) I'm just doing some additional research and should have more details tomorrow morning.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - I may have a convoluted and manual way to support this if they decide to set up some kind of temporary and manual sales tax rate up for Ohio, but it'll be tricky and I'm not 100% confident in it.. They might be able to create a custom tax class and Zone in BigCommerce to do this, as discussed in this blog post . Likely, the best route would be to leave Zamp enabled and also set up some manual tax rates (with 0% rates) for Ohio. This should be able to work with Zamp based on what I've read in this BigCommerce article . They would essentially turn Zamp "off" for Ohio-only by using the provider targeting setup noted in this BigCommerce article , which should cause the manual rate + zone (Ohio) to be used. Zamp doesn't support sales tax holidays at this time. Here are some ask-the-builders cards about that: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/42435159/card_tables/cards/8903189116#__recording_8908409359 https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/42435159/card_tables/cards/8881240221#__recording_8904811908 I will try to get a reply out about this tonight, but it might not be until the morning.

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, Thanks for reaching out! Items that qualify for the Ohio sales tax holiday "include all tangible personal property that is $500 or less except watercraft or outboard motors required to be titled pursuant to Chapter 1548 of the Revised Code, motor vehicles, alcoholic beverages, tobacco, vapor products, or items that contain marijuana." Based on this information, your product would be eligible. You can find additional information surrounding this holiday here . Please let me know if you have any questions, Ashley

body:
Hi Renante,

Apologies for the double message-our Tech Success team just shared some detailed guidance regarding WooCommerce product categorization that they asked me to pass along. It's much more in-depth than what I previously sent, so I wanted to make sure you had it (see below).

They also offered to hop on a call next week if you'd like to discuss the recommendations further-just let me know what works best for you.

Thanks,
Caroline

For WooCommerce, they can set Zamp tax codes for each specific product by following the steps outlined here and also refer to the options here . There's also a section in WooCommerce -> Settings -> Zamp Tax -> Tax Codes and Zamp Tax -> Bulk Tax Codes, that they can use to set tax codes for many products. Here's the Tax Codes area: This is the bulk tax codes area: The product categories they're referring to here are categories that they (or their team(s)) create within WooCommerce, so it's a bit different from Shopify, and WooCommerce shares more detail about that here .

This is what that area looks like under WooCommerce -> Products -> Categories: The categories are completely separate (and self-defined/grouped) in WooCommerce.

Our WooCommerce plugin has functionality built into it that adds a "property" or way of adding a Zamp tax code to each product, so they'll handle assigning the tax codes we recommended by following these articles: https://support.zamp.com/article/60-zamp-tax-for-woocommerce-product-configuration https://support.zamp.com/article/89-zamp-for-woocommerce-handling-variable-products (only if they have variable products.)

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi All, Thanks for the update, Chrismer, and for your patience, Arlene Cycle Support Team! Chrismer, please let us (Zamp) know if you have any questions or items to discuss as the Chykalohpia Team works through solutions here. A few promised follow-up items from the Zamp side: Zamp's WooCommerce plugin uses the below WooCommerce hooks to interact with the cart and the WooCommerce cache: The plugin uses WordPress transients ( set_transient() and get_transient() ) to store tax calculation results. The plugin will clear its cache when these hooks are triggered: woocommerce_cart_updated woocommerce_checkout_update_order_review woocommerce_applied_coupon woocommerce_removed_coupon When the shipping address changes. A custom function may be hooked into the above WooCommerce actions with higher priority. The code associated with Zamp's tax calculations can be found in the following locations within the 'zamp-tax' plugin's code: includes/core/class-zamp-calculations.php includes/core/class-zamp-tax-provider.php The transaction sync, including the bulk transaction sync (which didn't work while on our call this morning), can be found in: includes/admin/transaction-sync The bulk or historical transaction sync is primarily handled through the code in includes/admin/transaction-sync/class-zamp-transaction-sync-batch.php . This process creates batches, processes them, and schedules them. Our plugin is using the WordPress Action Scheduler in batches of 25 for background processing. I hope this helps, and please let us know if you have any questions!

author: support@chykalophia.com
body: Hello Team, I'm happy to report that we've successfully integrated the Zamp plugin to handle the tax calculations on the checkout page. The tax figures are now appearing correctly, which is a big step forward! We did, however, have to temporarily disable the quantity adjustment feature on the checkout page. During our testing, we found that updating the quantity would clear the Zamp tax calculation, causing the tax to revert to $0. The Zamp team confirmed they use caching for these calculations, which is likely the cause. Chris and I have verified the new tax calculations are working as expected and have already pushed the changes live to the production site. We (Chykalohpia Team) are actively looking for a solution to sync the tax calculations with quantity updates and will let you know as soon as we have a fix in place. Thanks for your patience and understanding. Best regards, Chrismer Ambay 📘 Our new book Made to Sell: Creating Websites that Convert is the Top 3 Best Sellers in Web Design Chykalophia is a woman minority-owned creative & web agency helping Femtech DTC & women-led brands transform their website to unlock business opportunities. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chrismer and Team, Following up here really quickly! I hope all is well, and I just wanted to check in and share some recent findings. @Chrismer - Our call was scheduled for today from 3:00-3:30 PM EST, and I waited while checking some additional items within the staging site, but you were unable to join. I understand that life and various situations happen. I'd still love to connect and discuss what might be causing the tax calculation or transaction syncing issues we've run into. Question —When is a good day and time for us to meet? Are there times that might be outside a 10 AM through 8 PM EST schedule that work better for you? I can adjust my schedule or initiate the call scheduling from my end to enable this flexibility. We can reschedule using this link or schedule a new call with this link . Recent findings: While reviewing various items and testing in the staging site, I found that with the Stripe Tax plugin deactivated or completely deleted , the Zamp plugin initially returned a tax rate and amount. Strangely, after the checkout page finishes loading, the tax amount is reverted to $0. With the Stripe Tax plugin no longer in the picture as it was likely causing a conflict, I was also able to see tax rates and amounts within the WooCommerce store's logs for Zamp, and I confirmed that similar logs were available on my end (within Zamp's logging). That said, a bulk Transaction sync (utilizing Action Scheduler) was still unable to run and didn't appear to have been initiated. Questions: Does anyone know of any custom checkout page items or custom code that could affect or clear Zamp's ability to display tax during the checkout process? Is it correct that Elementor is utilizing "wc-blocks" as a part of the Gutenberg Project, which WordPress introduced in the Summer of 2017? Are there any interactions, plugins (e.g., the advanced-cache.php drop-in plugin here ), or customizations that might be clearing the cache during checkout after the tax is added? Zamp's plugin is designed to cache the tax rate for 5 minutes, unless a product or address-related item within the cart changes; then, the cache is cleared for a calculation to rerun.

body: Hi Allie, Thanks for the update and the great question here! The details you've shared here make sense, and it sounds like QuickBooks Online's automatic sales tax calculation service may view graphic design services differently, or they're targeting the " Custom graphic design services that may include inconsequential tangible personal property " towards something different from what Zamp would expect here. In this situation, it may be best to utilize the "Nontaxable" setting under "Other options" as I was unable to find a category that sounds like it would match the tax-exempt expectation here: Once Zamp's updated and greatly improved QuickBooks Online Integration is fully and finally approved by Intuit (we're still waiting, and have followed up), you would be able to utilize Zamp's tax codes instead. I hope this is helpful, to a degree at least!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, Thanks for sending this over! We'll review the invoice (9886) in QuickBooks Online to confirm. Still, our understanding was that the Graphic Design service best fits within our tax code R_SRV_PROFESSIONAL (Professional Services), which would be treated as tax-exempt in Virginia. Currently, this tax code is only taxable in these states: Alaska Hawaii New Mexico South Dakota

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tiffanie and Sean, Thanks for checking in and for your continued patience here. Regarding shipping taxability in Florida: I've confirmed that Zamp currently treats shipping as taxable in Florida, and we share more details about that in this guide . The short version is that as far as we know, the product can't be picked up in Florida as it's shipping from Arizona; Zamp also either treats shipping as taxable or tax-exempt (at the current time). Regarding the tax rate for transaction INV-4268732-001's address: The 6% rate would be correct here. We've confirmed using the Florida Department of Revenue tool here that this address falls within an 'unincorporated' area of Collier County, which is subject to a 6% sales tax rate instead of a 7% sales tax rate. I hope this helps, and please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Per the shipping guide, shipping is taxable in FL: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QRYS4Ffu7CR8-J7LRk-OG6BiDwgP2NyuO9avzu62la4/edit?gid=192905435#gid=192905435

body: Hi Rangilei, I'd like to follow-up on this situation. Please note that including the Keylight "Invoice Number" as the name within the API calls to Zamp will cause the "Invoice Number" to be displayed on the transactions page as the ID (shown below), instead of a new column: Then, the id value from the API call, which is also the 'transactionId' in the Zamp transaction expor,t would contain whichever value is provided in this column of the transaction export: Meaning, both of the following items would be shown in the transaction export: API call —> name = transactionName in the export. API call —> id = transactionId in the export. This export is obtained by clicking this button: I've attached a copy of this export for the 8/10/25-8/11/25 transactions as a reference.

body: Thanks @chris ! Did you want to review the Keylight integration further or should I send the following - Hi Rangi, Thank you for your feedback regarding the Transactions view in the Zamp Dashboard. I have added some notes below next to the specific requests - Invoice No. - We use the transactionName that Keylight's integration provides, but if one isn't provided, we fall back to transactionId , and Keylight would need to update their integration (specifically, their API calls) to include the Invoice No. as the transactionName . Then you would see this displayed. Zip Code - If you export the transactions page, the zip code will be displayed. Account Name - Not currently available Account Number - Not currently available We will add these as feature requests to our team. However, this most likely is not something our team will be able to implement in the near future.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @christine - some answers here: Is the invoice number not the Transaction ID? It should be the transaction ID, but as I recall from our call with Pronto/KeyLight, this ID is set by the specific values KeyLight's integration is designed to put. We use the transactionName that Keylight's integration provides, but if one isn't provided, we fall back to transactionId , and Keylight would need to update their integration (specifically, their API calls) to include the Invoice No. as the transactionName I'll review more tomorrow to confirm for sure, but it looks like Keylight's integration is providing the following: An id in the API call which translates into transactionId They are not providing a name in the API call which translates into transactionName Zip Code can be seen when they click into the transaction. Yep—they can click into the transaction or export the transactions to a CSV file; then, the zip code will be displayed. This could be a feature request to pass along to the builders. Still, I'm unsure how likely it is to happen unless we implement some customization feature that lets customers "pick" the columns displayed (adding a zip code would make the page seem cluttered, in my opinion). For account name and account number, should I just let them know that I will add this as a feature request but we will not be able to implement this in the near future? Yes—this is something that would be a feature request and Keylight (or someone) would likely need to update their API integration to use the Zamp API's metadata property so that their integration could store "custom" fields like account name or number; then that would tie into a feature request to allow customers to customize the columns of information displayed on the transactions page.

body: Hi Rangilei, Thanks for reaching out and sharing this feedback with us. We're reviewing and evaluating internally and should have an update to share soon.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie and Team, Thanks again for being so patient here! First, our team has grown, and we're implementing numerous improvements to prevent delayed responses in the future. Second, here's what I found internally at Zamp about how Handwrytten should charge sales taxes: Our understanding was that Handwrytten offered various digital goods/services, which are billed to a customer who might be different from the person receiving the item. In this situation and understanding, the recommendation was to charge sales tax based on the billing address. This is what I've gathered from various conversations and notes on the Zamp side. General details to share: Generally, sales tax should be charged based on the billing address for digital goods/services, as items aren't physically shipped. Then, if physical goods are shipped, sales tax would be charged based on the shipping address . Next steps: Do you think the above details help here? Would you like us to run any specific scenarios by our Tax Research Team for additional confirmation?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Hanna, Thanks for getting in touch with us about this! Could you please explain what logic you use to handle precision differences? Sure! In general, Zamp will round amounts either up or down, but always to two decimal places, when calculating the taxDue for a transaction or jurisdiction. The above means that Zamp is always rounding to the nearest cent, with a precision of $0.01. The specific logic involved varies from state to state, as some states require sales tax to be rounded up, while others require it to be rounded down. Would it be helpful to you if we ask our engineering team for additional details here, at least for California?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @carie - Yes, I think this could be a support article, pretty much noting that Zamp has all kinds of sales tax and state-specific logic built into rounding for calculations, transaction creation, and by jurisdiction, where required by various state rules. In some scenarios, we round up and in others, we round down, based on state or jurisdiction-specific logic. In general, Zamp rounds to two decimal places as our API and app don't accept more than 2 decimals.

author: onboarding@zamp.com
body: Hi Stacey, Thank you again for sending over all the CSV files. I just heard back from our data team, and it looks like the format they were sent in isn’t compatible with our Amazon upload system. They provided the following steps to ensure the files are exported correctly: *Steps to Export Transactions from Amazon:* 1. Navigate to the top-left menu on the Amazon homepage 2. Hover over *Reports* and select *Fulfillment* 3. Under *Most Popular Reports*, select *All Orders* 4. For the date range, select *Event Date* > *Exact Dates* 5. Download data *one month at a time* (Amazon only allows monthly downloads) 6. The file format should be *.txt* If you're able to resend the files using this format at your convenience, that would be greatly appreciated. Please note I’ll be out of office next week (7/28–8/1). If you're able, feel free to include *support@zamp.com <support@zamp.com>* when you send the updated files so the team can help with the upload in my absence. I’ll be checking my email periodically as well if anything comes up. Thank you again for your help! Caroline How would you rate my reply? Aug. 2025 um 16:30 Uhr schrieb Rangilei Bernardo <rangilei@prontomarketing.com>: Hi Erik, Following our meeting this week, there are two open issues with the Keylight & Zamp integration that need to be fixed (points 2 and 3 below), and we need your input on point 4. 1. Transactions incorrectly appearing in Zamp upon order creation This issue looks resolved in both Production and SBX. Draft orders are no longer creating transactions in Zamp. 2. Incorrect Transaction ID formatting in exports When exporting transactions from Keylight (via this data view ), some Transaction IDs display as #NAME? in CSV/Excel because the IDs start with a hyphen (-) and are interpreted as formulas rather than text. This results in showing the #NAME? error instead of the actual ID. See screenshot below: Could you please update the export formatting so that Transaction IDs appear as either plain text or do not start with a hyphen? 3. Missing transactions in Zamp The Keylight transactions listed in this spreadsheet are missing from Zamp. As recently discussed with Zamp Support, this could be related to the shipping address fields, which we don't use but appear to have been re-enabled in Keylight after the latest updates. Please investigate the root cause and resolve it so both systems remain in sync. 4. Access to API failure logs Could you provide instructions on how to access API failure logs for this integration so we can easily identify which transactions failed to import into Zamp? Please confirm your timeline for resolving these items and let us know if you need any additional details. Best, Rangi

body: Hi, I spoke with our engineering team and they found a bug with the Zamp integration. Instead of calling the "calculate tax" API, they are calling the commit transaction API. This is why all calculations are showing up as committed. This is being fixed & tested right now. We will have a patch out as soon as possible. Thanks, Kevin

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, Thanks for your patience here! In these scenarios, it should be fine to issue the refund through Stripe and then notify us when this happens. We can then review the Stripe Transactions within your Zamp account and adjust for the refunded tax accordingly. Our typical recommendation would be to void the transaction with tax collected, and create a new transaction without tax after the customer has been marked as tax-exempt in Stripe. That said, I understand this may not be simple when Stripe subscriptions are involved, and this will likely mean we need to take a manual adjustment approach on the Zamp side for now. To ensure we're on the same page and that the tax is accounted for correctly, could you please share an example Invoice or Transaction ID that requires a tax refund? I'd like to review how our Stripe integration handles sales tax only refunds in this situation. After that, we can help adjust for this transaction and recommend the most efficient approach for all involved when handling these situations in the future.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thanks again for your patience with this! Our Tax Research Team reviewed the tax rate situation here and found that Zamp is correct in returning a 6.75% rate. We found that while the state's rate locator is stating that this address (MADISONVILLE, TX 77864-2315) should be inside the city and include the additional 1.5% city rate, the address is outside of the city limits. Here's a screenshot from the Madison County, TX, interactive maps : Note : the yellow line is the city boundary, and this address falls outside of it. This situation is why sales tax rates, various lookup tools, and even location/geography data can be tricky to work with. While they're a good reference, they may be missing part of the picture. Various folks on the Zamp side have started some discussions around how we can best surface information to help in situations like this, and we may have feature(s) to help increase the transparency in the future. Have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: I need to follow up here with the below details, we think the 6.75% rate is correct and the TX rate lookup tool is wrong. https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/42435159/card_tables/cards/8898358217 we are correct in returning 6.75%. While the state rate locator says it should be inside the city and include the additional 1.5% rate, this is not true. This address is outside city limits. I have attached a screenshot from the Madison County interactive maps. (Yellow line is the city boundary) I see you were using Google Maps for research, which is fine for a quick check, but you will get much better information if you can find a local resource. In this instance I checked the Madison County interactive maps. Most of the time local resources are going to have more accurate maps and better address information. https://gis.bisclient.com/madisoncad/ Also, this is a good example of how state rate lookup are also a good reference, but are not perfect.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Logan shared the details below (Screenshots in the email above and the BC card thread ): the issue here is the address coordinates. This address is very close to the parish line. The coordinates in the Zamp rate admin are within Bossier Parish, while the address and the LA rate finder are correctly indicating this should be within Caddo Parish. 1. 8.35% is correct. 2. The issue is the coordinates for this address from our provider are incorrect. 3. Your best bet is to look up the address in the state rate finder. Whatever county is indicated, you will then insert the county/parish name followed by gis, interactive maps, or property search. Then, you can try and find the address. Occasionally, you may have to check the next county over if you are unable to find the address and you suspect it may be close to or over the county line. For this one, I was able to find it by searching "caddo parish gis", then choosing the link from arcgis.com. Kyle - do we have a fix for addresses that are pinning within an incorrect jurisdiction, causing the incorrect rate to be returned? I apologize for the slow turnaround, I have a pretty long backlog I have been trying to work through. TODO : once a fix is released, follow up with the customer.

Our Tax Research Team investigated this and found that the situation here was tricky within our tax geography data because this address's coordinates are very close to the parish boundary within LA. They also confirmed that the Louisiana Rate Lookup Tool was correct in placing this address within Caddo Parish instead of Bossier Parish. Our Tax Research and Engineering Teams are collaborating on an improvement to solve for this scenario, and we'll follow up once this has been released. Here's what the parish boundaries look like:

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rangilei, PoM, and Team, Another follow-up here! I am answering the questions throughout this thread, but please let me know if I'm missing any, and we can cover those in another email or during our call tomorrow morning (8/19/25, I'm in EST/EDT). 1) The Ship To address, line 1 field, and error: Could you please guide us on which specific " Ship To address " field in Keylight corresponds to this requirement? Yes—this shipping line 1 field would need to be set to null within Keylight, and this is likely something that would need to live within Keylight's Zamp integration logic, or code. We can talk about this more during our call tomorrow. One workaround for this, while testing or before any integration updates are made, is to enter "a" or some letter other than a space or leave the field empty. This corresponds with Line 1 of the Ship To address, but I'm unsure which exact field in Keylight that this corresponds to. Within Zamp, it will be this property: shipToAddress.line1 2) For the error "Invalid US zip: 8070 means that Zamp's system was unable to accept the zip code as it should have been 08070 (with a '0' in front)": If this transaction didn't sync due to a missing '0' in front of the Zip Code, why are other transactions with similar missing '0's appearing in Zamp? Could you please re-investigate the actual reason why this specific transaction did not sync? Just to let you know, this is the error we see within Zamp when the transaction creation attempt occurred. When this happens, this means that Zamp received "8070" as the zip code instead of "08070". Additional investigation or reasons this occurred would need to come from investigating the settings or invoice/transaction fields within Keylight, and the Keylight Team would be able to help here best (or whoever owns supporting situations like this within Keylight). 3) As for the extra transactions in Zamp (Zamp has More Transactions than Keylight), these seem to be related to four accounts that we don't recognize. Could you please help investigate it? Sure! I can share information about what we see within Zamp, as we (Zamp) do not have access to Keylight, and this is a relatively new system to us. We're happy to learn from you all and the Keylight Team, and add some documentation on our end to capture those learnings (internally). These four transactions have the following details in Zamp's logs: They were created between 1:34 and 1:41 PM GMT on July 22, 2025. The day they were created appears to be the day that the transactions were made within Pronto's Keylight environment (I'm referencing Zamp's record of the transactedAt here.) Below are the IDs (an invoice or transaction ID) that we have for these transactions, and I believe these IDs may be internal but searchable within Keylight: tjjr6uxg9j-rg-mu2807idyh ar0n-q6c_yf2380vss7_a5k7 aka0toe31qlbcum0fns8wh_h dgq4xjerx3_88i9o_kdcsksf I've attached the logs we have for these transactions in case it's helpful. If these were test or incorrect transactions in any way, please let us know, and we can delete these transactions from Pronto Marketing's Zamp account. Please let us know if you have any additional questions.

Based on our recent reconciliation of Keylight invoices against Zamp transactions for July 22-28 (after the API connection), we have a few follow-up questions and observations: Does Zamp pull data based on US Zip Codes? Do all US Zip Codes need to be exactly 5 digits for transactions to sync correctly? We've noticed several Keylight invoices that are not appearing in Zamp transactions. In most of these cases, the zip codes are either 4 digits or missing. However, there are also some invoices with 5-digit zip codes that are not showing up in Zamp. Could you please investigate these discrepancies further for us? We want to ensure all data is accurately captured. Thanks & Regards, PoM

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi PoM, You're welcome, and thanks for sharing such helpful details with us! Regarding New Jersey: I investigated this further and found that the two transactions noted below (as two of the IDs shared on 7/22/25 were the same but had different amounts) contained errors in our API logs related to address data. The API responses (including status codes and error messages) and logging data are in the attached XLSX file, and we'd recommend sharing this with the Keylight Team 7a58pdl93e0kr-4v6fx0rgk9 - the error String must contain at least 1 character(s) means that line 1 of the Ship To address needs to either have at least one character or value, or be null . In my API testing, I usually set line 1 to null if I just want to use a zip code when creating a transaction. k4xxy1an97j1614jr-tm7wi_ - The error Invalid US zip: 8070 means that Zamp's system was unable to accept the zip code as it should have been 08070 (with a '0' in front). To resolve situations like this, we recommend allowing leading zeros in zip codes or implementing Zamp's Address Validation API endpoint to help prevent such issues from occurring. Regarding the other discrepancies and findings: We've started investigating this, and we hope to have more details to share by next week. If we think the differences here may be related to the bug Kevin noted yesterday, please let us know. We're happy to investigate this now or work with you if you have questions after the bug and underlying data have been improved. Thank you for your patience and partnership as we work through these situations.

author: pom@prontomarketing.com
body: Dear Zamp Support & Christine, Thanks again for your ongoing support with our data. While we await your investigation into the missing New Jersey sales on 22 July 2025 (from our previous discussion), we've identified some additional data variances that require your expertise. We'd greatly appreciate your help in investigating these discrepancies and providing insights into the root causes, or guiding us on how we can work together to resolve them ASAP. Here are the details: CSV Data vs. Zamp Transactions (May 1, 2025 - July 11, 2025): Observation: Namtarn sent a CSV file on July 15, 2025, containing 1,899 US invoices (Invoices + Credit Notes) for this period. However, Zamp only shows 42 invoices for the same period. Request: Could you please help us understand the criteria or process for uploading transactions from CSV into Zamp? We need to clarify why there's such a significant difference in invoice count. API Integration Variances (July 22 & 23, 2025 - Post-API Activation): Observation: We've reconciled the API data for July 22nd and 23rd and found two types of variances: Missing from Zamp: 5 clients/invoices from Keylight are missing from Zamp transactions, totaling $735 ($229 on July 22nd, which aligns with Rangi's information, and $506 on July 23rd). (Please refer to: Excel file: KL vs Zamp (1-23 Jul 2025) > sheet API_Issue_22&23Jul2025 > rows 1-12 for details) Zamp has More Transactions than Keylight: Zamp shows transactions totaling $48,549.87 more than Keylight ($33,048.82 on July 22nd & $15,501.05 on July 23rd). (Please refer to: Excel ile: KL vs Zamp (1-23 Jul 2025) > sheet API_Issue_22&23Jul2025 > rows 15-54 for details) Request: Could you investigate these specific API discrepancies? We need to understand why certain Keylight transactions aren't appearing in Zamp, and why Zamp has additional transactions not reflected in Keylight. Missing from Zamp: Zamp has More Transactions than Keylight Our goal is to ensure complete data accuracy and a smooth integration process. Let's work together to pinpoint these issues and find the best solutions. Please let us know if you need any further information from our side. Thank you for your continued partnership. Regards, PoM

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rangilei, Thanks for letting us know about this! There is no setting that should prevent transactions for customers based in New Jersey from syncing with Zamp, while transactions from other states sync fine. This situation may be related to something on the Keylight side or something specific to these invoice transactions. That said, we'll review the logs and look for anything that might help us determine what is happening here. We should have an update for you by tomorrow (7/23).

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Hi Victor, Thank you for your patience on this matter. After reviewing your nexus numbers we can confirm that these are correct. The reason for the difference between Zamp's and Shopify totals, is that Shopify does not count returns or shipping towards your nexus status. Our tax team has done a thorough review of each state's rules and found that all states still count the original order towards nexus, even with a return. Please let me know if you have any further questions. Thanks

author: chris@zamp.com
body: We could share something like the below with Stoko: The difference here is caused by Shopify utilizing net sales (after refunds and discounts). At the same time, Zamp's Economic Nexus Analysis uses the total sales in a state (gross sales less discounts), and Zamp doesn't include refunds/returns in the threshold analysis. We also include shipping in our threshold analysis. After our recent tax research deep dive and thorough review of each state's economic nexus laws and thresholds, we found that refund transactions are not included in any state's economic nexus thresholds.
