author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Andrew, Thanks again for your patience! After thinking this through a bit and triple-checking the various items involved with economic nexus thresholds in visible's remaining states, we've confirmed that either path for reporting your B2B Transactions to Zamp should work here. I'll outline those details below. 1) Regarding the manual, CSV, route: As this is the preferred path, we're OK with taking this route if you prefer. The CSV file would need to meet the guidelines outlined in this article , and I've attached an example CSV template. One caveat here that will differ from the article is that the adjusted template accounts for visible selling of physical items and Software as a Service: We would need to know which row in the CSV file for a transaction (identified uniquely by the transactionId and there can be a single row per product type) should have the SaaS tax code assigned, which is R_DIG_SAAS_B2B for B2B (or R_DIG_SAAS for B2C). I added an extra column to the template for this, which has a header titled itemProductTaxCode . 2) Regarding manual invoices in Stripe, to be imported automatically: If a manual invoice is raised, we'd recommend including the devices and memberships as single line items while utilizing the quantity field (or similar) for the number of devices and memberships. Within Stripe, if a product is created for the B2B memberships, it appears that the Stripe Tax code txcd_10103001 would fit, and Zamp would automatically map this to Zamp's tax codes, as we currently do for your non-B2B transactions. This could impact the threshold reporting in various states because our Tax Research Team recently confirmed that the majority of states determine if the Gross Sales amount crosses an economic nexus threshold on a transaction. This means that discounts and refunds are not considered in Zamp's economic nexus analysis. Suppose the invoices are created on a per-user basis instead of a single transaction, in the states where we haven't seen visible cross a transaction count threshold which includes Arkansas, Connecticut, Utah, Vermont, and West Virginia. (These states also have a dollar amount threshold.) The other remaining states do not have a transaction count threshold and only have a dollar threshold instead. I hope this is helpful, and please let us know if you have any questions!

author: andrew@makevisible.com
body: Hey Zamp, just reaching out with a quick question around sales tax tracking for a specific B2B transaction. Currently, all of our sales are direct-to-consumer via Stripe (which, of course, integrates seamlessly with you). For a particular B2B deal, we'll be selling 150 devices and memberships in bulk to a Californian university, who will then distribute them to staff and students. We're currently at 60% of the $500k CA threshold, and this transaction would take us up to 80%, so no issues around tax collection, we're more looking for guidance on how best to handle the threshold tracking in this case. A couple of options we were considering: Manually import the transaction into Zamp via CSV, alongside our regular Stripe-collected transactions. Preferred. We can raise an invoice outside of Stripe. Raise a manual invoice in Stripe and have Zamp handle tax collection as you do with our usual B2C sales. Slightly cautious with this, as reporting may be impacted (and also individual tax thresholds - see below) due to the way our Stripe is currently set up. In addition, we plan to activate the memberships via 100% discount in Stripe for each of the 150 users, but unsure if this may create tax threshold implications on a per-user basis - could you comment on this? Be good to get your input. Thanks in advance! Andrew Long Financial Controller

author: jason@shopravella.com
body:
Hi Chris and Ashley,

NEW ISSUE IDENTIFIED -- please hold off on approvals/processing.

New issue:
When we do an EDIT ORDER (eg a size change from XS to S), we know already that we need to manually minus out the 'duplicate' item - since only 1 item was shipped.
However, it seems if the shipped item ends up getting returned for refund anyway, Zamp is NOT recording the tax adjustment for that returned item.

Example order: Only 1 item ordered -- price $195. Only 1 item paid. Size changed from XS to S/4 (via Edit Order). See 3 line items in Zamp calculation below: Because of the edit order, Zamp currently thinks 2 items were sold, for a total of $390 with $34.14 in tax. There seems to be a manual deduction (I think by Chris) that deducts the 1 duplicate item, resulting in -$16.27 in tax. However, after the item actually shipped (S/4 size in this example), and the customer decides to return for refund, we should get a negative tax adjustment of lets say $16.27 or $17-- but that's missing now. Chris -- please have a look at this example, and we can discuss today before 5:30pm EST if you have time.

We are out of the office on Thursday and Friday, so would need to review today.

And then once we find the logic issue here, let's pls go back and search for and adjust for all similar cases (Edit Order + Refund afterwards).

Thanks,
Jason

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bobbi and Jason, Following up quickly here with a few updates! First, we're happy to share that our engineering team has released some significant improvements since mid-June that now properly account for these transaction scenarios with Shopify transactions: Voided/Expired transactions - we now create a separate refund transaction to account for these. I validated this by reviewing voided orders within a Shopify export and comparing them to Zamp. Partial refunds that are not order edits are captured, and I validated this by reviewing 'partially_refunded' orders within a Shopify export and comparing them against Zamp. The above means that I made adjustments to Shopify Transactions within Zamp by reviewing 'partially_paid' and 'paid' transactions from a 'web' source with a positive outstanding balance. Please note that the process we previously agreed upon remains unchanged, except for the updates mentioned above regarding voided/expired/partial refund adjustments. We also have additional work scheduled to start in August 2025 to reattempt finding a solution for order edits within Shopify. Meaning—there's a chance these adjustments won't be necessary in the future, but we don't yet have an exact timeline. I've also adjusted for the remaining prior period refunds in California and Colorado. I've attached three files: A file showing the Shopify adjustment transaction work. An export of the Zamp Transactions for states with filings this month. This includes a Pivot table showing tax amounts by state. The tax-due estimate I sent previously is also included in this file. The prior period refunds brought into June 2025 for the previous periods. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Scott, Thanks for your patience here! Although I don't currently have a transaction-by-transaction tax rate file to share, I've identified the cause of the difference in tax due expectations here. Regarding Pennsylvania: We found that for PA, just the state rate (6%) was collected on some of the transactions, which did not include any locals (there are two in PA), and this ties into some details that Matt Grattan shared on 7/10/25 around ensuring not to overcharge customers when rates change throughout the state, and over time. Once we recalculated the PA Transactions to match Zamp's expectations, the tax-due estimate was updated to a number closer to your expectation. The estimated tax-due amount is now: $4,291.38 . This includes a timely filing discount of $43.35. Regarding Texas: Texas is a bit of a tricky situation, which we share more details about here , with Business-to-Business Software as a Service (B2B SaaS) because our understanding and Zamp's calculation engine considers the below information, which differs from a flat 8.25% rate across the board: Texas considers SaaS a data processing service, which subjects it to an 80% sales tax on the service's price. This also means that 20% of the price of a SaaS service in Texas is considered tax-exempt. The above leads to the following amounts and breakdown, which align with the tax-due estimate for TX: A taxable sales amount of $7,810 - these are sales to non-exempt entities. The original non-exempt total sales amount (excluding non-profit sales) was $9,762.78 , which the taxable amount noted above represents as 80% of. A tax-due estimate of $644.33 , less a timely filing discount of $3.22 , for a total estimated tax due of $641.11 . The above means that the $ 641.11 tax-due amount is our estimate of the correct amount, considering the taxability of SaaS in Texas. A question and next steps: Do we have your approval to move forward with filings for both Texas and Pennsylvania? These two states have due dates of the 20th this month, and we want to ensure timely filing. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Anjali, I hope that you are doing well! I'm jumping in for Chris to help assist with your questions: The Q2 payments (for example, New York) is a prepayment that is required by the state that will be applied to your quarterly return due in September. California also requires prepayments which were made in May and June that will be applied to the California Q2 return that is filed this month. Due dates vary by state. For example, Maine is the earliest due date (the 15th) while California has a later due date (the last day of the month). Most states have a due date of the 20th. We remit on your behalf to each individual state so you will see a separate remittance for each state. It's hard to say exactly when the funds will be pulled from your account as our team is actively filing as the reports are released but we will file and remit prior to the applicable state due date for a timely filing. I hope this helps to clarify and please let me know if you have any further questions, Ashley

body: Hi Danielle, Thanks for your patience with this! Our engineering team confirmed that Zamp doesn't currently support sales tax holidays. At this time, we're unable to find a good workaround because BigCommerce allows custom products and shipping rules. Still, the limitations on shipping usually come from third-party apps (which won't prevent the display of the product to non-Florida customers). Something like this may be possible with custom development and access to technical resources. If that's possible, the gift card product tax code (R_TPP_GIFT-CARD) would be treated as exempt in Florida and all US states. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chris, Thanks for sharing this! I didn't know that shipping was taxable in Texas. Is labor? No worries! The taxability of shipping varies from state to state, and in all kinds of scenarios; we're here to help with that. Labor may or may not be taxable depending on the kind of service involved. What types of services would you be referring to? We have a few that might fit this kind of category, but this may also be something to run by our Tax Research team for confirmation. These are the categories we currently support: The " TPP " below refers to " Tangible Personal Property ", which is generally taxable products. Regarding the PDF you shared and CCF_000129: I reviewed this further and also triple-checked some items within your Zamp account for your Texas sales tax registration. I found that when Zamp registered Accelerated Tooling LLC in Texas, we registered you with a 'Single Local Tax Rate' license type in that state. This is similar to other simplified sales tax rate licenses and programs in different states, and it's typically used by out-of-state businesses. The Single Local Tax Rate for Texas with this type of sales tax registration is 8% on all transactions, regardless of the shipping address. For this order and considering shipping taxable, $3.36 would be 8% of $42.00 . This means that a single sales tax rate is collected on orders shipping to customers within Texas, and here are some resources about this: Under ' How to Collect Sales Tax on Interstate Texas Sales ' in our Texas Sales Tax Guide, here . On the TX Comptroller's page here . I hope this helps, and please let us know if we can assist with anything!

Yes—you should be able to trust the software, and we're here to help answer questions and ensure any items are resolved.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Todd, Thanks for checking in and for your continued patience. Usually, importing the data would take a day or two, but we've had some unexpected delays. We're putting multiple items in place to prevent this, in the future (including hiring some new folks). We currently have your eBay Transactions importing into the MN Pawn America Zamp account. We've started working through the website sales, but I have one question (below). Aside from the Gunbroker sales, we should have all the data imported into Zamp by tomorrow (October 21, 2025). Once we have resolved the question (below) about Gunbroker sales and our engineering team adds Gunbroker as a supported Marketplace, we'll be able to import those transactions. Regarding Gunbroker: Question —Do you or your team know what GunBroker's EIN/FEIN or Tax ID number is? This may be included on any legal/tax forms or documentation that is not publicly available. One route to request this (if you're unsure of the ID) is to contact their support at support@gunbroker.com or submit a ticket/question from their Help Center page here . Zamp will need the GunBroker Tax ID number to ensure proper and compliant sales tax filing in a few states that require us to include a Marketplace's Tax ID number when filing sales tax returns, one of which is Oklahoma. Without this information, we would be unable to import the Gunbroker sales. Regarding your API question: Also, how can we test the sales reporting API? You or your team can test the sales reporting API, our /transactions API endpoint, by following the documentation here and using the API keys linked below. Please note that these API keys can only be viewed once. We recommend saving the API keys in a safe location before closing the browser/tab. [Sandbox] Pawn America Minnesota API Key [Sandbox] Pawn America Wisconsin API Key In our experience, this type of testing is typically performed once an integration is built, using a script or an API tool such as Postman (or a similar tool). Our /transactions API endpoint here is used for creating transactions in Zamp for reporting and filing purposes. We share our Transaction Object here . We also share important details regarding refund transactions here . Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

body: Thanks @amelia ! I called Jackie back. Notes: Jackie said that Asal is concerned about the amount, and they think we're doing this right, but the Shopify Report is making this tricky. There is confusion about how returns are handled because Shopify separates orders, returns, shipping, tax, and other amounts. For example: Jackie seems to understand what I'm saying, but it sounds like Asal is either confused or looking at some different report/export. I think maybe they thought we were deleting the duplicate Loop transactions, but we're just creating refunds ("Returns") to offset that duplicated amount. I let Jackie know that we do this because our Shopify integration could resync the duplicate Loop transaction if a change is made to it (by Loop, Shopify, a customer, someone at Cult Gaia, etc) so we take this path to make sure the amounts match the Shopify Reports; tax is not duplicated. Jackie said she'd check with Asal's assistant and see if we can all get on a call to ensure we're on the same page. Again. Closing this until Jackie or Asal replies.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jackie, Thank you for the responses and for providing additional context. Yes—Zamp accounted for the Loop Returns with duplicated tax for all states. This is something we check each month before sending the tax-due estimate and adjust for in all states, regardless of whether a filing is due. Additionally, our engineering team has a roadmap item scheduled to start next month that will add a feature to support accounting for this specific scenario. This means that ideally, these adjustments will happen automatically in the future. didnt we talked abt this last time? and you can even see what loop has duplicate charge. I am confused why you would dig in when i am assured that this was happening? Yes—we confirmed in previous calls and emails that Zamp is accounting for the duplicate tax charges on the Loop returns, and this is something our team accounts for each month. When returns were noted, I didn't initially realize that this was related to Loop returns (as there can be other return types within a Shopify store.) I'll ask more questions next time. I think it would be better to provide a monthly report that would clearly show the calculation. Sure, I'll note this on our end and we'll do our best to provide something showing the returns (refund transactions in Zamp) as we move forward. Just so you know, these returns (refund transactions) can be found in the export shared on July 9, 2025, and the adjustments for these returns always include the text ' loop-discount-adj ' in their IDs. Here's how to find these transactions within the export/report we share: 1) Add a filter in Excel (or whichever software is used) to the transactionTax column (L) to display only transactions with a negative amount to see all refund transactions associated with returns: 2) To see the transactions we created to adjust for the duplicate tax that occurs with Loop returns or exchanges. Add a filter in Excel to the transactionId column (A) for the text "loop-discount-adj.": The adjustments we make should always have " loop-discount-adj " in the transactionId for quick identification. For now, I've attached two spreadsheets: Containing all returns. Containing Loop-related duplicate tax adjustments, which offset the duplicate tax from Loop. Please let us know if you have any questions. We're still happy to schedule a call (or call at a time that works best for you today) to discuss this further.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Call with Sandy regarding Georgia April 2025 filing and differences: We talked through the possible causes of differences, which are: Sandy/team records (revenue recognition) based on the date an order is fulfilled. Zamp records amounts/tax/etc based on the payment date - following accrual accounting practices. Zamp also files in each state by adjusting for the state's specific timezone. In the GA Report, the top-level taxable sales appear to be state-only. While the rest of the sales are broken out across the varying local jurisdictions. We also confirmed that the product and associated tax code David Protein uses is treated generally as exempt in GA (but taxable at local maybe, at least according to Shopify.) The bar/energy/protein PTC they're mapped to from Shopify —> Zamp is actually a "snack food" PTC in the new food & bev guide. According to the taxability chart for GA, this is a state-level exemption, and locals aren't necessarily exempt. They were comfortable with the differences, and nuances of each system + handling of it overall.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sandy, You're welcome! After a thorough review of the situation and verification of a few key items, it appears that the majority of the discrepancies in tax collected are related to the items noted in this article . Primarily, we're seeing a $44.77 difference between Zamp and Shopify for the tax collected amount. A small (percentage-wise) difference like this is usually caused by rounding or a timezone difference, but timezones don't appear to be involved in the root cause here, as David Protein is based in New York. The other cause of a difference here would be that Zamp will list the tax collected as $0 for any Marketplace transaction, which includes Shopify SHOP transactions, Amazon transactions, and other marketplaces listed here . Also, Zamp's Transaction exports are what we call a "line item export," which means that the transaction-level details (starting with 'transaction') for Shipping and Handling, subtotal, discount, tax, and total are repeated across rows with the same transaction ID if there are multiple line items within the order. This can inflate any summing of those columns with a formula or pivot table, and here's an example of this: A way that I've adjusted for this in the past is to use the formula below with conditional formatting while selecting only the values within the 'transactionId' column: =COUNTIF($A$2:$A2, A2) > 1 I've attached a Zamp April 2025 export for Georgia, which shows this with the formula, conditional formatting, and filtering (by color) applied to the first sheet. The data I would sum, review, etc., is on the second sheet. I'm also happy to discuss this during a call. Another potential cause of these differences is related to manual (or programmatic, through a third-party Shopify app) changes or edits made to Shopify orders after they have been processed. For example, we've seen the SplitOrder Shopify app (recently, with a different client) create duplicate transactions and increase tax when it "splits" transactions into multiple orders and the tax is kept on the "new" orders. The difference in gross sales (or the sum of transaction subtotal or line item amount) can occur due to specific logic that ensures only the tax collected is remitted to the various states when filing sales tax returns. To ensure we're on the same page, was the concern primarily a difference in the tax collected, the gross sales (or net sales when accounting for refunds), or both? Overall, there are numerous moving pieces to this, and we should schedule a call to discuss further.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, Thanks again for being so patient here! A team member, Lucas, and I dove into the data over the last couple of days to ensure no piece of the puzzle was overlooked. We found that, in addition to the partial refunds missing from June 2025, the orders from the BigCommerce DormCo store were also missing. This happened because the checkbox shown below was not enabled for the DormCo store. We enabled this setting today (8/8/25), and we plan to import the missing transactions if you agree with this approach. Based on my research of internal notes and previous email conversations, I have the following understanding of the migration from Volusion to BigCommerce. Still, please let me know if any of this is incorrect. The Volusion data was provided via CSV and imported into Zamp through March 2025. The DormCo BigCommerce store data should have been synced with Zamp from April 1st, 2025, and forward. I've attached a few files showing our findings, and here are a few notes about these files: The first file, starting with 'DormCo - Missing Store', contains all of the transactions from the DormCo store from 4/1/25-8/8/25 that we could not find in Zamp. This comparison was made by using an export from BigCommerce and comparing it against an export from Zamp. We've also added a pivot table showing the tax amount by state. The second file, 'Master - Analysis - DormCo', shows a few different areas within each sheet: A set of "offset" transactions intended to be imported into Zamp to account for the difference between the incorrect full refund created by the BigCommerce integration, when the refund was a partial refund. A set of partial refunds that were missing within Zamp. A set of partial refunds without tax, as far as we know. A consolidated sheet containing all transactions. Pivot tables showing the amounts for GA, OH, PA, and CA. Note: The amounts are close for GA, OH, and PA, within reason for timezone differences to be the cause. I'm still reviewing items with CA because there appears to be a larger difference between Zamp's June 2025 tax-due estimate ($1,936), the missing transactions, and the remaining difference between Taylor's estimated amount for Q2 2025. I know this is a lot of information, and this is your busy season. We're aiming to resolve this and ensure accuracy. We've also put some items in place to prevent this from happening again in the future. We also have improvements coming to our BigCommerce integration that should save time for all involved. We're more than happy to sort this out over email or by scheduling a call, whichever is the easiest for you. A few questions: 1) Do you agree with the findings so far, and do we have your approval to proceed with importing the missing transactions along with the partial refund adjustments? We would import these missing transactions into the July 2025 filing period (with 7/15/25 dates) to ensure the tax is accounted for and remitted to the states. We also have an option to spread that tax out across future filing periods, if that is preferred. 2) Are there any pieces of the various situations that we might be missing? Once we have this data imported, we'll send out DormCo's tax-due estimate for the July 2025 filings. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: DormCo topics with Lucas: We confirmed that BigCommerce transactions from the DormCo store, DormCo, were missing from Zamp because of the issue noted on 8/4, here . @lucas - is diving into the analysis for the above. Next steps: Compare a DormCo store export from BigCommerce to the transactions in Zamp to ensure we don't import transactions that already exist, which would create duplicates. Sum the tax amounts for the missing transactions by state after the step noted above. Sum the tax difference between the partial and full refunds from BigCommerce, utilizing the file(s) Taylor shared. We'll get their approval before importing transactions and, overall, resolving the situation. After the above, we'll need to adjust for the refund issue (partial refunds currently treated as full refunds) in future months, until Blayzer/Indisea fix the issue.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bryan, Thanks again for continuing to be patient here. We investigated this further and found that the cause of these tax differences wasn't due to sales tax under-collection within QuickBooks Online or another system. The differences are that the amount listed on your Zamp account's Filing History page is a combined amount of the Tax Due, Penalty, and Interest due. Penalties and interest apply in situations where overdue or past-due filings are processed; the state itself assesses these penalties and interest. Here are the amounts for each overdue period that have been filed and the amounts confirmed, so far: Colorado October 2024: Tax Due: $1,120.18 Penalty Due: $596.56 Interest Due: $13.83 Amount Paid: $1,730.57 Colorado November 2024: Tax Due: $1,437.87 Penalty Due: $619.20 Interest Due: $14.98 Amount Paid: $2,072.05 Colorado December 2024: Tax Due: $2,034.80 Penalty Due: $446.63 Interest Due: $6.54 Amount Paid: $2,487.97 Nevada Q4 2024 and Q1 2025: $0. This can also be seen by downloading and reviewing the return and payment upload files available on your Filing History page here , after clicking on the specific filing row. Although there are still slight differences here (less than 5% of the total tax due), these kinds of differences are typically due to items such as Zamp utilizing multiple time zones (PST, MST, CST, EST, etc) vs Shopify (or QuickBooks Online) using a single time zone based on that system's timezone configuration (Shopify utilizes the primary address associated with a store, I believe), rounding, and other items noted in this article . We've confirmed that your Zamp account is configured correctly, that potentially difference-causing third-party apps are not currently in use within your Shopify store, and that the data looks normal from what we can tell within Zamp. I hope this helps, and please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Gavin, You're welcome, and thanks again for your patience! Here are the steps to set up the Zamp Shopify integration, and we're also happy to hop on a call to work through this with you: First, grant Zamp Collaborator access within Shopify: Could you please share your Shopify store's Collaborator Access Code with me? This will be under Settings —> Users in your Shopify Admin. After we have this, we'll send across a collaborator request to obtain the following view or read-only permissions: Orders Export orders Products Customers Reports Manage and install apps and channels Locations View Apps developed by staff and collaborators Develop apps Enable app development Manage tax settings Second, you, your team, or I can work through these steps to finish the connection: Steps: Log in to your Shopify admin. Click on Apps (Left sidebar at the bottom) The apps screen will pop up. Scroll to the very bottom and click on “ app and sales channel settings ” Select “develop apps” in the upper right corner Click “Create an app” App Name = Zamp Choose justin@zamp.com for the app developer Click “create app” Click “Configure admin API Scopes” Choose these 6 options Read Analytics Read Customers Read Inventory Read Locations Read Orders Read Products Click “save” Click the "Install app" button at the top right (may need to refresh the page) Share the details below with us using a One-Time Secret Link , another secure link, or during a call: Shopify URL - for example, this-shopify-store.myshopify.com Access Credentials - In the Shopify store, click the button to reveal it once, select the small icon to copy the value to the clipboard, and save it. Access the Secret Key (located at the bottom, under the 'Secret' API key) and save the value. Please share the details from step 11 with us securely, as noted above, and we will then add the Shopify integration within your Zamp account. Just so you know, the permissions mentioned above are specifically tailored to our integrations, enabling us to access the necessary data. We only need the customer's shipping address information; we don’t import their name, phone number, or email. We only import shipping so that we can calculate sales tax for filings.  The same read-only situation applies to orders, products, locations, and any other permission we're requesting. Zamp can’t change anything in their Shopify store since it’s “read-only” Please let us know if you have any questions! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

body: Findings so far: With the PA orders I've reviewed and the logs are tied to those, there is the error noted above (here) showing duplicate line item ids in the request to Zamp, and those need to be unique. A log file from their store is attached, showing this as well. The examples I've confirmed fit this pattern are highlighted in blue. This likely also applies to the TX and MN orders, as I see a bunch of the same line-item-related 'bad request' errors in the attached file.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Ébano, Maier, and Matt, Thanks for the responses and for sharing these details. I see what you're saying regarding the line item IDs, and it is also helpful to know that the Zamp application hasn't been customized. It sounds like there shouldn't be other customizations in place outside of Zamp that could affect this process. Regarding Access to the Affordable Screen Co Dev site: I believe that our Integration Team had access at one point, and I'm escalating this situation to them for further review. If I found out that they need access again or they'd prefer I have access, I will follow up here to share the necessary details for that access. A few outstanding questions for Ébano or Maier: 1) Could you please share any of the Zamp-related logs associated with the Order IDs and dates below? Logs for the date range of 8/13/2025-8/21/2025 should work here. The Order IDs in question are 000040361 (Texas) and 200105956 (Minnesota) The above details will help us confirm that the missing tax collection for those orders is the same as the Pennsylvania orders, or if it differs. I've narrowed down Zamp's logs to 65 different API calls for TX and MN addresses. 2) This may be a question for Matt—could you also please share the Ship To zip codes for the 000040361 (Texas) and 200105956 (Minnesota) orders? 3) What is the current version of the Zamp Extension that is installed?

author: maier@bemeir.com
body:
Look at
https://github.com/zamptax/zamptax-adobe-commerce-extension/blob/main/Model/TransactionObject.php lines 379 and line 395 vs line 364, clearly one of those 2 conditions is what's being triggered vs the first condition.

This means :

if ($item instanceof InvoiceItem || $item instanceof RefundItem) {

Is returning false and going to the else conditions which use "product id"

the Line Item ID used in the API requests to Zamp should be coming from an order_item_idand product_id on the order within Adobe Commerce. The code for this lives in the /zamptax-adobe-commerce-extension/Model/TransactionObject.php file.

author: matt@affordablescreenco.com
body: Hi Ebano, would you be able to answer the question from Chris below?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Matt, Thanks for sharing this! We'll have some order-by-order or zip-code-specific details to share tomorrow morning and will look into this Minnesota order. For the Pennsylvania order from 7/3/25 (zip code 17111), we found that the Storm Window store order had duplicate lineItemId values and our API returned this error: {"code":"BAD_REQUEST","issues":[{"code":"custom","message":"must be unique within transaction","path":["lineItems",1,"externalId"]}],"message":"Input validation failed"} This was the request sent to Zamp, and it doesn't seem this is typical or by design with our integration: From reviewing Zamp's Adobe Commerce Extension code, the Line Item ID used in the API requests to Zamp should be coming from an order_item_id and product_id on the order within Adobe Commerce. The code for this lives in the /zamptax-adobe-commerce-extension/Model/TransactionObject.php file. I'm noting this because I saw several errors related to non-unique (or duplicate) line item IDs in the Adobe Commerce logs that Ébano shared. Is there any customization or other item that might interfere with this on the Storm Window side?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Grace, Thanks for your patience with this! We looked into this further, and we've confirmed that we see the following California prepayment amounts within your CA CDTFA account: Prepayment 1 - $13,517.14 Prepayment 2 - $16,714.24 The tax-due estimate sent earlier this month did not account for those prepayment amounts; however, our filing team will take these into account when filing the return. The above means that the amount Zamp would estimate to be filed would be closer to $21,395.62 after subtracting those prepayments. Please note that, since New York follows a fiscal quarter (e.g., Q2 is June 2025 through August 2025), Zamp's tax-due estimate for NY would be considered the first prepayment associated with the NY Q2 2025 sales tax filing. A few questions: 1) Considering the above, do we have your approval to proceed with ETERNE's filings this month? 2) Regarding NY—if you'd like us to confirm the prepayment and filing amounts for this state, could you please reset or update your NY password and share it with us? We were unable to log in due to an expired password here. The password could be shared securely using this one-time secret tool.

Please note there were no partial refunds for "Texas" in Q1 2025. Additionally, please remember that sales made through a marketplace by a marketplace seller are included in item one (Total Texas Sales) on your sales tax return, but excluded from item two (Taxable Sales) if the marketplace provider has certified it will collect and remit tax on your behalf. Therefore, please ensure the total Texas sales amount is corrected on the Q1 amended sales tax remittance. https://comptroller.texas.gov/taxes/sales/remote-sellers-marketplace-faq.php Kindly forward this information for approval prior to submitting. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, You're welcome; thank you for the follow-up. Please could you also confirm receipt of the request to switch the Shopify Zamp connection back to the live Zamp account this Friday ? Yes—we will switch the Shopify Zamp connection back the production Zamp account and I've set a reminder on my end to ensure this is completed tomorrow morning (7/11/25.) Please can you confirm orders look correct in Zamp? Yes—the orders look correct within Zamp. After further investigation and comparison, I found that the order count difference was due to: Shopify does not create separate refund Transactions (it's noted within the order), but Zamp does create separate refund and order transactions. This happens because Zamp utilizes a ledger-based accounting approach, which creates a clear line of separation between orders and refunds. Some orders were not synced to the Zamp Sandbox account because they had order dates before the initial sync range (in April 2025); the initial sync was 5/1/25 and forward. After resyncing transactions, the order count totals match, when accounting for separate refunds. And also confirm the UK time window you'll be switching the Shopify connection to your live instance? Sure! What UK time window would be best for you all here? I usually start my day around 9 AM EST (1 PM UK time), but we can also target  a later time up to 11 PM EST (4 AM UK time) if that's better. Otherwise we can check with the broader team to see if anyone has a different availability. Please let us know if you have any questions.

body: Hi Briana, Thanks for sharing these details! I looked into this further, and you're right, the amounts are close. Most of the differences appear to be related to the following items: Timely filing discounts in each state. Our tax-due estimates automatically account for these. For CO, this discount is $93.96 For SC, this discount is $11.72. Rounding NC appears to fall into this category, and possibly time zones as well. Time zone differences between Stripe and Zamp: Zamp would file using EST in NC and SC. We'll file using MST in CO. We see these kinds of differences commonly with Shopify, but similar logic would apply to Stripe, depending on the time zone used in Stripe's reports/views. So that you know, these differences are expected and compliant. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Kwandwo, You're welcome; thanks so much for your understanding here! Overall, we've found that there appears to be no uncollected revenue (or orders) synced with Zamp. A teammate, Lucas, and I worked through a comparison of the Declined/Expired Authorize.net transactions Google Sheet and an export of the transactions within your Zamp account. The tricky piece of this situation is that the Order IDs are not the same between Authorize and Shopify or Zamp. To work through the comparison here, the strategy was to compare based on the customer email, transaction total, and shipping zip code. Overall, we were able to find 5,881 of the rows (or "payment transactions") from the Authorize file in Shopify; this is ~47%. We also found that within the transactions we were able to match, 2,793 of those are duplicates, meaning multiple Authorize.net IDs linked to a single Shopify Order ID. During the comparison, we came to the following working theory: We found that many of the failed payment attempts (declined/expired) eventually had a successful payment, and we also noticed a couple of things: Authorize.net records each payment attempt, regardless of whether it's successful. Zamp and Shopify both record the successful payment, and Zamp only receives the successful transactions from Shopify. Shopify records the failed payment attempts in a Shopify order's notes, but each overall order that has a status of Some examples of what we shared above are listed below, and please note that these links should open directly to the order within Shopify: #124687 #123888 #130191 #121587 #121609 We've uploaded an Excel file in the Google Drive folder here showing the comparison we worked through, if you'd like to review it. We're also happy to schedule a call to discuss this. Please let us know if you have any questions. Have a great weekend!

author: ktuffour@sereneherbs.com

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: Hey @chris following up on the data comparison, I've completed an initial analysis using only June transactions. Here’s a summary of my findings regarding Authorize.net transactions: Data Matching Challenges: Due to differing IDs between Authorize.net and Shopify/Zamp, cross-referencing required combining email, transaction total, and shipping zip code. Match Rate: We found 5881 out of the customer’s 12567 shared transactions (approximately 47%) in Shopify. Duplicate Transactions: Within the matched set, 2793 transactions are duplicates – multiple Authorize.net IDs linked to a single Shopify order ID. Root Cause Hypothesis: Reviewing some random Shopify orders with these duplicates reveals failed payment attempts before successful completion. Authorize.net records each attempt, while Shopify/Zamp only records the success (if any). Zamp receives only the successful transactions recorded in Shopify. Examples: #124687 , #123888 , #130191 I also noticed that there is a flag in Shopify's order page indicating: Authorize.net is reviewing this order for fraud I’ve attached an Excel file detailing this analysis.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Mary Beth, A quick follow-up here; thanks again for your continued patience. 1) Inv#153 - 6/3/25 - $11,250.00 - was Voided = $00 - Ga Tech 2) Inv#160 - 6/12/25 - $59,150.00 - not listed - U of Florida 1) We ended up skipping the import of INV#153 because it was voided, which usually means that items and transactions were not shipped and finalized. The reason for this is that $0 transactions within Zamp can count towards economic nexus in some states. Zamp also does not include refund transactions in our economic nexus analysis because our Tax Research team's compliance-focused research found that no state includes refunds in their economic nexus thresholds; meaning, the thresholds are analyzed utilizing gross sales (including shipping, less any discounts). 2) We have manually imported Inv#160 for the U of Florida. Also>> 2ndQ QBO Invoice total is $585,179.86 Zamp's total is $573,541.86 Attached is the Invoice list for QBO, including the ShipTo info. Thanks for sharing this! Zamp's transactions now match the $585,179.86 invoice total for Q2 2025 when we account for these credit memos: CM-169 - -$11,800.00 CM-158 - -$364.87. If you'd prefer we do not include credit memos, we can delete these. Please just let us know. Here are the totals from the transactions page now: Sales Tax Owed to CA is $3411.25 for the 2ndQ . Please look at the following invoices: 1) Inv#114 UC Berkeley - $15,986.25 2) Inv#130 UC Berkeley - $16,537.50 Both of these invoices have sales tax on them. It doesn't show up when you run a report. This has to do with Avalara. If you open the invoice you will see it listed. We manually included these invoices last month, and we'll keep an eye out for any similar situations in the future. Here are these transactions: If you have any questions, please let us know! Have a great week!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, Thanks for reaching out! Could you please clarify the documentation you requested regarding returns in Shopify? We would only need documentation if a partial refund for a customer located in a nexus state (Texas) were processed in Shopify for June 2025 or Q2 2025 for either Metal Mark or Dandy Lion. Sure! We would just need a CSV file containing refund transactions that match the attached template and guidance in this article , for partial refund transactions. The minimum necessary details for us to import the data into Zamp are: An Order ID. The date the partial refund was processed. The subtotal amount. Any shipping amount refunded. Any tax refunded. The Ship To Zip code (the full address is best, but a zip code is the minimum) I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thanks again for your patience here! Our Tax Research team investigated this and confirmed that the 11.25% rate is the correct rate here, as Lancaster City recently increased its rate by 0.75%. We have updated the rate within the underlying data, and the rate will be updated in the near future. Once this rate update has been fully applied, we'll follow up to let you know.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: From the ask-the-builders thread linked above: The issue is a missed rate change. The city rate increased by 0.75% on April 1, 2025. We captured the code change but not the rate change. I've updated our FIRE table and the update will be visible next time we load the data (I'm not sure when that will be because we are doing updates in the next couple of weeks). 1) Is the 10.5% or 11.25% rate correct here? 11.25% is correct. 2) If the 10.5% rate is correct, is this related to something with out-of-state sellers, CA, and district or other taxes that might not apply? N/A 3) What might have caused this, and how can we fix it? This is just an oversight. We capture about 95%-97% of the updates but, inevitably, something slips through. The bigger/busier the maintenance cycle, the more likely that we'll miss something due to sheer volume. We try our best to avoid the misses.

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: ok perfect thanks for confirming!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Edley, Thanks for sharing this context! I understand, and this context is super helpful. I'll share some details below that I believe will help ensure we're on the same page. :) I want to make sure that whichever way we do it Zamp is calculating the correct tax amount that has been collected ans should be remitted. Agreed! I want to confirm this as well. The good news here is that Zamp's Shopify integration has logic in place that can look for either handling of US sales taxes: Tax exclusive - tax listed separately. Tax inclusive - tax included in the product price. As if the system assumes we are including it in the price in the USA, but we are now adding it to the price, then the system may be calculating the wrong numbers To my understanding and review, Zamp will be able to detect whether the Shopify transaction has tax included in the price, or if it's now added to the price (separately). Meaning—our system's calculations will differ, depending on whether Shopify tells us how the tax is included in the price or not. Our Shopify integration (system) will handle both situations and calculate correctly from there. As i understand it in both cases Shopify itemises the tax collected out into a line in the order so would assume the system should just be looking at this "tax total" line? Yes—we do look at the 'tax total' line, and we also look for a property the Shopify API provides us with called taxesIncluded , and our integration handles it from there (Based on if this is 'true' or 'false'). I hope this helps!

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: Hi Chris, Historical we have included VAT in all our pricing, including in the USA. This changed a few weeks ago (around the start of July) so now we add tax on top of the price, but just in the USA. I want to make sure that whichever way we do it Zamp is calculating the correct tax amount that has been collected ans should be remitted. As if the system assumes we are including it in the price in the USA, but we are now adding it to the price, then the system may be calculating the wrong numbers As i understand it in both cases Shopify itemises the tax collected out into a line in the order so would assume the system should just be looking at this "tax total" line? Thanks Edley

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Edley, Thanks for the response! Isn't this the wrong approach? Could you please share more about why this might be the wrong approach here? I just want to ensure we're on the same page, as I may have misunderstood when you noted the following. We recently updated our settings on the 26th June so that tax is now charged at checkout instead of included from the order total. When I review your Zamp account's transactions from April 1, 2025, to June 25, 2025, I see that Zamp is bucketing transactions with tax collected across various date ranges and states. My understanding is that the tax was included in the cost of items sold. I also see tax collected from June 26, 2025, to June 30, 2025. After reviewing the code related to our Shopify integration, I found that we support tax-inclusive pricing (included in the item's cost), which was introduced late last year. That said, it is correct that the best and most compliant approach is to list sales tax separately (also known as tax-exclusive pricing, where the tax is not included in the item's cost). This compliance piece focuses more on complying with sales tax regulations than on reporting and filing. We'll continue to hold Drool Arts filings this month as we discuss this further. However, please keep in mind that we need to have the various state filings moving along in the process by the end of the day tomorrow (7/16/25) to ensure timely filing.

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: Hi Chris, Isn't this the wrong approach? We've switched from including tax in US to adding tax at checkout

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Edley, Thanks so much for your continued patience here! We've looked into this and confirmed that Zamp is accounting for tax-inclusive pricing here. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Eddy, Thanks for letting us know! Yes—we'll investigate this and follow up as soon as we're able (likely early next week).

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: Hi there, We recently updated our settings on the 26th June so that tax is now charged at checkout instead of included from the order total. Could you check this feeds through properly to your reporting? Thanks Edley

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tammy, Thanks for the context here! We can fast-track the investigation here, considering the critical meeting on Monday, as we'd like to ensure we handle this in the way that best helps you. Regarding Pennsylvania: The tax-due estimate for Pennsylvania is $201.23, which includes a timely filing discount in PA. Here's the breakdown: We see a total tax collected of $203.32. There is a timely filing discount in PA of $2.03. The remainder of the difference ($0.06) appears related to rounding within the sales tax logic; these slight differences can happen due to the nature of sales tax. Regarding Michigan: Within Zamp, I found that $137.59 in tax was collected for customers located in Michigan.. The reason Zamp is noting that $1.40 is due is due to two reasons: There is a timely filing discount in MI of $2.80 (the full tax due Zamp calculated is $4.20 .) Within Zamp, our system is designed to view digital products (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS) as tax-exempt in Michigan, which means we'd expect $0 tax to be collected on those transactions. This means that we see $133.39 of the $137.59 tax collected as over-collection. We have the option here to ask our filing team to file the $137.59 amount instead of the $1.40 (less any timely filing discounts). Then, later this month, we could schedule a meeting or discuss via email to determine why more tax was collected than Zamp would expect. Would you like me to ask our filing team to file the $137.59, less any timely filing discounts, in MI? Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Katie, You're very welcome! I understand! It's tricky juggling the various states and the unique situations of a few, such as CA, WA, NY, MD, and others. :) To confirm and ensure we're on the same page—do we have your approval to proceed with these filings this month? It sounds like we're on the same page, and we just like to be extra cautious when there are questions around the various amounts!

author: kate@otteroo.com
body: Thank you for confirming regarding CA and WA - all as I expected there! I did not realize the MD fiscal year ended June 30; that explains it! Thank you! Katie Casini Movement is Happiness otteroo.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Kate, Thanks so much for your patience here! I've shared answers to your questions below. Please let us know if this helps! 1) The CA amount ($379.29) aligns with the taxes collected in June, but Q2 should be much higher? Yes—the amount Zamp estimates will be remitted to the state (paid/due) should align with the June 2025 tax collected amounts, and this is what we see occur with clients who California has assigned a quarterly Prepay filing frequency. This happens because our tax-due estimate already accounts for the prepayments made for Otteroo in CA: 1st Prepayment - $459.00 2nd Prepayment - $458.00 Total Prepayments - $917.00 2) Is WA is higher than what I see in shopify due to B&O tax? Yes—this should be due to the B&O tax in Washington, as that amount is $21.90 for Q2 2025. 3) Maryland in Shopify (for all of 2024) is about $130 higher than what I see on zamp Just so you know, part of this difference is likely due to a timely filing discount of $5.42; however, this only accounts for a portion of the discrepancy. Overall, this difference is likely due to the date range associated with the MD filing frequency assigned to Otteroo by the MD Department of Revenue, which is a Fiscal Annual filing frequency that covers the period from July 1, 2024, to June 30, 2025. When you have a moment, could you please confirm the following items with us to help with this investigation? The date range associated with the MD Transaction review in Shopify. A screenshot or copy of an export from Shopify for MD is being used to compare here. We'll also hold Otteroo's filings until we have approval to proceed, due to the questions here, as we want to ensure timely and accurate filing. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: amelia@zamp.com
body: Hi Katie, Thank you for reaching out. I have flagged this to our technical success team who will review your account and get back to you. Thank you,

body: A few quick questions: 1) The CA amount ($379.29) aligns with the taxes collected in June, but Q2 should be much higher? 2) Is WA is higher than what I see in shopify due to B&O tax? 3) Maryland in Shopify (for all of 2024) is about $130 higher than what I see on zamp Thank you! author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Marjorie, Another follow-up here! We've made the necessary updates to adjust by an amount close to what you noted and shared in the Shopify vs Zamp comparison file. The overall adjustment we made was -$2,700.53 because the majority of the Washington Q2 2025 difference was due to WA's Business & Occupation tax (B&O), which is a gross receipts tax, not collected from customers. We include this amount in our tax-due estimate. The B&O Tax amount for Q2 2025 was $518.80 , while the difference you noted was $690.03. This means that we adjusted WA by $171.23. We're sending an updated tax-due estimate along with an increased review window time, within the next few minutes. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Marjorie, Thanks for the follow-up and your continued patience. We should have an update about this today, or Monday (7/14) at the very latest. We're keeping an eye on the state filing due dates, and we'll help ensure filings are processed on time.

author: melendrezm@vetchy.com
body: Hi Zamp, Could I get an update on this, please? Thank you! Best regards, Marjorie Melendrez (209) 417 5047 The information contained in this message may be privileged and confidential and protected from disclosure. If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient, or an employee or agent responsible for delivering this message to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error, please notify us immediately by replying to the message and deleting it from your computer.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Marjorie, Thanks for the response! We can certainly understand your perspective, and we would like to partner with you to resolve this situation. A slight difference, such as 1.25% (even if the dollar amount seems high), is very likely related to time zone differences between Zamp and Shopify. Zamp's tax-due estimate and filings will use the US time zone that aligns with the state's capital, meaning we use EST, CST, MST, PST, Hawaiian Time, and Alaskan Time across the various states. We'll dive into this further and confirm if the difference is related to time zones. If that's the case, our recommendation would be against adjusting by this amount, as it would mean not remitting tax to the various states. If time zones aren't the cause, we'll find the root cause and work with you to adjust the data accordingly. We should have more details to share or questions by early next week. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - Normally, we'd try to push back on this. However, we can conduct a quick comparison using the Zampboni tools that Lucas built to confirm whether the issue is related to time zone differences or something similar. If that's the case, then we can provide a quick explanation. If it's not, and we can determine the root cause, we can adjust. I'll hold their filings here. https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/38934726/card_tables/cards/8813898594

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ken, Thanks for the response here! If I delete this transaction now, will it be adjusted correctly next month? Sure! If you delete the transaction now, we can manually import a refund version of this transaction to account for it. Ultimately, the transaction could be left as it is so that the original data used to file for Virginia remains intact. Then, when we manually create the refund for this transaction, we can note on the line item description that this is a refund because the transaction was canceled, never shipped, and refunded. Does the above work well for you here? The 4 day window provided (truly 3 with the holiday) is really tight. Is there any way to expand that? We appreciate your feedback and understand your perspective. We'll share this with the broader team and consider any possibilities. The tricky portion of these situations is that the state filing due dates (each state's deadlines) don't change to account for holidays, and Zamp's filing timeframe and approval windows are designed to ensure we file timely for all Zamp customers, while optimizing for efficiency across teams.

body: Hi Monica, Thanks again for being so patient here! I'm following up to note that we were able to account for the below invoices that were voided/refunded: SS15179 SS15730 That said, there is a larger population of voided invoices that we're unable to account for due to low or $0 tax collected in the state(s) associated with the transaction. The reason for this is that Zamp is unable to file negative amounts in any state or any state's local jurisdiction. We're currently developing a plan to move forward and track the remaining voided transactions in future filing periods. I'll also share a list with you so that we're all on the same page. We will also be following up about some duplicate transactions in our other email thread (with the subject "Re: Incorrect NY filing"). For now, we will be sending out the tax-due estimate to ensure timely filing, as Florida is due on the 20th, but has some complex rules regarding payment submission. However, Florida will be $0 for SnapStream this month.

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Great, with the system I've set up, which compares a new pull of Gamefound data with the previous month's data, it's easiest for me to just show the net change. So we'll only have to resort to reversal/rebill style when there's a change in the address. Luckily, none of those in July. So I'll just send the transactions with the net changes. Will upload the sheet soon.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sean, Thanks for following up and again, sharing great questions! I'm glad to hear that they don't involve address changes! For these, should I just send the net change in the transaction as a new transaction? Yes—sending the net change in the transaction as a new transaction is likely the cleanest and most accrual/ledger accounting focused way of handling them; it creates a clear line of separation. This could be the path used for positive or negative amount changes. Would "net difference" transactions like these two examples be good? Or is it better to me show a full reversal transaction, along with a full replacement transaction? I think "net difference" transactions like this, or showing the complete reversal transaction along with a full replacement transaction, will work well here. Ultimately, I'd recommend that you take whichever path is the easiest for you here, as I know working with this system's reporting has been tricky (to say the least). Either route should work well with Zamp and ensure Earthborne Games remains compliant. Especially since we both have a good understanding of the situation and it's documented on our end. I hope that helps. Have a great weekend!

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Chris, The question of previous transactions that had a modification after-the-fact came up in my June submission. I have a couple of these in my July submission as well. These ones are a little less complicated, since they don't involve an address change. For these, should I just send the net change in the transaction as a new transaction? For example, I have one transaction with a discount/partial refund, so I would send that amount as a "negative" transaction. For another, some additional tax was collected, since the tax charged was erroneously short last time. So I could just send a transaction with only tax collected, and zero sales revenue. Would "net difference" transactions like these two examples be good? Or is it better to me show a full reversal transaction, along with a full replacement transaction? Thanks, Sean

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Chris, Attached are the five Gamefound transactions for June which were previously reported in May, but now in June have new shipping and tax amounts, and a new street address. (There are no entirely new Gamefound transactions for June, but make sure you saw the new BackerKit transactions on the previous email which are new June transactions.) My thought is that we should therefore show 10 June transactions, 5 which are reversals/credits of the original May transactions, and 5 of which are the "rebilled" transactions. Do you need me to add the 5 reversals to this spreadsheet as well, or is the 5 transactions in their "new form" enough? Or alternatively, do you have any thoughts on a better way to handle these? Sean

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Chris, Just about done... So as I said, there are two pieces to this for June. First, the final wave from the old BackerKit for Minnesota sales. That's the easy part - attached in a spreadsheet. Second, the Gamefound. I expected that once I finished my transforms, which cross-reference the current state of the Gamefound data against what we have recognized as sales to date, I would show no new activity in June. I was right, except for five anomalous transactions that are showing me weird numbers. Investigating these, the best I can tell, these are orders that had to get redirected to an updated address at the last second, after we'd already given our warehouse the go-ahead to ship (and recognized the sale). The new address means the tax rate changed in Gamefound's system, and there's now additional sales tax on the orders from what there was when we previously reported them in May. But it also means we reported the sale in May to a state that is not the state where we got the product to in the end. And Gamefound's data doesn't make this clean for us - they don't give us a reverse sale in the original state and a new sale in the new state. They just make the edit and show us the final version. That's the problem with Gamefound reporting - anything new that happens to an order just changes the order, regardless of the date of the order, so it looks like the order has been that way since the beginning. There's no concept of a period closing or a change order to a transaction, just an unauditable edit. It doesn't even show you what the original ship-to state was - we have to cross-reference that in our data. The way these crowdfunding sites work means there's always going to be some weird error like this that creeps in and we won't report things like sales tax perfectly. Anyway, for these five transactions, on our end, I suppose the cleanest thing we can do is try to show a reverse sale at the original address and a new sale in the new address. I will get you the info on these five shortly...

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sean, Thanks for letting us know.

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Nick, I should have this June data for you within the next few days. There will be two spreadsheets, which, when ready, I will upload to the shared Google drive previously provided: The first will be BackerKit data for Minnesota . This will possibly be the final batch of BackerKit data ever, unless we end up returning to BackerKit one day. The second will potentially be a new batch of Gamefound data for all states . However, it's possible this one will turn out to be $0 for June once I complete all the transforms. Sean

author: jeff@ampedbikes.com
body: HI Nick, While I would love to offer a login for Zamp, at this point we're trying to limit our plan to the number of seats and its confirmed that QBO doesn't offer those fields anymore for reports (for what reason I don't know). I've attached a csv with a vlookup equation to pull in the billing address. Do you have any other recommendations on how to do this moving forward that may require less manual input, since it doesn't seem like even if you did have access that the invoice list export would allow you the address fields you need. Please let us know. Thanks!

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Hi Jeff, Thanks for the response and that is odd. Is it possible to create a custom report that can fulfill the required fields? An alternative option would be to grant Zamp access and we could create a custom report for you. If you would like to do that, you can add integrations@zamp.com as a user. Please let me know what you would like to do.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @nick - This one is strange! I checked a few customer QBO accounts (billboards, LumiQ, Forcible Entry), and those accounts still have options like the ones below with the addresses that we need: Shipping Address Ship To Billing Address Bill To We accomplish this through a custom report in QBO, typically based on the invoice list report that he mentioned. Additionally, it doesn't appear to be a QBO-wide change from a quick review, but rather an issue specific to their account. They may need to contact QuickBooks (Intuit) support by following the steps in this Intuit article . The report we usually use: The columns: This article shares some details about adding columns like this to a report, but as far as I can tell, it should be the same process they used: https://quickbooks.intuit.com/learn-support/en-us/help-article/customize-reports/create-custom-reports-quickbooks-online-advanced/L1LHo5Ti2_US_en_US Maybe we can ask him to add integrations@zamp.com as an accountant user in QBO? What do you think?

author: jeff@ampedbikes.com
body: Hi Nick, It looks like quickbooks online changed their accessible columns on the invoice list report where billing address and shipping address are no longer options to include. There is a column "Bill To" on the CSV that I've included that includes the shipping address with zip codes included. This is the only option that I've found on the invoice list report that enables us to include those details. Do you have any other recommendations on pulling from quickbooks?

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Hi Grace, After reviewing the transactions we had imported the B2B Quickbooks transactions up until May 9, 2025. To resolve this we can import the remaining May and June transactions with a July date for next month. Going forward we are going to disconnect the Quickbooks automation and import the data manually. This will ensure that Shopify orders are not duplicated in our system.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: We'll want to tell Grace: Zamp did report wholesale transactions up until May 9, 2025. That said, some transactions are missing after May 9, 2025, but not many. We'll include those in their July 2025 filings (meaning, import with a date between July 2 and July 30). We'll want to reassure her that we'll handle the QuickBooks Online data import manually each month, to ensure Shopify B2B orders are filtered out. We're unable to filter out B2B Shopify transactions, as that's a more complex integration. I disconnected QBO Alloy. That should be all we need to do and tell her, here.

We should be okay, but we want to verify. Review their QBO transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm3oqxyo500vz99dr0gvlj30y/transactions?connectionId=cm3yrp31p000203mle0yfhzm0&date=2025-01-01~2025-07-22 . There are 16 in total, but it's a high dollar amount. Compare against Shopify to see if any have the identical amounts, addresses (probably zip code), or any pattern that seems to stick out: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm3oqxyo500vz99dr0gvlj30y/transactions?connectionId=cm3yrp0oo000103ml04ecebdc&date=2025-01-01~2025-07-22 We could probably filter this further to look at states where they had QBO transactions (there are only 16 in there this year). If we can't find anything quickly, we'll likely want to ask them to add us as an accountant user in QBO, because our integration with QBO isn't currently designed to exclude invoices by Shopify order number in the PO number field, or to determine if they're from Shopify. Tamella Cassis Beth Willis Knockout Beauty: buyer@knockoutbeauty.com Thank you,

Grace Lee (Controller) - 562-477-9280
Julie Tran (Accounting Assistant) - 562-955-0530 PLEASE COPY OUR ACCOUNTING EMAIL: ACCOUNTING@YSEBEAUTY.COM FOR INVOICES.

author: amelia@zamp.com
body: Hi Grace, B2B orders or wholesale orders where no tax was collected will still be included on your returns. You can either use Shopify's dedicated wholesale features , or you can designate individual customers as tax-exempt. Here is more information on how to do so. Please let us know if you need more assistance on ensuring your wholesale orders are marked correctly when Zamp pulls them in. We can hop on a quick call with our technical support team to review if needed. Thank you,

author: glee@ysebeauty.com

Thank you, Grace Lee (Controller) - 562-477-9280 Julie Tran (Accounting Assistant) - 562-955-0530 PLEASE COPY OUR ACCOUNTING EMAIL: ACCOUNTING@YSEBEAUTY.COM FOR INVOICES.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thank you for your response and the additional details. 1) Great! I'm glad to hear this was resolved. The situation with the rates returned here was related to what happened with Colorado. Overall, Colorado, South Dakota, and Indiana were affected. 2) Noted regarding the usage of the Google address autocomplete here, as that would certainly explain the difference between the two addresses and zip codes. We highly recommend Smarty, and I'd forgotten that it was already implemented on your end (from our earlier call). 3) Perfect! At the time of my initial response, I was unaware of the underlying reason for the behavior we were seeing, and my initial guesses were incorrect. I also see the taxes object included in the API request with either the 46241-55 74 or 46241-55 34 zip codes. We should be all set here now. If anything else comes up or you have any questions, please let us know.

So, it's likely working now due to that. Eng is going to put some other items in place to test and check these situations better. I'll word that a bit differently with the customer.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thanks a ton for your patience here! Our Engineering Team investigated and resolved the situation with Colorado here last night. What happened here was an unexpected edge case (which had not occurred in the past) when our teams were loading updated tax rate data as a part of one of the quarterly tax data updates. Our teams are also working to implement additional testing and processes to prevent this from happening in the future. Now, we are seeing the full rate returned for an address after triple-checking via internal tools and our API. Here are some screenshots noting this: The tax rates noted above also match the Colorado Sales Tax Lookup Tool here : Please note that Zamp's tax rates will align with the CO's General Merchandise (Tangible Personal Property) rates, as listed in the Sales Tax Lookup Tool. The 'General Merchandise - Use Tax' rates are tied to consumer use tax rates (for individual consumers or businesses ), instead of sales tax. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions.

body: Hi Hanna, Thanks for checking in! Is there any update? Yes—I have imported these transactions into TheWayo's Zamp account, and they will be accounted for within the California CA Q3 2025 filing, which is scheduled to be processed in October 2025. This applies to the transactions in the attached files. I updated the dollar amounts for the shipping tax refunds associated with CO-3371-8210 and CO-6039-7377, which are shown here: Regarding the differences you noted for #CP-2200-3112 and #CP-5704-2905: These transactions were previously omitted from my final calculation because they lacked shipping charges; this was an oversight on my part. I've created tax-refund adjustment transactions for these two Order IDs. That said, I'm unsure of the exact cause of the difference because San Francisco, CA, has not had any tax rate changes since April 1, 2025, and there was no shipping included to be taxed. Please let us know if you have any questions. Have a great weekend! Best, Chris Ralph Technical Success Zamp

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna and Team, Thanks again for your patience! I looked into this further and found that the difference between your calculation and my estimate was more minor than we initially thought. The reason for this is that Transaction Exports from Zamp are what we like to call "line-item-level files," which means that the "parent" or "transaction-level" amounts, such as those noted below, are intentionally repeated across transactions with the same transactionId when there are multiple line items (identified uniquely by the lineItemId ). My initial estimate was $396.72, and the actual refund amount with your calculations is $396.95; a difference of $0.23. This difference is likely caused by line-item-level rounding being accounted for within your current API calculations, as that was not accounted for in my estimate. In a "line-item-level" file, the below amount values should be counted once per row in a Zamp Transaction Export: transactionTax transactionShippingHandling transactionSubtotal transactionDiscount transactionTotal To help illustrate this, I've highlighted the rows with repeated transactionId values here: Questions: 1) Do the above details make sense, or is there anything that I can clarify further? 2) If the answer to #1 is "yes", do we have your approval to proceed with creating the necessary refund transactions (within Zamp, via CSV) for the sales tax refunded here at the amount of $396.95?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Thanks for sharing this! Because of the process you used here, which was a good idea (and I should have used instead), your tax amounts calculated for shipping would be more accurate, as it utilized the Zamp API. The method I used was a bit rougher, as I was arriving at the tax rate by dividing the lineItemShippingHandling + transactionSubtotal by the amount of tax collected. Then, I multiplied the lineItemShippingHandling amount by this tax rate. I'll review in more detail and see if there's anything further to share. Ultimately, the amount you arrived at should be more accurate. I will have this update for you tomorrow (8/7.)

author: hanna@thewayo.com
body: Hi Chris, As mentioned earlier, we exported the transactions from Zamp and used the Calculation API to recalculate the sales tax. For the period from January 1, 2025, to June 5, 2025, the total discrepancy between the historical sales tax and our current calculation is $434.05, which differs from the $396.72 estimated refund amount you provided. I've attached the details-please help review and identify the reason for the difference. Best Regards, Hanna

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Thanks for checking in and again, for being very patient here. This took a bit longer than expected to investigate because our Tax Research and Engineering Teams backdate the fix for California Transactions. That said, I found a way to determine the tax amount charged on shipping, and the amounts we've chosen are in two columns in the attached Excel file: Column I - the Tax Rate , which was determined by summing the transactionSubtotal and lineItemShipping amounts, then dividing by the tax amount collected for the transaction. Column J - the Shipping Tax Refund Amount , this was determined by multiplying the lineItemShippingHandling amount by the Tax Rate (Column I). Please note that we focused on the date range of 1/1/2025 through 6/5/2025 because that matches the date range that you provided, and our teams released the improvement for shipping taxability on 6/5/25. Zamp's first CA filing for TheWayo was in April 2025 for the Q1 2025 filing period. The total amount we estimate to be refunded here is $396.72 . Do you agree with this assessment, and can we proceed with including refund transactions in TheWayo's subsequent California Q3 2025 filing due in October? Please let us know if you have any questions!

The tax rate associated with shipping. The tax amount associated with shipping. Sum the difference per transaction. Then, create an import that would offset the amounts they're refunding here.

We'll run an export and an analysis on our end, and confirm if they match; then, we can share any differences or findings. We hope to have an update for you about this by Thursday, July 31, 2025.
