I can provide a list, but I'm not entirely sure if it's fully accurate. The logic behind the list is: we exported transactions from Zamp and used the Calculation API to re-calculate the sales tax. If there was a discrepancy between the historical sales tax and the current calculation, we included those transaction IDs in the list. Best Regards Hanna

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Hanna, Thanks for the answer and for checking in! We're happy to help sort this out. The likely best path forward would be to create refund transactions within Zamp for the shipping portion of the tax, after the refunds have been processed. This is a bit tricky because Zamp's API and overall system don't allow for sales tax-only refunds. We would need to associate either a shipping amount or a subtotal (tied to a line item) amount as well. Could you please provide us with a list of transaction IDs that were refunded, along with the corresponding tax amount? Then, we can create these transactions via CSV within Zamp. If the above is not possible here, we can assist with reviewing all California transactions from April 1, 2025, to June 29, 2025, and determine if we can calculate only the shipping portion of the tax listed. We're also happy to schedule a call to discuss this further if that would be helpful.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Suzanne, Thanks for meeting with me earlier! Here are the steps to check the 'webhooks' area as a part of our investigation into why Stripe invoices are not syncing automatically to Zamp: Once logged into Stripe, navigate to Developers —> Webhooks or use this link to navigate there directly once logged in: https://dashboard.stripe.com/webhooks The webhooks related to Zamp's integration will start with https://inn.gs We would want to look for any "Events" or "Event deliveries" to find the potential cause. One item I noticed is that our Engineering Team's screenshots display Stripe's newer ' Workbench' view , whereas the Design Bundles Developer view is actually the Developer Dashboard . This can be changed under Developers —> Settings in Stripe here . I would like to know if switching to this view may resolve the situation.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Suzanne, Thanks for letting me know! Great! I've rescheduled the call to 1:30 PM GMT tomorrow. If you see this before the call—would it be possible to push the call to the same time as our call today, 2:00 PM GMT? I realized after sending the previous email, that the same time could be doable for an engineer on our end who'd like to join as he's in Mountain Standard Time and 2:00 PM GMT translates to 8 AM in that time zone. If not, it's OK, and I'll record the call and ensure we download some logs. :)

author: suzanne.clark@designbundles.net
body: 1.30 would be great!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Suzanne, Thank you for letting me know, and I hope everything turns out okay on your end. Sure! author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Suzanne, Thanks for your patience here! I've outlined some things below that I believe should better explain why the invoices/transactions don't appear to be duplicates to us, but please note we'd still like to investigate why the amounts appear higher than you'd expect for July 2025. If you're comfortable with this, it would involve scheduling a call or adding Zamp ( filing@zamp.com ) as a user within Stripe with a view-only role/permission, as that should allow us to review and export data to compare to Zamp. After exporting transactions from Design Bundles' Zamp account, here's a screenshot of the export using 3AKZLAUS-0001 as the example: I know the screenshot above may be hard to view, but the individual line items can be seen in the attached file by scrolling to the right in Excel or your preferred spreadsheet program. Here's how this ties into the transaction within Zamp: At the top-level, anything in the export file starting with 'transaction' will all be the same if the 'transactionID is the same, and we can tell that each row represents a line item on a Stripe Invoice by the different 'lineItemId's and other 'lineItemProductName's further to the right. I've also uploaded a quick video to a Google Drive folder here describing how Zamp's exports work and why we don't think there are duplicate transactions here. Questions for next steps: 1) Can you share screenshots or exports from Stripe where you're seeing a lower amount for July 2025 than in Zamp? Stripe shares how to export payment data here and how to export any Stripe Tax-specific reports here . The Stripe Tax export would be best if Stripe Tax is enabled for Design Bundles. 2) Would you prefer to hop on a call? I'm happy to help sort this out, either way. Another, unrelated question: When you have a moment, could you please share a screenshot of your Stripe Webhooks page here , after following the steps below? On this page, click on any items (" endpoints ") listed that start with " https://inn.gs " as these will be related to Zamp. Then, click on the 'Event deliveries' tab/section. Could you share a screenshot of what you see on this page, and it should be similar to the one below? Our Team will be curious to see which pieces of the process are happening successfully (green) or unsuccessfully (red). The version of the 'Webhooks' page that you see will likely be white/gray/blue, as the screenshot below is a newer version of Stripe Developer tools. Please let me know if you have any questions!

body: Right now, the transactions page matches what they see in their internal records. On the nexus page, the data is different and I explained this is by design (different date ranges, the 'met on' date is frozen, but other amounts might update, etc.) Becky shared the liability report last week and we talked through it in this call, I noted that it's a general amount from the 1st of the month forward, and includes Amazon amounts, which would be excluded when calculating tax and the actual amount due. A separate issue: They are seeing tax calculated on order-level (partial) refunds in BigCommerce, even though they don't have nexus in any states and do not have tax calculations enabled. They're processing these refunds through their payment processor, Stripe, but that refund doesn't sync back to BigCommerce. David would like me to let him know once a fix is released for this, as this is something that was on Blayzer's radar, and Indisea will likely be diving in to fix. Similar tax calc issues on refunds with no tax: Eddins: https://secure.helpscout.net/conversation/2983110551/150651#thread-9077233924 Relisation Par: https://secure.helpscout.net/conversation/2971052446/146645#thread-9185074251 I think the solution here is to actually disable the BigCommerce fallback (10%) rates. I forgot about that (see the Realisation Par ticket above.)

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David, Following up with an update as we head into the weekend. First, I'd like to note that we're happy to talk about this on a call, and one can be scheduled with Becky and me using this link . So that you know, Zamp's system for sales tax filings and economic nexus analysis will adjust for each state's time zone. This is how Zamp was designed from the beginning, as it was determined to be the most technically legal and accurate approach by our Tax Research Team. This means that for RI, we'll automatically adjust for the EST time zone based on the date and time included with a transaction. For WA or CA, we'd use PST. For IL or KS, we'd use CST. We'll also adjust for AK and HI time zones. We do have some feature improvements in discovery and planning that could allow options to utilize a single time zone for filing. However, I'm unsure if we know that it would affect economic nexus analysis just yet. While digging into the data and reviewing the code and database tables involved in Zamp's Economic Nexus logic, I found a few items that affect\ the sales data used here that are important: Zamp's Economic Nexus Analysis tool looks at a varying set of data ranges per state, depending on the state's rules and legal code. E.g., for Alabama, we'll look at all of 2023, 2024, or 2025 as a version of the calendar or the Current Year . For Connecticut, it becomes tricky as we look at a " rolling 12 months " that ends on a specific month-end date: We look at 12 months ending at 12/31/23-12/31/25 , currently. For Illinois, we look at a rolling 4 quarters ending in date ranges from 12/31/23-12/31/25. There are other variations of this. In addition to the above, our Economic Nexus Analysis tool will utilize the date range with the highest dollar amount or transaction count to ensure compliance, with conservative estimates. I've shared some examples below. Alabama: I've attached a file showing the transactions used in our analysis for AL. We're looking at all BigCommerce orders, excluding refunds, and excluding Amazon Transactions. The date range we're using is 1/1/2025-8/22/2025 (the 2025 current year) because it is the highest of 2023, 2024, and 2025. Regarding Rhode Island: I've attached a file of the Rhode Island transactions we're using to make this determination, and Zamp is utilizing the 2025 year data for this, noting that we see the threshold as being met on 6/28/25 (the count of transactions then was 201). Currently, the count of transactions is 287. This count should update tomorrow or within the next few days at the latest (it's currently at 255.) So that you know, RI excludes refund or "free" transactions but includes Marketplace Transactions (Amazon) in their thresholds. Regarding Washington: I've also attached a Washington file showing all of the transactions that Zamp is using to consider here, and Zamp is also utilizing the 2025 data. The threshold was met on 8/9/25 with 100,058.08 in sales (transaction ID INV-259461-shipping_253668-01 and older within the attached file). Currently, the dollar threshold would be at $108,384.08. In this scenario, Zamp is excluding refund transactions and "free" transactions. I hope this is helpful, and we're happy to look into additional states or talk on a call. Have a great weekend!

Both, our internal estimate as well as your data is below the threshold Luckily here the data more or less matches. author: david.krutky@gmail.com
body: Hello Chris, I just spoke to Becky, I think we need to resolve this before moving forward. I'll dig into this more too. I updated the shipping address. I'll keep this up to date as we'll be transitioning to a new warehouse soon. According to our Tax Research Team's recently updated deep-dive research into every state's rules for economic nexus thresholds, refund transactions are excluded from the economic nexus thresholds, and all states' thresholds are based upon the gross sales (which include shipping). We have around 5% of returns on average. I don't think that would make the difference. Many states also have varying exclusions tied to resale/wholesale transactions, marketplace transactions, tax-exempt physical items, specific services, or tax-exempt services. I don't believe a lot of these would apply to XSTANCE here, based on my understanding of the product(s). No we don't have any wholesale Zamp's Economic Nexus Analysis also displays the dollar threshold amount and transaction account for whichever date range was the largest. Meaning, for a period of ' Previous or current calendar year' , we would look at either 1/1/24-12/31/24 or 1/1/24-7/31/24. That's ok and I matched our records to that as well. When we do make any changes, should we exclude any transactions from any of the Channel Names or sources noted in the BigCommerce export? We have to keep all the channels. They're all for US orders. The same for the sources, all sources should be included. Best, David

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David, Thanks for letting us know about these differences. I was writing up a follow-up as your email came in, and below are the items I wanted to follow up about. I'll share my thoughts about investigating the differences here, below those items. First, please note that we've imported the July 2025 Transactions from your BigCommerce Store, and from now on (from today), the transactions will sync automatically. An important step: While reviewing your BigCommerce store further, I noticed a message below on the tax settings page, indicating that an address within your BigCommerce store would need to be added for Zamp to calculate taxes (once that is enabled after registering in your nexus states). This address can be added under Settings —> Shipping —> the Shipping Origin section here, and BigCommerce shares more details about this setting in this article . Regarding the economic nexus thresholds and differences when compared against internal records for revenue: These differences are interesting to hear, especially for Illinois and Minnesota. I will need to dig into those situations further starting tomorrow, and I hope to have an update by Monday. A few items to consider with Zamp's Nexus Analysis: According to our Tax Research Team's recently updated deep-dive research into every state's rules for economic nexus thresholds, refund transactions are excluded from the economic nexus thresholds, and all states' thresholds are based upon the gross sales (which include shipping ). The date range for evaluating economic nexus thresholds varies by state, and we share more details about that in this article . I'll dive into the date ranges associated with the states noted, and confirm what we're using here. Many states also have varying exclusions tied to resale/wholesale transactions, marketplace transactions, tax-exempt physical items, specific services, or tax-exempt services. I don't believe a lot of these would apply to XSTANCE here, based on my understanding of the product(s). Zamp's Economic Nexus Analysis also displays the dollar threshold amount and transaction account for whichever date range was the largest. Meaning, for a period of ' Previous or current calendar year' , we would look at either 1/1/24-12/31/24 or 1/1/24-7/31/24. We'll start our investigation and gather as much information as possible about the situation before making any changes. One question I thought of: When we do make any changes, should we exclude any transactions from any of the Channel Names or sources noted in the BigCommerce export? Here's what we see after filtering the data to US Transactions:

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Knowledgebase idea: Note in a BigCommerce article or create a new one (ideally, a non-public-facing customer article) that enabling fallback tax rates in BigCommerce may cause tax to be calculated on refunds even when tax was not calculated initially.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David, Thanks for the update! This is very interesting to hear! We'll note this on our end as something to keep in mind. Overall, we tend to recommend keeping the BigCommerce fallback tax rates enabled in case they're ever needed. It may be worth exploring other settings in that area or checking with BigCommerce support about options to ensure taxes aren't calculated when the fallback is enabled if tax wasn't collected/calculated for the original order. You're very welcome, and it wasn't a goose chase! We learned something new today! Have a fantastic week!

author: david@doubleq.com.au
body: Hi Team, Have disabled the BigCommerce fallback tax rate and can confirm I am no longer seeing this issue. Seems the setting takes some time to propagate through the BigCommerce system as when previously attempted the same fix this did not work, it took about an hour for it to reflect correctly. Thanks for your work on this one and apologies for the goose chase, hopefully the above helps if any customer experiences in future! Cheers, DW -- David Wells DoubleQ m/ +61408319807 w/ doubleq.com.au

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David, Thanks for your continued patience here! We don't yet have an update about this, but we hope to have one soon (ideally this week), and will note this as urgent. Overall, it appeared that the tax calculation requests here were occurring due to BigCommerce's fallback logic with the 10% rate, and that Zamp wasn't triggering that behavior. That said, we want to be sure.

Response to #2: We think Option #2 is more realistic: > >    - *Option 2:* Begin filing in *August* for *July transactions*, using >    the *API integration* > > Response to #3: Bailey has agreed to send them today.  I sent him a courtesy reminder a short while ago. Response to #4: You and I completed the access to our current 5 nexus state websites. Response to #5:  I appreciate Chris's feedback / clarification, which was very helpful.  I am populating the CSV with requested data, but it is taking much time.  It is not a simple download, as tax has been embedded in the price of the product, etc.  I completed a CSV with January 2024 data and have attached it to have you review and ensure I am on the right track to fill in the rest...Feb 2024 - May 2025.  A few blank cells indicate fields for which I did not have data. I look forward to hearing from you. Best regards, Kay Kay Dreaden Accounting Manager Iron Lion Entries, LLC (931) 494-4965

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aksel, You're welcome! Great! We've received the approval, and yes, we're all set for the month!

author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Thanks and we received the email + just approved it so we should be all set for the month. Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, You're welcome! The tax-due estimate went out yesterday afternoon, around 4:24 PM EST. {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Sounds good all around, thanks! Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, You're welcome! I did have a nice holiday weekend; thanks! I hope your weekend was a nice one as well! 1. I just uploaded the CSV for August transactions - could you confirm that this will be taken into account for this upcoming filing cycle? Great! We received the file, and I'm working to get that data into Zamp right now. We should have a tax-due estimate heading your way with the Zoey data included by the end of the day. 2. I happened to see the task in Scope after logging in (I have a reminder on my end to check) but did not receive an email notification about the new task in there, so just a heads up. I'm not sure if I was supposed to receive a notification. This is interesting to hear, and thanks for letting us know. An email notification about the task should have been sent. We'll look into this and follow up before the end of September to ensure the notification is sent for October. I will also have a separate email heading your way to introduce you to our contact at Scope <https://scope.cx/>, Yuri. {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, I hope you had a nice holiday weekend & thanks for the info below. I wanted to check in about a couple of things: 1. I just uploaded the CSV for August transactions - could you confirm that this will be taken into account for this upcoming filing cycle? 2. I happened to see the task in Scope after logging in (I have a reminder on my end to check) but did not receive an email notification about the new task in there, so just a heads up. I'm not sure if I was supposed to receive a notification. Thanks, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, You're welcome! Great; I'm glad we're all set here and we appreciate your collaboration and understanding throughout all of this. Out of curiosity, which project management tool have you decided to adopt? We're using a tool our Head of Customer Success found, called Scope <https://scope.cx/>, and it's been wonderful so far! Yes—we have Zamp branding implemented. Have a great week! Thanks Chris. I received the invitation so I think we're all set there and sounds good about ensuring the csv doesn't get missed going forward. Out of curiosity, which project management tool have you decided to adopt? I can't make out whose it is when logged in. Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, You're welcome! *1) *Good to know, and thanks for your patience with this. I realized that I missed a step in the invite process, and I sent the project management tool invitation (clients.zamp.com) out a few minutes ago. *2)* Yes, we'll include the CSV data in the filings for Illinois and Virginia. Before we had realized what had happened here, Georgia and Pennsylvania had already been filed. - I will bring the GA and PA transactions into August 2025 to ensure the tax is remitted to the states. - I'm also putting some additional checks and balances into the process to ensure this doesn't happen again. Please let me know if you have any questions, or if you do not receive the project management tool invitation. Thanks Chris. 1. I didn't receive an invitation, just a heads up. To confirm, did you send it to aksel@ficksmusic.com? (Nothing in my spam folder) 2. Thanks. Also to confirm this point, the csv info will be included in this most recent filing? Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, You're welcome! 1. I received the invitation to join the account, does this mean I now also have access to the project management tool at clients.zamp.com? No—this is a separate invite and I forgot to include that invite for you. I've sent this invite out to you as of a few minutes ago. 2. I saw the 8/5 "Review & approve filings" email come through, could you confirm that the CSV that was uploaded via the project management tool was taken into consideration and used as part of the latest filing/calculations? No—it looks like this CSV file wasn't included, and I'll sync with the folks who worked on this to ensure it's not missed in the future. I'll work on importing this data and confirm with you here once it's completed (likely tomorrow morning). Thanks for your help with this, Chris. Just a couple of follow-up questions: 1. I received the invitation to join the account, does this mean I now also have access to the project management tool at clients.zamp.com? 2. I saw the 8/5 "Review & approve filings" email come through, could you confirm that the CSV that was uploaded via the project management tool was taken into consideration and used as part of the latest filing/calculations? Thanks again, Aksel Hi David, You're welcome; glad we could help here! I understand and would likely take the same path if I were in a similar situation. I've updated items on our end to ensure Zamp-related emails will go to Aksel for filing or data-related items, and Zamp account-related items. I've also unsubscribed you from these emails on our end. That said, and if you do receive an email from Zamp after today, there should be a quick unsubscribe option at the bottom of our emails. Have a great evening! wrote: Hi Chris, No worries! We're both admins with transparency, so we're not concerned about that. Mainly, I'm trying to remove any noise that Aksel is handling from my inbox. So, if there's any easy unsubscribe that I can do (or you can do for me) that would be ideal. That way my user login stays active should I ever need to log in. So, basically option 2. And thank you for being so conscientious about this! Best regards, David Hi David and Aksel, Thanks again for being so patient! I just sent out the Zamp user invite to aksel@ficksmusic.com. Please note that Zamp doesn't have a concept of account admins currently, and everyone would have the same access. David—to confirm, would you like us to remove you from Zamp's emails, remove your Zamp user (which would remove all Zamp access), or both? - I'm just being cautious here and confirming, in case it wasn't clear that this would mean losing Zamp access. - We do have "unsubscribe" options in our emails, and I could separately remove you from our filing and csv/data-reminder focused emails. How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9214552996/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9214552996/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9214552996/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} wrote: Yes, please do! (and feel free to remove me at the same time if that's easy/possible) Best regards, David Hi Aksel and David, A quick follow-up! For Aksel to receive emails when new tasks are posted in the new project management portal, I would need to add aksel@ficksmusic.com as a user within the Fick's Music Zamp account. - This will provide access to Zamp and ensure Aksel is included in all communications (task emails and all Zamp emails). Is it OK if I proceed with doing this? How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9208225588/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9208225588/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9208225588/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Aksel, Thanks for asking about this! Yes—we should be able to do this. I've updated two of the email settings related to emails we may send here (our onboarding and filing email notification lists), and I'm triple-checking with the other teams to see if there's any other area that matters here. We may also need to add you as a user to Ficks Music's Zamp account. We'll follow up once we've confirmed. -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Chris, Is there any chance the name/contact info in the new project management tool you're using could be changed/updated from David (cc'ed) to me? This way I can receive email notifications when new tasks are posted. Thanks in advance. Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, You're welcome! How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9175185142/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9175185142/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9175185142/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, Got it, thanks for the heads up and update on this! Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, A quick follow-up here! We've imported the Zoey transactions from January 2025 through June 2025 into the July 2025 filing period, with dates of 7/15/25. This way, the tax will be included in future filings. I hope that you have an excellent rest of the week! How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9169205595/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9169205595/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9169205595/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Aksel, You're welcome! This sounds like a good plan to me! We appreciate all of you working through this with us! -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Chris, Sounds good all around, thanks. We'll continue with the monthly exports and look forward to truing up the numbers during the next filing period. Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Askel, You're welcome! Great! We'll bring these transactions forward into the July 2025 filing period(s) next week, and one of us will follow up once that has been completed. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. I hope this helps! How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question—Does that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Askel, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team jumping in! Thank you for the follow-up and for providing this data. *1)* OK, noted, and this makes sense to us. *2)* Normally, we would be able to include these additional orders in the tax calculations for the most recent reporting cycle, with filings due this month, July 2025. As of today (7/7/25), Ficks Music's sales tax filings, due this month, have been released. We didn't hear back before the deadline noted in the email, Thursday, 7/3/25, which was sent out on 7/1/25. - Meaning—the sales tax filings are already being processed and are in varying stages of submission to the various US states. We could handle this in a similar way to how we'd recommend handling the May 2025 transactions. *Question*—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 filing period *3)* For the May 2025 transactions, we can include them along with the June 2025 transactions in the reporting and filing period processed for July 2025 in August 2025. *4)* Yes, that works for us! We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*—Does that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially? Thanks, Aksel Hi Askel, You're welcome! Great! We'll bring these transactions forward into the July 2025 filing period(s) next week, and one of us will follow up once that has been completed. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. I hope this helps! -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question—Does that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. I received the invitation so I think we're all set there and sounds good about ensuring the csv doesn't get missed going forward. Out of curiosity, which project management tool have you decided to adopt? I can't make out whose it is when logged in. Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, You're welcome! *1) *Good to know, and thanks for your patience with this. I realized that I missed a step in the invite process, and I sent the project management tool invitation (clients.zamp.com) out a few minutes ago. *2)* Yes, we'll include the CSV data in the filings for Illinois and Virginia. Before we had realized what had happened here, Georgia and Pennsylvania had already been filed. - I will bring the GA and PA transactions into August 2025 to ensure the tax is remitted to the states. - I'm also putting some additional checks and balances into the process to ensure this doesn't happen again. Please let me know if you have any questions, or if you do not receive the project management tool invitation. Thanks Chris. 1. I didn't receive an invitation, just a heads up. To confirm, did you send it to aksel@ficksmusic.com? (Nothing in my spam folder) 2. Thanks. Also to confirm this point, the csv info will be included in this most recent filing? Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Aksel, You're welcome! 1. I received the invitation to join the account, does this mean I now also have access to the project management tool at clients.zamp.com? No—this is a separate invite and I forgot to include that invite for you. I've sent this invite out to you as of a few minutes ago. 2. I saw the 8/5 "Review & approve filings" email come through, could you confirm that the CSV that was uploaded via the project management tool was taken into consideration and used as part of the latest filing/calculations? No—it looks like this CSV file wasn't included, and I'll sync with the folks who worked on this to ensure it's not missed in the future. I'll work on importing this data and confirm with you here once it's completed (likely tomorrow morning). Thanks for your help with this, Chris. Just a couple of follow-up questions: 1. I received the invitation to join the account, does this mean I now also have access to the project management tool at clients.zamp.com? 2. I saw the 8/5 "Review & approve filings" email come through, could you confirm that the CSV that was uploaded via the project management tool was taken into consideration and used as part of the latest filing/calculations? Thanks again, Aksel

Thanks again, Aksel Hi David, You're welcome; glad we could help here! I understand and would likely take the same path if I were in a similar situation. I've updated items on our end to ensure Zamp-related emails will go to Aksel for filing or data-related items, and Zamp account-related items. I've also unsubscribed you from these emails on our end. That said, and if you do receive an email from Zamp after today, there should be a quick unsubscribe option at the bottom of our emails. Have a great evening! wrote: Hi Chris, No worries! We're both admins with transparency, so we're not concerned about that. Mainly, I'm trying to remove any noise that Aksel is handling from my inbox. So, if there's any easy unsubscribe that I can do (or you can do for me) that would be ideal. That way my user login stays active should I ever need to log in. So, basically option 2. And thank you for being so conscientious about this! Best regards, David Hi David and Aksel, Thanks again for being so patient! I just sent out the Zamp user invite to aksel@ficksmusic.com. Please note that Zamp doesn't have a concept of account admins currently, and everyone would have the same access. David—to confirm, would you like us to remove you from Zamp's emails, remove your Zamp user (which would remove all Zamp access), or both? - I'm just being cautious here and confirming, in case it wasn't clear that this would mean losing Zamp access. - We do have "unsubscribe" options in our emails, and I could separately remove you from our filing and csv/data-reminder focused emails. How would you rate my reply? We may also need to add you as a user to Ficks Music's Zamp account. We'll follow up once we've confirmed. -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Chris, Is there any chance the name/contact info in the new project management tool you're using could be changed/updated from David (cc'ed) to me? This sounds like a good plan to me! Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. I hope this helps! How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question—Does that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Askel, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team jumping in! Thank you for the follow-up and for providing this data. *1)* OK, noted, and this makes sense to us. *2)* Normally, we would be able to include these additional orders in the tax calculations for the most recent reporting cycle, with filings due this month, July 2025. As of today (7/7/25), Ficks Music's sales tax filings, due this month, have been released. We didn't hear back before the deadline noted in the email, Thursday, 7/3/25, which was sent out on 7/1/25. - Meaning—the sales tax filings are already being processed and are in varying stages of submission to the various US states. We could handle this in a similar way to how we'd recommend handling the May 2025 transactions. *Question*—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 filing period *3)* For the May 2025 transactions, we can include them along with the June 2025 transactions in the reporting and filing period processed for July 2025 in August 2025. *4)* Yes, that works for us! We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*—Does that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially? Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*—Does that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aksel, You're welcome! I did have a nice holiday weekend; thanks! I hope your weekend was a nice one as well! 1. I just uploaded the CSV for August transactions - could you confirm that this will be taken into account for this upcoming filing cycle? Great! We received the file, and I'm working to get that data into Zamp right now. We should have a tax-due estimate heading your way with the Zoey data included by the end of the day. 2. I happened to see the task in Scope after logging in (I have a reminder on my end to check) but did not receive an email notification about the new task in there, so just a heads up. I'm not sure if I was supposed to receive a notification. This is interesting to hear, and thanks for letting us know. An email notification about the task should have been sent. We'll look into this and follow up before the end of September to ensure the notification is sent for October. I will also have a separate email heading your way to introduce you to our contact at Scope , Yuri.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @carie - Of course, and this is a great idea! I'll take care of the intro here in a few minutes after I get back to Aksel.

author: carie@zamp.com
body: @chris - do you mind making a warm intro for Yuri <> Aksel? In speaking with Yuri today he was surprised to learn that many of our customers are interested in Scope, as he has not had any come to him and mention Zamp. I told Yuri we could start warm-intro'ing him.

author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Hi Chris, I hope you had a nice holiday weekend & thanks for the info below. I wanted to check in about a couple of things: 1. I just uploaded the CSV for August transactions - could you confirm that this will be taken into account for this upcoming filing cycle? 2. I happened to see the task in Scope after logging in (I have a reminder on my end to check) but did not receive an email notification about the new task in there, so just a heads up. I'm not sure if I was supposed to receive a notification. Thanks, Aksel Güngör

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aksel, You're welcome! Great; I'm glad we're all set here and we appreciate your collaboration and understanding throughout all of this. Out of curiosity, which project management tool have you decided to adopt? We're using a tool our Head of Customer Success found, called Scope , and it's been wonderful so far! Yes—we have Zamp branding implemented. Have a great week!

author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Thanks Chris. I received the invitation so I think we're all set there and sounds good about ensuring the csv doesn't get missed going forward. Out of curiosity, which project management tool have you decided to adopt? I can't make out whose it is when logged in. Thanks, Aksel

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aksel, You're welcome! 1) Good to know, and thanks for your patience with this. I realized that I missed a step in the invite process, and I sent the project management tool invitation (clients.zamp.com) out a few minutes ago. 2) Yes, we'll include the CSV data in the filings for Illinois and Virginia. Before we had realized what had happened here, Georgia and Pennsylvania had already been filed. I will bring the GA and PA transactions into August 2025 to ensure the tax is remitted to the states. I'm also putting some additional checks and balances into the process to ensure this doesn't happen again. Please let me know if you have any questions, or if you do not receive the project management tool invitation.

author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Thanks Chris. 1. I didn't receive an invitation, just a heads up. To confirm, did you send it to aksel@ficksmusic.com? (Nothing in my spam folder) 2. Thanks. Also to confirm this point, the csv info will be included in this most recent filing? Best, Aksel Güngör

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aksel, You're welcome! 1. I received the invitation to join the account, does this mean I now also have access to the project management tool at clients.zamp.com? No—this is a separate invite and I forgot to include that invite for you. I've sent this invite out to you as of a few minutes ago. 2. I saw the 8/5 "Review & approve filings" email come through, could you confirm that the CSV that was uploaded via the project management tool was taken into consideration and used as part of the latest filing/calculations? No—it looks like this CSV file wasn't included, and I'll sync with the folks who worked on this to ensure it's not missed in the future. I'll work on importing this data and confirm with you here once it's completed (likely tomorrow morning).

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David, You're welcome; glad we could help here! I understand and would likely take the same path if I were in a similar situation. I've updated items on our end to ensure Zamp-related emails will go to Aksel for filing or data-related items, and Zamp account-related items. I've also unsubscribed you from these emails on our end. That said, and if you do receive an email from Zamp after today, there should be a quick unsubscribe option at the bottom of our emails. Have a great evening!

body: Hi Chris, No worries! We're both admins with transparency, so we're not concerned about that. Mainly, I'm trying to remove any noise that Aksel is handling from my inbox. So, if there's any easy unsubscribe that I can do (or you can do for me) that would be ideal. That way my user login stays active should I ever need to log in. So, basically option 2. And thank you for being so conscientious about this! Best regards, David Hi David and Aksel, Thanks again for being so patient! I just sent out the Zamp user invite to aksel@ficksmusic.com. Please note that Zamp doesn't have a concept of account admins currently, and everyone would have the same access. David—to confirm, would you like us to remove you from Zamp's emails, remove your Zamp user (which would remove all Zamp access), or both? - I'm just being cautious here and confirming, in case it wasn't clear that this would mean losing Zamp access. - We do have "unsubscribe" options in our emails, and I could separately remove you from our filing and csv/data-reminder focused emails. Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question—Does that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Askel, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team jumping in! Thank you for the follow-up and for providing this data. *1)* OK, noted, and this makes sense to us. *2)* Normally, we would be able to include these additional orders in the tax calculations for the most recent reporting cycle, with filings due this month, July 2025. As of today (7/7/25), Ficks Music's sales tax filings, due this month, have been released. We didn't hear back before the deadline noted in the email, Thursday, 7/3/25, which was sent out on 7/1/25. - Meaning—the sales tax filings are already being processed and are in varying stages of submission to the various US states. We could handle this in a similar way to how we'd recommend handling the May 2025 transactions. *Question*—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 filing period *3)* For the May 2025 transactions, we can include them along with the June 2025 transactions in the reporting and filing period processed for July 2025 in August 2025. *4)* Yes, that works for us! We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*—Does that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially?
