Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. Thank you for the follow-up and for providing this data. *1)* OK, noted, and this makes sense to us. *2)* Normally, we would be able to include these additional orders in the tax calculations for the most recent reporting cycle, with filings due this month, July 2025. As of today (7/7/25), Ficks Music's sales tax filings, due this month, have been released. We didn't hear back before the deadline noted in the email, Thursday, 7/3/25, which was sent out on 7/1/25. - Meaning—the sales tax filings are already being processed and are in varying stages of submission to the various US states. We could handle this in a similar way to how we'd recommend handling the May 2025 transactions. *Question*—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 filing period *3)* For the May 2025 transactions, we can include them along with the June 2025 transactions in the reporting and filing period processed for July 2025 in August 2025. *4)* Yes, that works for us! We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*—Does that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially? Thanks, Aksel Hi Askel, You're welcome! Great! We'll bring these transactions forward into the July 2025 filing period(s) next week, and one of us will follow up once that has been completed. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi David and Aksel, Thanks again for being so patient! I just sent out the Zamp user invite to aksel@ficksmusic.com. Please note that Zamp doesn't have a concept of account admins currently, and everyone would have the same access. David—to confirm, would you like us to remove you from Zamp's emails, remove your Zamp user (which would remove all Zamp access), or both? I'm just being cautious here and confirming, in case it wasn't clear that this would mean losing Zamp access. We do have "unsubscribe" options in our emails, and I could separately remove you from our filing and csv/data-reminder focused emails.

author: david@ficksmusic.com
body: Yes, please do! (and feel free to remove me at the same time if that's easy/possible) Best regards, David Hi Aksel and David, A quick follow-up! For Aksel to receive emails when new tasks are posted in the new project management portal, I would need to add aksel@ficksmusic.com as a user within the Fick's Music Zamp account. - This will provide access to Zamp and ensure Aksel is included in all communications (task emails and all Zamp emails). Is it OK if I proceed with doing this? How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/1/&gt ; Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/2/&gt ; Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/3/&gt ; -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question—Does that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Best, Aksel Güngör Hi Askel, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team jumping in! Thank you for the follow-up and for providing this data. *1)* OK, noted, and this makes sense to us. *2)* Normally, we would be able to include these additional orders in the tax calculations for the most recent reporting cycle, with filings due this month, July 2025. As of today (7/7/25), Ficks Music's sales tax filings, due this month, have been released. We didn't hear back before the deadline noted in the email, Thursday, 7/3/25, which was sent out on 7/1/25. - Meaning—the sales tax filings are already being processed and are in varying stages of submission to the various US states. We could handle this in a similar way to how we'd recommend handling the May 2025 transactions. *Question*—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 filing period *3)* For the May 2025 transactions, we can include them along with the June 2025 transactions in the reporting and filing period processed for July 2025 in August 2025. *4)* Yes, that works for us! We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*—Does that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] < https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform&gt ; Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially? Thanks, Aksel Hi Askel, You're welcome! Great! We'll bring these transactions forward into the July 2025 filing period(s) next week, and one of us will follow up once that has been completed. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes—the monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. I hope this helps! -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform> Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question—Are you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question—Does that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Best, Aksel Güngör

body: Hi Rod, Thanks for checking in, and your continued patience! body: Hi there, Thanks for sharing this question! This is happening because of a large refund in Illinois, which was processed on May 14, 2025, but was associated with a transaction from April 26, 2025 (Order ID #1933). This refund includes a total of $201.77 in tax that was refunded, and the Illinois jurisdiction associated with it reported $0 in sales for May 2025. The specific jurisdiction involved is CHICAGO CITY (COOK COUNTY). The reason this happens is that Illinois does not permit negative tax balances on its filings for local jurisdictions, such as Chicago. When this happens, Zamp reduces the filing for that jurisdiction to $0 (or, in this case, leaves it at $0). Would you like us to track this transaction and roll it forward in a future filing period if there are future sales to Chicago, IL, that will allow this refund to be accounted for?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, Thanks for letting us know about this! That being said, rather than adjusting that prior liability to zero now, will it work to leave that as a liability debit on the books for now, and offset our June report for Minnesota with a $395.28 credit? In this situation, we should be able to account for it in the June 2025 filing period for Minnesota as long as there is enough tax collected to cover the $395.28 amount. The reason for that is that the various states do not allow negative local jurisdiction balances on their filings. After briefly reviewing the MN Q2 2025 data, we may be able to account for this credit, depending on the amount of sales bucketed into Ramsey County, MN, once it's time to file that return. Currently, the sales volume in this county is $2,763, with a tax of $14. Otherwise, the transaction would need to be moved forward until it can be accounted for. I can investigate this further by Tuesday and will follow up with the results or any additional findings. What is the best way to approach these adjustments? What do you need from me to report voided invoices? I believe we'd want a credit memo created in QuickBooks Online, referencing the invoice that was voided by it, for this purpose. If we want to track it there, we can create one. Alternatively, we can adjust within Zamp once we've validated that there is enough sales tax in the associated local jurisdiction.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Persha and Jen, Thanks for your patience here! As discussed during our call on Friday, we confirmed that the timezone issue didn't affect the 2022-2024 historical data that was imported in February 2025; it was also recalculated for overdue filings in April 2025. We also reviewed the following months for Connecticut and found the causes noted below. The June 2025 CT tax-due estimate was higher due to a timezone issue. There were 23 CT Transactions with $11.53 in tax collected that were moved into June, in addition to the June 2025 transactions. The June file had $163.26 in tax collection. The combined total was $174.80 , which becomes $175.00 when applying Connecticut's rounding rules for their filings. The May 2025 tax-due estimate and tax remitted were lower due to the timezone issue. This amount was $156.75 in tax collected, which becomes $164.00 when applying CT's rounding rules for their filings. The April 2025 does appear to have been affected by the timezone issue. We're currently working on the January through April 2025 data to determine if and which transactions were also affected by this timezone issue. Once we've confirmed this, we'll update the data, share the results, and ensure that any transactions in states where Q2 2025 filings were already processed are moved forward, as we did with the May 2025 transactions. I've attached two files: a June XLSX file with tax totals by state and another XLSX file showing the May 2025 transactions that were moved into June 2025. This will help us all ensure we're on the same page. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes: For June 2025 in CT, it was higher because 23 CT transactions moved forward with $11.53 in tax. This was from the " Sauce - Missing May 2025 Transactions Time zone conversion issue - 01MAY2025 moved to June 2025.csv " file. Transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm34x4f5o01qn14lgi27uxuk8/transactions?date=2025-06-01~2025-06-30&shipToState=CT June file had $163.26 in "transaction revenue" transactions with tax. For May 2025, the difference was due to transactions that had a timestamp/timezone, and we moved those forward into June - the difference is exactly $11.53 For April 2025, the transactions matched, but the report didn't update until after we refreshed it (something was "stuck" in the tax calc process.)

Jen estimated a bit over $300, while the file Nick shared showed $198 just in subscription revenue. We need to triple-check the amounts and see if a file just needs to be reimported. https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm34x4f5o01qn14lgi27uxuk8/customer-reports/liability?monthRange=2023-01~2023-01 https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm34x4f5o01qn14lgi27uxuk8/transactions?shipToState=CT&date=2023-01-01%7E2023-01-31&limit=50 We need to: See why the gross sales are low - likely the timezone issue that we ran into for May 2025. Perhaps transactions weren't included, although they were imported, and this is related to a broader issue we've observed. We'll likely need to compare the original source files to data within Zamp.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Another update here! We've successfully created the offset (refund) transactions to account for the tax that was already remitted to the state of New York for these two deleted orders. This means that the $7.75 tax refund will be included in your upcoming Q2 2025 NY filing to be filed in September 2025 (covering the date range of 6/1/25-8/31/25). Zamp files sales tax returns net of any returns or refunds, meaning those transactions "offset" or recover taxes that were either not charged to the customer or refunded to the customer. Here's what these transactions look like within Zamp: Please let us know if you have any questions. Have an excellent rest of your week!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, Thanks for your patience here! We looked into this further and confirmed that the majority of the Connecticut tax-due estimate difference was related to missing the in-person Shopify POS Transactions. I also believe we've found the cause of this, and I'll share more details below. The other variances appear to be due to rounding, timely filing discounts (where Zamp's estimate is lower), and potentially time zone differences. We've manually imported those transactions for this month, and here's an updated tax-due estimate: State code Period Estimated sales tax AR May 2025 $57.00 CT May 2025 $1,080.00 GA May 2025 $244.31 IL May 2025 $622.00 KY May 2025 $119.07 MD May 2025 $191.41 MA May 2025 $545.89 MI May 2025 $290.93 NE May 2025 $56.70 NC May 2025 $498.03 OH May 2025 $511.97 RI May 2025 $47.14 UT May 2025 $69.81 VT May 2025 $81.03 VA May 2025 $266.49 WV May 2025 $55.25 Combined Total: $4,737.03 Question —do we now have your approval to proceed with Select Seeds' filings this month? We aim to have these moving along by the end of today, but we can hold them a bit, until the end of the day on Monday (6/16/25). The goal here is to ensure timely filing by the states' due dates. The cause of this: This issue occurred because the Zamp Shopify integration's access to your Shopify store is missing the " read_location " permission, a newer requirement that Shopify recently introduced. Specifically, it allows us to view the POS locations and associate those addresses with the transactions in Zamp. This permission can be added by going to: Settings —> Apps and sales channels —> click "Develop Apps" (in the top right) —> Zamp —> Configuration within your Shopify Admin. Then, click the "Edit" button next to "Admin API integration." Search for "locations" and add " read_locations " by checking the box. Click the black "Save" button. This was an item we reviewed in all Zamp customers' Shopify stores, but it was missed because there weren't POS Location sales for us to import from Select Seeds until May 2025. I'm also happy to hop on a cal l to walk through the above. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, Thanks for sharing those details! This is interesting because we should pull in Shopify POS sales, but it could be related to Zamp's permissions within your Shopify store or some other configuration item. I'll dig into this further and let you know what we find!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Kay, Thanks for your patience here! We have calculated sales tax on the price and use tax on the cost of goods. I do not see where these values are broken down on the CSV, so I am unsure where / how to enter. In this situation, the sales tax would be placed in the transactionTax column within the CSV template. At this time, Zamp does not currently support importing transactions with business use tax on the cost of goods, as Zamp's product and services are geared towards sales and use tax collected from customers. If you're referring to sales and use tax (some states call "sales tax" a form of "use tax" for out-of-state businesses), then it would belong in the transactionTax column as well (combined with sales tax). I've connected with Caroline about the business use tax piece, and this is something that could be discussed further. However, if there was an installation charge or other charge, should this also be included in the total or broken out? Yes—if there is a charge for a service or product that is tax-exempt or potentially taxed differently in various states, we'd recommend breaking that out into a separate row (with the same transactionId) on the CSV template. Then, in the last column of the attached example template, place the applicable tax code in the lineItemProductTaxCode column (column Q in the attached CSV). Ultimately, the decision to break this out separately or not is up to you (or the Iron Lion Entries team). If the installation charges are not billed independently, they will be considered taxable along with the rest of the transaction. I am attempting to populate the CSV from our filed reports. Does the order of the columns in the CSV matter or must they stay in the represented positions with "transactionId" in the first column, etc.? Yes—the order of the columns within the CSV file needs to remain as it is because Zamp's system is designed to import the sales data with the file's columns in the exact order of our template. I hope this helps, and please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Moving to pending ahead of the call. After reviewing the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin code looking at zamp-tax/includes/admin/transaction-sync/class-zamp-transaction-sync-batch.php , it appears this could be related to multiple items: The following is similar to situations we worked through at TaxJar for WooCommerce. We may need to involve Arlene Cycle's more technical team for database access, depending on what we find during our call today. Issues After Plugin Reinstallation Several things might cause transactions not to sync to Zamp after reinstallation: Orphaned Action Scheduler Tasks : The plugin uses WooCommerce Action Scheduler to queue batch processing tasks After reinstallation, old scheduled actions might still exist in the database, but the code to handle them might have changed These tasks are stored in the WordPress database in the wp_actionscheduler_actions table Stale Transaction Status Metadata : The plugin stores transaction status as post meta ( zamp_transaction_status ) If an order was previously marked as "Success", it won't be reprocessed by default After reinstallation, this metadata remains but the actual sync state might be different Incomplete Cleanup of Previous Sync Data : Batch progress data is stored in WordPress options with prefixes: zamp_transactions_queue_ for batch queues zamp_sync_progress_ for progress tracking If reinstallation happens during an active sync, these might remain in an inconsistent state Sync Status Inconsistency : The global sync status is stored in the zamp_sync_status option If this is stuck in 'in_progress' after reinstallation, new syncs might be blocked Clearing Caches and Resetting Queues To resolve these issues after reinstallation, you should: Clear Action Scheduler Queue : The plugin has a built-in method: Zamp_Transaction_Sync_Batch::cleanup_scheduled_actions() This calls as_unschedule_all_actions('zamp_process_transactions_batch', array(), self::SCHEDULER_GROUP) You might need to manually trigger this if the reinstallation didn't properly clean up Clean Up Sync Data : Use Zamp_Transaction_Sync_Batch::cleanup_sync_data() to remove all sync progress and queue data This removes all options with prefixes zamp_sync_progress_ and zamp_transactions_queue_ Reset Sync Status : Set the sync status back to 'ready': Zamp_Transaction_Sync::set_sync_status('ready') This allows new syncs to be initiated Clear Transaction Status Metadata (if needed): If you want to force reprocessing of previously synced orders, you might need to clear the zamp_transaction_status post meta This would be a custom SQL query against the post meta table The most reliable approach would be to run a cleanup sequence that: Stops any in-progress syncs Clears all scheduled actions Removes all sync-related options Resets the sync status to 'ready' This would give you a clean slate to start syncing transactions again after reinstallation. —————————————————————————————————————————- 1. Zamp Plugin UI The Zamp plugin itself appears to provide some admin UI for transaction sync operations, but based on the code reviewed, there is no explicit UI button or menu for a full "reset" or "cleanup" of all sync data and scheduled actions. However: Stopping Sync: There is an AJAX action for stopping sync ( zamp_stop_transaction_sync ), which calls Zamp_Transaction_Sync_Batch::cleanup_scheduled_actions() and resets status. If the plugin’s admin UI provides a “Stop Sync” or “Cancel Sync” button, using it will clear scheduled actions and reset the sync status. Starting Sync: Starting a new sync ( zamp_start_transaction_sync ) also calls the cleanup method before creating new batches. So, starting a new sync from the UI should clear out old scheduled actions. No "Full Reset" Button: There is no evidence of a UI button to clear all progress, batch queues, or transaction meta in bulk. These are handled in the backend code. 2. WooCommerce Action Scheduler UI WooCommerce (and some plugins) provide an Action Scheduler admin screen at: WooCommerce > Status > Scheduled Actions Here, you can view, search, and manually run or delete scheduled actions, including those for Zamp (look for hooks like zamp_process_transactions_batch ). You can manually delete stuck or failed actions from this screen. 3. WordPress Options / Post Meta No UI for Options Table or Post Meta: WordPress does not provide a native UI to delete custom options (like zamp_sync_progress_* , zamp_transactions_queue_* ) or post meta ( zamp_transaction_status ). You would need a plugin like “WP-Optimize”, “Advanced DB Cleaner”, or direct database access for this. 4. Cache Plugins If you are using a caching plugin (e.g., WP Super Cache, W3 Total Cache), you can clear the site cache from their UI, but this does not affect Action Scheduler or Zamp sync data. Summary Table What you can do from UI How/Where Stop/cancel sync Zamp plugin admin (if button exists) Start new sync (clears queue) Zamp plugin admin View/delete scheduled actions WooCommerce > Status > Scheduled Actions Clear transaction/post meta Not available in default UI Clear plugin options Not available in default UI Clear site cache Cache plugin UI (not related to Zamp sync) If you need a full reset: Use the Zamp UI to stop any running sync. Use the WooCommerce Scheduled Actions UI to delete any stuck Zamp-related actions. For a true “factory reset” (clearing all progress, queues, and post meta), you would need to run code or SQL, or add a custom admin tool.

body: Hi Celina and Team, Thanks again for your patience here! After reviewing the logs and conducting some research, I don't immediately see the cause of this issue, and we should schedule a call using this link for early next week (if you or the team are available). There are a few items we can review within a WooCommerce order to see what happened and why it didn't sync to Zamp. A call would also be helpful to hunt for details in WooCommerce's 'Scheduled Actions' queue in case something isn't happening there as it should. This is under WooCommerce —> Status —> Scheduled Actions. A few questions: 1) When you have a moment, could you please share a screenshot of what the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin shows when attempting to run a historical transaction sync ? I'm curious to see this message and if there's any history, log, or report available to download: However, the Historical Transaction Sync shows "No sync activity report to load." 2) If you try rerunning the historical transaction sync, do you see any log files that might be named 'zamp-transactions' or something similar? The logs will be under WooCommerce → Status → Logs and start with 'Zamp.' I'm also working with a colleague who helped build our WooCommerce plugin to sort this out. I'll follow up if there's anything else we need to ask! Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Celina, I hope you're doing well! Thanks for your patience here! Our team recently updated the Zamp WooCommerce plugin, and we've provided the updated version. Here are the steps to install this version: Download the zip file containing the updated Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin from your Onboarding Dashboard here . Uninstall the current 'Zamp Tax' plugin by going to Plugins —> Search for 'Zamp Tax' —> Deactivate —> Delete —> Confirm Deletion . Follow steps 3-7 in our installation article here . Confirm that the initial configuration is in place (or set it up) as noted at the bottom of the article linked in step #3. We can share the Zamp API token again if it is needed. We also have additional helpful articles centered around configuring Zamp Tax for WooCommerce in our knowledge base here . Review the new Diagnostics page to ensure everything is configured to receive calculations by navigating to: WooCommerce > Settings > Zamp Tax > Diagnostics I've also removed all the existing WooCommerce Transactions from within the Arlene Cycle Support Zamp account, as they did not include the tax amount collected. We'll want to run another Historical Transaction Syn c once the new plugin version is installed. We're also happy to schedule a call to work through this if that would be helpful. Please let us know if you have any questions!

body: Hi Henry, Thanks for the follow-up! Okay so it seems correct? Yes—it looks correct to me! Oh also, could you help check shopify vs zamp for NY? Yep! For New York, Mod Lighting is assigned a quarterly filing frequency, and New York's quarters follow an unusual date range. Q1 2025 is from 3/1/25 to 5/31/25, and is due in June 2025. We share more info about that here , and the NY DOR shares details here . In the Shopify Report here , the total tax collected is $12,616.72 , and Zamp's tax-due estimate is slightly lower (due to time zones, most likely) at $12,606.10 . New York's tax-due estimate also looks correct to me.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Henry, Thanks for the response. I've looked at May's numbers and most look good, WA looks a bit high in zapped, could you help us check here? Sure! The difference in Zamp's tax-due estimate for Washington versus Shopify is caused by the Washington Business & Occupation (B&O) tax , which is a gross receipts tax that businesses pay to the state on gross sales to customers located within Washington. This is a tax that is not typically collected from customers but is required to be paid when filing WA sales tax returns. The Shopify United States Sales Tax Report shows $3,384.16 in tax collected. The breakdown of the B&O tax is: Retailing - Gross Amount: $38,972.09 - Tax Rate: 0.471% - Tax estimated due: $183.56 . Wholesaling - Gross Amount: $9,693.87 - Tax Rate: 0.484% - Tax Due: $46.92 . Combined B&O total : $230.48 The combined total of tax collected and the B&O tax matches Zamp's tax-due estimate ($ 3,609.77 ) within a few dollars (lower): $3,614.64 . Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: henry@mod-lighting.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Henry, I just wanted to follow up with you here, as noted in our other email thread. I've attached an XLSX file showing a comparison between Zamp's tax-due estimate and Shopify's United States Sales Tax Reports (links to those reports, below). The Shopify United States Sales Tax Report filtered to New York for the NY Q1 2025 period (3/1/25-5/31/25). The Shopify United States Sales Tax Report here is filtered to only the nexus states we're filing in this month, which are the monthly filing states. The difference here is minimal and is due to a mixture of timely filing discounts and time zones; we share more details in this article . Overall, the Zamp tax-due estimate is lower than Shopify's reporting. In Washington, the difference ( $230.48 ) is due to the state's Business & Occupation Tax , which is a Gross Receipts tax imposed when filing Washington sales tax returns. Please let us know if you have any questions. Have an excellent rest of your week, and I hope that the weekend ahead is relaxing!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: You're welcome, Allie! Would that be the case, then? No—Amelia and I were able to find a temporary solution for a tax code that will work for this scenario when utilizing the Zamp API. Amelia will be following up about that shortly! Regarding how to handle this in QuickBooks Online: To my understanding of QuickBooks Online's product and tax settings, it would be best to categorize the product or service item as a Nontaxable item for any of these 3% (or other percentage) fees associated with payment processing. As far as "non-taxable income" goes, I believe that would be a separate account (from sales tax) within QuickBooks Online after reading through this resource and this other resource. I'd still recommend that you confirm with QuickBooks Online support to be sure. Regarding using the "gift card" code: Yes—that code could be used here as well. Which would be: R_TPP_GIFT-CARD. The thought process on our end regarding the code Amelia will share is that it falls closer to a category that payment processing fees might be categorized under.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, You're welcome; thanks for your patience here! what's the best way to ensure this isn't included in the taxable total on Zamp's reports? The likely best path here would be to create a non-taxable item for credit card fees and then confirm via a test invoice that QuickBooks Online does not calculate tax for the item. If we make a non-taxable item for credit card fees, would it effect the total tax owed if other line items in the invoice are taxable? Or will it be avoided if Quickbooks isn't calculating sales tax on it? In this situation, the item's total amount won't be included in the taxable portion of the sales within Zamp, and it won't affect the tax owed, as Zamp files based on the tax collected. That said, the gross sales associated with the transaction would be slightly different in Zamp (grossed down), as we've discussed in the past. The upcoming and improved Zamp QuickBooks Online integration will help resolve scenarios like this, as we'll then receive taxability information from QuickBooks Online at the line item level (if the integration is used and configured). I hope this helps!

author: allie@handwrytten.com
body: Hi Chris, Thank you again for all your help and the update. I had another question for you about invoicing credit card fees. If we implement a 3% upcharge for credit card processing, what's the best way to ensure this isn't included in the taxable total on Zamp's reports? If we make a non-taxable item for credit card fees, would it effect the total tax owed if other line items in the invoice are taxable? Or will it be avoided if Quickbooks isn't calculating sales tax on it? I just want to make sure we're on the same page for June. Thank you! Allie

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Stephanie, Thanks for your patience here! I've connected with Taryn regarding the sales tax calculation situation for Michigan and confirmed that, while Zamp isn't planning to file sales tax returns in Michigan for Accelerated Tooling, the calculations can be handled separately. This would likely simplify the situation and increase accuracy. First, Zamp can provide the tax rates and calculate local sales taxes in Michigan for WooCommerce. Sales tax should also be collected in Minnesota and Texas within WooCommerce. 1) A quick question—would you like us to add MI for calculations within Zamp? The Accelerated Tooling Team will still be able to file MI sales tax returns, as this is a separate process from these calculations. 2) If they aren't enabled already, could you please also enable Minnesota and Texas for calculations within WooCommerce? We share how to enable calculations here , and each nexus state (MI, MN, and TX) would need to be added to the nexus states section: Please let me know if you have any questions, and I'm also happy to schedule a call if that would be helpful.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Stephanie, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team reaching out to you on behalf of Accelerated Tooling. It's nice to e-meet you! I wanted to see if you could help us turn off the transaction sync to Zamp from the Accelerated Tooling LLC WooCommerce store. The reason for this is that Chris informed us that WooCommerce Transactions (orders and refunds) are entered into QuickBooks Desktop. Chris provides us with the QuickBooks Desktop data every month, and we aim to ensure that there are no duplicate transactions. We share how to turn off the transaction sync to Zamp in this article , and it involves unchecking this box: Navigate to WooCommerce —> Settings —> Zamp Tax —> Send Transactions . Questions: 1) Does the above make sense, and is there anything we can help you with here? 2) Are sales tax calculations enabled within WooCommerce? This should be the case as far as we know. We haven't seen any Texas or Minnesota transactions sync to Zamp, yet, so our visibility into this is limited. Please let us know if you have any questions! We're also happy to discuss this further during a call .

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes from the call: Todo: Bring transactions forward: Kyle is okay with that, and I will need to run that by Anita. Explained the situation, and Kyle understood. Escalate to eng. Other notes and details: They've conducted extensive testing for July 1st with Zamp and are using Zamp for the filings. They might switch to Zamp calculations. Using the TaxJar API is inexpensive, and we want to avoid the technical work. They discovered that Alaska doesn't return the FreightTaxable flags in TaxJar. In Alaska, some municipalities calculate tax on shipping, while others do not, depending on the locality. Do you know if Zamp has already gotten this right? If so, they might move over. It's not a huge cost savings, but it would be good to have better accuracy. A feature request: Is there a way to look up a tax rate without a total? Just an address. If the address validation includes fields such as tax rate, freight taxable, etc., this could be useful. He's happy to hop on with product and engineering folks to hear their reasoning and why, etc. This is tied to how their ERP works; it stores a tax jurisdiction with a rate for the ship-to location, and they can't tie it to an order.

body: Hi Chris, Thanks for sending this over! We'll be sure to reach out if we have questions or notice anything strange. Regarding WooCommerce: This is interesting to hear, and we'd love to help confirm this and explore any necessary solutions. Let's schedule a call to dive into this, but we'd likely want to have Stephanie involved in that call. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Mary Beth, A quick follow-up to close the loop here! We've adjusted for the voided invoices by deleting them, as Zamp's Nexus Analysis does not include refunds in its analysis. This is based on our Tax Research Team's recent research, which confirmed transaction types considered in economic nexus thresholds. Zamp typically doesn't have a concept of voided invoices except to create a refund transaction. This way, those won't count towards economic nexus thresholds. We'll follow up with you in the July 2nd email thread to confirm the necessary adjustments have been made for the filings due this month and separately send a tax-due estimate. We appreciate your patience throughout this process!

body: Hi Ken, Thanks for letting me know! I've made a note of this and understand about time zones and dates via the API to Zamp. Regarding Order ID 229610: This makes sense! Yes, we're now seeing this transaction updated within Zamp: The updated tax-due estimate for Florida: The amount has been updated to $478.94 , which accounts for a Florida timely filing discount (also known as the Florida ' Collection Allowance ') of $12.28 . The total tax collected that we see is $491.22 , which aligns with the combined sum of the tax due, as noted in bold, and the timely filing discount. Here's an updated table with the FL amount updated: State code Period Estimated sales tax FL May 2025 $478.94 GA May 2025 $197.14 IL May 2025 $254.00 MI May 2025 $35.82 MN May 2025 $119.00 OH May 2025 $297.99 UT May 2025 $294.65 VA May 2025 $177.40 Estimated sales tax this month: May 2025 $1,854.94 Please let me know if we have your approval to proceed with the FL filing or if you have any questions.

Please run the Florida report one more time and let me see if it coincides with what I have on my end. Ken MacMaster +1-80-GOT-WATTS +1(860) 468-9288 WiredWatts.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ken, Thanks for the response; continued patience here! So, it should not be run in EST, it should be run in EDT should it not? Correct! In this situation, a time zone-related difference would be a bit different because of the following: Zamp's API receives date stamps (the transactionDate property) in UTC unless the time zone is specified in the request. I can confirm if this is the case if you or your team could share an example API request with me. Zamp then converts the UTC date/time stamp into EST for Florida. The above means that there can still be a slight variance depending on whether the date/time stamp sent to Zamp was in UTC or if it indicated the time zone was in EST. Here's how to indicate if a date/time stamp is in UTC or EST: For UTC, the date/time value would have a 'Z' at the end like this: 2025-06-09T18:40:00 Z For EST, the date/time value would have a time zone on the end of it, such as '-4:00' for EST (EDT, during Daylight Saving Time), such as: 2025-06-09T18:40:00 -04:00 That said, I don't believe time zones are the cause of the larger difference you've noted for Florida here, and I'll share more details below. The cause of the Florida discrepancy here: After digging into this further, I found that the cause of the difference was related to Order ID 229610 because this transaction was created within Zamp as if it should be fully taxable, and $0 tax was collected: For API integrations such as Wired Watts' integration with Zamp, our tax-due estimates are based on what should have been collected via the Zamp API (the taxDue amount). A few questions: 1) Should this transaction be treated as RESALE (wholesale) or something other than fully taxable? 2) If so, does Wired Watts have the ability to update the transaction via the API? We can sort out a path forward for adjusting to this situation once we have more details. I'm also happy to hop on a call with you if that would be helpful! Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Research: I don't see any negative jurisdictions in FL , so that's not the cause. Time zones don't account for this either, because when adjusting for UTC, there is only one extra transaction worth a few dollars in sales tax. This issue appears to be related to Order ID 229610, as it has $0 tax collected but a taxDue, which is likely due to the API. https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/3319-variance-reviewing-by-transactiontax-table?companyId=cm3j4a2ee01c1jx82bksg33hq&stateCode=FL&startDate=2025-05-01&endDate=2025-05-31

author: ken@wiredwatts.com
body: I understand the idea of the time zone thing if the state was in a separate time zone from us, however, that part of Florida is in the same time zone as us in GA. We are both in the Eastern time zone and practice daylight savings at the same time. We recorded the transaction to take place on 5/1/2024 at 12:40 am as did you. If the transaction came in at that time, it was May 1st when that person placed their order in that city in the United States. The only discrepancy would be daylight savings… which the United States takes part in. So, it should not be run in EST, it should be run in EDT should it not? Either way, it sounds like it was already paid for, and as you said, the ~$2 is not the issue here. However, I would like to hear your thoughts on this because this does not make our books align with whatever you are doing on your end. As for the major discrepancy, please let me know what you find. As stated earlier, you can take this email as a "Go-Ahead" on the rest of the filings, we don't need to delay that any further. Just hold off on Florida until we can get some clarity. Ken MacMaster +1-80-GOT-WATTS +1(860) 468-9288 WiredWatts.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ken, Thanks for letting us know. We will investigate this and will follow up as soon as we have more details to share. Regarding Transaction ID 841408 , Zamp is placing this transaction within the April 2025 filing period for Florida. This happens because Zamp files in each state based on the state capital's time zone . Because Florida is in the Eastern Standard Time (EST) zone and this transaction had a UTC timestamp of May 1, 2025, at 12:40 AM, it is included in the April 2025 filing. This transaction can be viewed on your Transactions page here . This transaction doesn't explain the full difference here, though. There are a few other items this could be related to, but we'll need to confirm. We'll investigate further and follow up as soon as we can.

body: Hi Karen and Team, Thanks for your patience here! We investigated this further and confirmed that the difference noted between 'Taxes Due' and 'Tax Collected' is related to the timely filing discounts and the Washington Business and Occupation (B&O) tax. There is some difference here due to sales tax rounding as well. The timely filing discounts can be reviewed on each state's sales tax filing (return) artifact available on your Zamp account's Filing Page here . The discounts vary in name but apply to each state with differences greater than approximately $1.00. In the future, we hope to display the timely filing discount in an easy-to-access way, and we've already started discussions with our engineering team about this. Have a great week!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Richard, One quick follow-up! I'd also like to note that we need to hear back about this, have the situation sorted out, and receive approval to file your sales tax returns by the end of the day on Monday (6/16/25) to ensure the filings are processed on time for NY and CA.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Richard, Thanks for your continued patience here! We've confirmed that the tax-due estimate Zamp shared is based on the tax collected from your Shopify store, which includes both in-person POS location sales and online sales. To our understanding, if a business has nexus in a state, sales tax is calculated and collected for in-person locations and online sales. Additionally, Zamp's tax-due estimate includes only the taxes we've seen collected within your Shopify store. I've attached an export of the transactions we've sold to or shipped to customers located in California and New York. It's important to note that the New York filing includes transactions from March 1, 2025, to May 31, 2025, because New York follows a fiscal quarter with a different date range than other states. A couple of quick questions: 1) To review this further and compare directly against Shopify's reporting, could you please share your Shopify store's Collaborator request code ? This code should be under Settings —> Users within your Shopify Admin. The collaborator access code is something separate from Zamp's automatic import of your Shopify transactions and allows us to review orders, sales tax reporting, and tax settings. 2) Also, could you let me know if we have your approval to proceed with After Market's filings this month? We've held the filings to allow time to investigate this and ensure we're all on the same page.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Richard, Thanks for reaching out! We're investigating this situation and will follow up as soon as we know more.

body: Hi Sean, Thanks for the update; I understand! Yes—if this is completed over the weekend, that will give us enough time to get the data into Zamp, for Zamp's system to calculate the estimated tax due, and for us to get an estimate out to you. That said, we would need to have the filings approved and released by the end of the day on Monday. If that would be a stretch or tight turnaround on your end, we can push them into June 2025 to then proceed with $0 filings (with the goal being to file timely, avoid going to the overdue filings queue, and avoid penalties & interest from the state.) What would you say works best for you?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, You're welcome! Have enabled Ohio, do we need to put a tax ID for the zamp calcs to work? Great! Thanks for the update! No—the Sales tax ID field is optional, as Shopify notes in their article here (it's a good practice to add the tax ID when one is available). Just so you know, Shopify Tax is handling the sales tax calculations here, as Zamp is unable to calculate sales tax within Shopify. Zamp will, however, provide the economic nexus threshold monitoring, registration, filing, and compliance aspects of the puzzle.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma and Angus, Thanks for your patience here! I don't seem to be able to add members, please could you add Angus to the Zamp portal? Sure! I've added Angus as a user to the Ancient + Brave Zamp portal, and an invite was sent to angus@ancientandbrave.earth . If we should add Tom or others to the Ancient + Brave Zamp portal, please let us know either in this email thread or onboarding@zamp.com. Chris - should all wholesale transactions show as RESALE in Zamp, regardless of nexus/non-nexus/certificate exemption status? Yes—all wholesale transactions will show up as RESALE within Zamp, and we'd recommend implementing a process around this regardless of nexus/non-nexus considerations. The reason for the above is that some US states exclude Wholesale/Resale transactions from their economic nexus thresholds, and Zamp has logic in place to account for this, state by state. In terms of letting you know test orders to delete from Zamp, is there a deadline to communicate this to you before they get filed? Yes—we would need to know which transactions to delete (a date range or IDs/names) by the 5th of the month if Zamp is filing sales tax returns for Ancient + Brave, as that is typically the earliest date we would start filing. Can we also see US sales tax in the order in Shopify? Yes—once tax collection is enabled for a state within Shopify, the tax will show up as a line between Subtotal and Total on a Shopify order: Here's an example: I assume I can go ahead and set Ohio up as a state A+B collects tax in on Shopify safely before I go on holiday? Sure, if that works best for you! I'll need to do this before UAT starts, but it makes me nervous that we're using Zamp's live system to test on the test Shopify store - is there not a sandbox we can connect to? I understand, and we can certainly switch to using a Sandbox account here instead. I've created an account within Zamp titled "Ancient + Brave Sandbox," and I've invited the following emails as users to this account. hello@emmaforward.co.uk angus@ancientandbrave.earth sophie@highcohesion.com A question here —since we're taking the sandbox approach with this, is it OK if we temporarily disconnect the Shopify store (ancientandbrave-us.myshopify.com) from the production account, named "Ancient + Brave"? I could then also remove any test transactions that have synced so far.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, You're welcome! I am writing to note that we've received your questions and will provide answers to you today by 4:00 EST.

author: hello@emmaforward.co.uk

Chris - should all wholesale transactions show as RESALE in Zamp, regardless of nexus/non-nexus/certificate exemption status? I want to be crystal clear on the UAT sheet's expected results. In terms of letting you know test orders to delete from Zamp, is there a deadline to communicate this to you before they get filed? Additionally, in the expected results on the UAT sheet, I've said to check Zamp for US sales tax calcs. Can we also see US sales tax in the order in Shopify? I don't see it as a line item in there currently when I look at a test order in Shopify, but we haven't set up Ohio as nexus yet. FYI tomorrow is my last working day until Monday 9th June and UAT will be conducted next week so I'd be grateful for a prompt response before I go. Many thanks, Emma Emma Forward eCommerce Consultant, eForward 07985644431 | eforward.digital Best Female eCommerce Consultant (UK) | Influential Businesswoman Awards 2024 Business Excellence Award Winner | FSB London Awards 2024 eCommerce Consultant of the Year 2023 | Management Consulting Awards 2023 Most Influential Woman in eCommerce Consulting 2023 | Influential Businesswoman Awards Most Trusted eCommerce Consultant | Greater London Enterprise Awards 2021 & 2022 Entrepreneur of the Year Shortlister | Women in IT Awards 2022 & 2023 Digital/eCommerce Business of the Year | FSB Awards London Finalist 2022 Digital Women Awards 2021 | Freelancer of the Year Finalist Holiday: 30th May - 8th June

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, Thanks for your patience! Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team, and I'm jumping in to help after syncing with Caroline about your questions. Also, I'm in the process of writing the testing scripts for the Shopify integration. Are there any particular testing scenarios you think are worth including? We'd recommend testing some basic scenarios here, and other testing depends on the third-party Shopify apps that are planned for implementation: An order shipping to a nexus state (e.g., Ohio) has tax collected. An order to a non-nexus state (not set up to collect tax) does not have tax collected. Orders for wholesale customers do not have tax collected and show up within Zamp as RESALE on the transactions page. If any third-party apps, such as those listed below, are used, we recommend reviewing those orders to ensure the tax amounts match within Zamp and Shopify (we can help if this is not the case or if these apps are planned). Loop - returns & exchanges. ReturnGo AfterShip Outside of the above, everything should be smooth sailing. I reviewed the Ancient + Brave store and confirmed that products are categorized and Shopify Tax is enabled. Also, once you know that your testing is complete, please let us know, and we can remove the test orders from Zamp by either the Shopify Order ID, Order Name, or a date range. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @carie - I've been working through the output Kyle shared. A few things: I realized we needed data from 11/1/23 to 12/31/24; we didn't need the October 2023 data, as we didn't file (per Nicole's notes above). The SUM of tax still doesn't match the tax due in the liability report , but that may be fine. I realized that we don't have the source data they're comparing against, so it's challenging to determine how close we are or whether this is the right approach to take. There are some transactions (highlighted in green in the attached file) that were created or updated after we filed for the customer. Although the amount is small, it may make a difference. I didn't see many transactions that had a difference between the Zamp created date and the updated date, meaning it's unlikely there were many updates to the data after we filed. There was one transaction, but it was updated 1 minute after it was created, and that shouldn't matter. This won't account for edited orders or partial refunds in Shopify (as Kyle noted here .) Could the customer be granted an extension, or should we schedule a call to talk about this more? They keep asking for the BigCommerce transactions or source files, but those will not match; we might want to explain that. I'd need more time to review the numbers and the data they're comparing against (we don't have all Nov 2023-Dec 2024 filing amounts uploaded into Zamp, it appears ). cc: @nick @ashleyD - in case either of you has thoughts or ideas. This one is pretty tricky.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Andy, You're welcome, and I'm glad these details have been helpful! Great! We understand that process changes take time, and we appreciate your patience as we work through these scenarios. Sometimes, (like this month or last month), we can accurately sort through it later in the month than we'd like. We still have some outstanding items surrounding wholesale transactions and order edit review in historical periods that we're working through (it's taken much longer than expected due to the volume of data and unexpected delays on our end). OK, understood regarding wholesale transactions. Please let us know if the scenarios arise where tax is refunded or if you have any questions. You're very welcome! We're all set now and we'll be sure to reach out if anything comes up! Have a great rest of your week!!

author: andy@ghostgolf.com
body: Hey Chris, Thanks for the follow-up - really appreciate the thorough breakdown and the supporting reports. I've shared this with our team. The tax per state looks good to me and I've already approved it for payments. I also really appreciate the effort you're putting in to make sure everything reconciles correctly - it's important we're only paying taxes we're actually responsible for. Regarding Wholesale transactions : What typically happens on our end is that the customer reaches out letting us know tax was incorrectly applied, and we either have to reimburse them or they short pay the invoice, which then requires us to manually correct the order. Going forward, we'll tighten this up to ensure anything tagged as WholesaleNoTax is properly exempted and doesn't have tax collected. Appreciate your help on all of this - let me know if anything else is needed from our side. Best, Andy

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Andy, A quick follow-up! I've confirmed that after running our temporary workaround method to force the reconciliation between Zamp's tax amounts and Shopify's tax amounts, the estimate sent just a bit ago aligns with the Shopify United States Sales Tax Report for April 2025 when filtering by Shopify Destination states we're filing in this month; I've attached a copy of that export from Shopify. Regarding Wholesale transactions: I've also attached a comparison of a Shopify export (looking for the 'Wholesale' or 'WholesaleNoTax' tags), which shows several transactions tagged with a wholesale tax, that have tax collected and paid without tax refunds. There are about 10 transactions with either of these tags that haven't been paid yet (it looks like they have various payment terms), and one example is #490783 . For the transactions noted above with payment pending and a wholesale tag, will the tax be removed from those Shopify orders, and should we offset this within Zamp? Please let me know if you'd like to hop on a quick call to discuss.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Matt, Thanks for sharing these details. This makes sense to me! To our understanding, Affordable Screen Company should charge an 8.25% rate in Texas because you have a location in Texas. Texas is an origin-based sales tax state , meaning the rate charged is based on your Lewisville, Texas, location. This can vary with other states, especially if you don't have a location in that state. How do other companies handle this? This depends on the accounting/ERP system being used. In the past, I've seen other companies handle this by: Using the built-in (native) automatic tax calculation functionality in systems such as QuickBooks Online, NetSuite, etc. Configure manual rates within the system by city, state, and jurisdiction. Configure an average sales tax rate for various states (this can lead to a mixture of under- and over-sales tax collection). Implement an integration with a sales tax API like Zamp's API for real-time sales tax calculations (if technical resources are available)? A few questions to help us research possibilities here: 1) Which accounting system are you using? 2) Have you ever needed to charge sales tax for customers outside of TX within this accounting system, and if so, how was that set up in the past? We could also hop on a quick call later this week or next.

author: matt@affordablescreenco.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, I hope you are doing well. I’m following up on the tax treatment of your Substack newsletter as a digital good in Texas and Connecticut, as our Tax Research Team shared some additional context and discovered an item specific to Connecticut. In Texas , a Substack newsletter is classified as a digital good, treated as tangible personal property under Texas Tax Code § 151.009 . This means it is subject to the full sales tax rate, similar to physical goods, and not at the reduced 80% taxable threshold that applies to certain services like information or data processing services ( Texas Tax Code § 151.351 ). Substack's digital newsletter is a product, not a service. Specifically, downloadable articles (txcd_10303000) and non-downloadable articles ( txcd_10304102 ) are taxable sales in Texas. In Connecticut , digital goods are also considered tangible personal property and are generally subject to the standard 6.35% sales tax rate, as outlined in Special Notice 2018(8) . However, after further review, Connecticut exempts sales of newspapers, whether in physical or electronic form, from sales tax under Conn. Gen. Stat. § 12-412(114) . As a result, both downloadable ( txcd_10303000 ) and non-downloadable ( txcd_10304102 ) newsletter articles are exempt from sales tax in Connecticut. It’s worth noting that some platforms, like Stripe, may not distinguish between electronically supplied goods or services in their general categories, such as the Stripe Tax code txcd_10000000 , which is currently configured. This means that if the path to not distinguish between downloadable and non-downloadable is taken, Stripe and Zamp would treat Citrinitas' newsletter product as taxable in both CT and TX. I hope this is helpful, and please let us know if you have any questions.

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, I hope this message finds you well. I’m reaching out to follow up on the tax treatment of your Substack newsletter as a digital good in Texas and Connecticut. In Texas, a Substack newsletter is classified as a digital good, treated as tangible personal property under Texas Tax Code § 151.009 . This means it is subject to the full sales tax rate, similar to physical goods, and not at the reduced 80% taxable threshold that applies to certain services like information or data processing services ( Texas Tax Code § 151.351 ). Substack's digital newsletter is a product, not a service. Specifically, downloadable articles (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS) and non-downloadable articles (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER) are both taxable sales in Texas. In Connecticut, digital goods are also considered tangible personal property and are generally subject to the standard 6.35% sales tax rate, as outlined in Special Notice 2018(8) . However, after further review, Connecticut exempts sales of newspapers, whether in physical or electronic form, from sales tax under Conn. Gen. Stat. § 12-412(114) . As a result, both downloadable (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS) and non-downloadable (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER) newsletter articles are exempt from sales tax in Connecticut. It’s worth noting that while some platforms, like Stripe, may not distinguish between electronically supplied goods or services in their general categories. Best, Ashley I think I'm stuck on what product tax code they should be using to be sure that their product is taxed appropriately. I hope that this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: From Tax Research (Mira) here: https://linear.app/zamptax/issue/TBD-349/request-confirmation-on-ptc-taxability-for-substack-in-texas-and 1.  Should a Substack newsletter be considered a digital good within Texas and Connecticut's definitions? Yes, an online newsletter is a digital good within both states, but the taxation varies (see below). 2.  Are digital goods in Texas fully taxable or taxed at a reduced rate or threshold of 80%, like SaaS is? Digital goods in Texas are taxed like tangible personal property. TX Letter Ruling 20005359L indicates that digital products are tangible personal property as defined in TX Tax Code § 151.009 ("'Tangible personal property' means personal property that can be seen, weighed, measured, felt, or touched or that is perceptible to the senses in any other manner, and, for the purposes of this chapter, the term includes a computer program and a telephone prepaid calling card."). The 80% tax situation applies only to information services and data processing services ( TX Tax Code § 151.351 ). "Information service" is defined as "furnishing general or specialized news or other current information" unless it is furnished to a physical, printed newspaper licensed by the Federal Communications Commission ( TX Tax Code § 151.0038(1) ). Substack's digital newsletter is a product, ​not a service​. The service of providing information to a newspaper is different from the digital newspaper/newsletter that is produced and distributed. As long as Substack categorizes its product as a digital newsletter (rather than some sort of service), it has to treat it as a digital good. Therefore, in Texas, R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS for downloadable articles and R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER for non-downloaded articles are both taxable sales (which we have correct in our system). 3 - Would a digital good be considered fully taxable in CT or taxed at a 1% rate? Special Notice 2018(8) indicates that digital goods are included in the definition of tangible personal property and are taxed at the 6.35% rate effective Oct. 2019. However, sales of newspapers, whether sold as physical copies or electronically accessed or transferred are exempt from sales tax ( Conn. Gen. Stat. § 12-412(114) ). Therefore, in Connecticut, R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS for downloadable articles and R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER for non-downloaded articles are both exempt sales (which we have correct in our system). I also want to point out that Stripe does not distinguish between an electronically supplied good or service at the "general" category that appears on Substack's support article . But for tax purposes, it is a vital distinction. It's up to the customer to classify their product correctly. In my opinion, a newsletter is a digital good, not a service. Let me know if I can be of further help!
