author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, Thanks for your patience here! We talked about this internally and wanted to share the details previously noted by our Tax Research and Content Team and how we would view this situation. Overall, Zamp understands and interprets that Citrinitas' offerings would be fully taxable at the full rate for Connecticut and Texas. The above interpretation is due to Citrinitas' offering being viewed as a digital good, separate from Software products/services, where the TX 80% reduced rate rule applies; this is also our view of the 1% rate for CT . From our understanding, Substack allows writers to share information via written format, podcasts, and videos. All three are digital products, or as Maine calls them, "products transferred electronically." This fits with the support article that advises using "General—Electronically Supplied Services." It seems like Citrinitas has some articles that can be downloaded and some that cannot. The ability to download matters in some states. Therefore, if they ​do not​ want to differentiate between which articles can be downloaded and which cannot, they can use R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS (which will tax both types of articles). Chris R Note - this is currently what the existing Stripe Tax code maps to, within Zamp. If they do want to make the distinction between downloadable and non-downloadable, these tax codes can be used: The Stripe Tax code for downloadable articles: txcd_10303000 The Stripe Tax code for non-downloadable articles is: txcd_10304102 Next steps: That being said, we will triple-check with our Tax Research team to confirm this interpretation and for any additional context that comes with our advisory services. As soon as we have more details, we'll follow up immediately. Have a great weekend!

body:
Hi Nicole, Thanks for confirming these details! I've imported the credit memo, and that change is now reflected in our tax-due estimate. Regarding #2 —yes, that's correct! These would be related to any credit memos not sourced from Shopify and are processed within QuickBooks Online. Below is the updated tax-due estimate, but first, I wanted to share some details about the difference for Colorado. Regarding Colorado: The $42.60 difference for Colorado is related to a refund transaction (#1899), causing the tax amount for the Denver, CO local jurisdictions within the CO filing to become negative. This applies to the City, County, and special tax (e.g., transportation or facilities-related districts). God's True Cashmere didn't have enough sales in these jurisdictions throughout April 2025 to cover the full refunded tax amount. A portion of the refunded tax is excluded from the filing because the Colorado Department of Revenue (DOR) doesn't allow negative amounts in local jurisdictions when filing Colorado returns; the majority of states don't allow this. In a situation like this, Zamp would need to file the sales tax return in CO as it is or after removing the refund transaction. As an exception, we can move this refund transaction into the May 2025 filing period to be processed in June 2025 if you'd like us to. Please note that we'll need to know how to proceed here by the end of the day (EST) tomorrow, May 15th, 2025 , to file for God's True Cashmere in a timely manner. If we cannot proceed or don't hear back, the filings will need to move into our overdue filings queue and could be subject to state-applied penalties & interest. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Israel and Team, Thanks so much for your patience here! My name is Chris. I'm part of the Technical Success Team here at Zamp, and we've been investigating the differences noted for the November 2025 filing period. After further review, it appears that Shopify Tax collected amounts for the October 2024 filing period (10/1/24-10/31/24) were used for the comparison on the 'Zamp-Filings' sheet of the file you shared. I've attached a modified version of your XLSX file with an extra sheet showing the November 2024 Shopify tax collected amounts on their own; this is on the 'Z Shopify Review - Nov 24' sheet. The 'Zamp-Filings' sheet has been updated with those amounts. That said, we're still seeing close to a 12% difference between Zamp and Shopify for Oklahoma and Rhode Island ; those are highlighted in blue. In both of these states, Zamp filed overdue returns in January 2025, while they were due in December 2024. The differences here are due to penalties & interest assessed by the state. The differences that are under or within ~2% are very likely due to timely filing discounts, rounding, or time zone differences; we share more info about that here . We also reviewed your account for known third-party apps (such as Loop, which Zamp accounts for and appears to be appropriately configured) or edge-case scenarios that might cause differences. A quick question: Which Shopify Report do you use to reconcile and compare? In our Comparison, we used the Shopify United States Sales Tax Report because Velvet Caviar uses Shopify Tax for the calculations. We've found this report to typically align closely with Zamp (with a few differences noted above). It also appears that you're likely using this report, but we wanted to confirm. If you'd like to discuss this on a call next week or sometime soon, please use this link to schedule a call . Have a wonderful weekend!

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Israel, Thanks for reaching out! I'm happy to address these items. When registering in California, the state flagged the original nexus start date as potentially being after the point of crossing the economic threshold and they wanted Velvet Caviar to reassess this information. After further conversation with Paul, the nexus start date was reassessed to March 1, 2023. This was resolved in February after the Q4 2024 deadline resulting in penalties and interest associated with the filing. This is the difference you are seeing for this period. We are reviewing these periods and will keep you updated. Thank you! In New York, you are on a quarterly prepayment filing frequency so the majority of the tax had already been submitted as "Advance payments". You can find this on your New York Q4 2024 return on page 8. I hope that this helps to clarify and please let me know if you have any further questions! In the meantime, we will work to look closer at November. Best, Ashley

author: finance@velvetcaviar.com
body: Hi Ashley, Thanks for the access- I was able to pull the Zamp filing reports and tie them back to the bank withdrawals. I also took another pass at reconciling the Shopify sales report. I understand there may be some timing differences, but I wanted to flag a few discrepancies and get your input: California Q4 shows a large discrepancy 129K paid vs 115K on the report-do you have any insight into this? November filings across multiple states also seem off. Was there a specific issue that month that could be contributing to these variances? Could it also be tied to the California Q4 discrepancy? Just a heads up: the Shopify report I'm using includes returns in the tax totals. Lastly, regarding New York : it looks like we began filing monthly starting in December, but the Q4 NY filing totals only show about $11K-did we potentially miss a month? Let me know what you think when you get a chance and if it would be easier to just jump on a call. Thanks -- Israel Vaca Financial Controller | Velvet Caviar inc. VelvetCaviar.com | @velvetcaviar

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chad, You're welcome! Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success team. We've started investigating this and haven't yet found the exact (or entire) root cause. We've discovered eighteen 2024 exchange transactions processed through Loop that could be a part of the difference you're seeing. We'll also dig deeper into Loop return transactions. In the past, these transactions have been processed correctly with Zamp because our Shopify integration has some Loop-specific logic in place for handling those. When you have a moment, could you please share a copy or export of whichever report you're using to determine this potential variance? This will help us remain on the same page and compare similar data sets. We'll find the pattern and root cause one way or another! We hope to have more details to share by early next week!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - I've looked into this some, and will have more time throughout today/tomorrow. So far, I see very few Loop transactions that overstate the tax due because we see Loop exchange transactions without tax listed (which would mean they probably have the Loop Discount disabled, which is what we want). https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clv2sou8001uto8m6dh2m8ykj/transactions?search=EXC&date=2025-01-01%7E2025-05-08&limit=100 That said, there are ~15-18 transactions since we started filing (8/1/23-5/8/25) where Loop transactions associated with exchanges have tax associated with them; these would typically cause duplicate tax. We'll need to dig into this further, but these can also be adjusted for within future periods. https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/5644-find-shopify-loop-exchange-transactions-with-tax-collected-v2?company=clv2sou8001uto8m6dh2m8ykj&start=2023-08-01&end=2025-05-08 We'll also need to manually review their Shopify transactions vs. Zamp transactions because they're using Avalara for tax calculations in Shopify , which is trickier to investigate. (We don't have the Shopify US Taxes report to work off of, just the 'taxes' report , which I'll need to review more.) That said, Zamp's estimate is under the total tax collected for April 2025 in the 'Taxes Report', but that's likely due to filing frequency differences and time zones.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @nick - This could be a good reconciliation to dive into if you'd like to. We'd need to use: The United States sales tax report and the Transactions version of that report. I'd usually run the Shopify forced recon script here, and we still could, but I did that already for this customer before filing. We'd likely want to look at the results of Variance reviewing and j urisdiction-level queries to see if anything stands out. Suppose they have a bunch of refunds in various states, making the amount in the jurisdiction-level query negative. If the amount is negative and ends up being close to the difference here, that is likely the culprit. There's a good chance the differences are just time zones, rounding, etc, as the overall difference is only ~6.6%, but it's high in some states. Lucas or I are happy to help with this too, if there are questions.

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Hey Chris! I just saw this notification and dug in since we definitely don't have $100k USD in PA transactions. But I think I found the issue 😊 What I believe is happening is that things are importing with a translation issue. If we're using the foreign currency, then the integration is multiplying by the currency conversion rate instead of what we should be doing, which is dividing. As an example, Invoice 6448 should total $18,000 USD but is showing up as ~$36,800 USD in Zamp (see attached screenshots). If I take the QBO canadian amount of $25,734.33 CAD, and divide it by $18,000 USD, that implies a 1.429685 exchange rate. But $25,734.33 * 1.429685 = $36,791.99 which is what is showing up in Zamp. Let me know what you think or if you would like to chat through! Cheers, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sandy, You're welcome, and we greatly appreciate your continued patience here! We're still evaluating the situation and data from multiple angles. We've had a few unexpected delays. So far, we haven't found evidence of transactions sold through Marketplace Platforms having tax attributed to them within Zamp because Zamp will attribute a $0 transaction tax value for Meta, Shop, and TikTok if our integration "knows" that the transaction is from one of those channels. By extension, this should mean that the Taxes Collected Report shouldn't include Marketplace Facilitator tax collection. This situation is tricky because, to my understanding, not all SHOP transactions will be associated with Marketplace Facilitator tax collection. That said, I'd like to be sure we're on the same page and have a couple of quick questions: Note—I will also sync with Ashley about this when we're all back from the US holiday this weekend. 1) Which Marketplace or Shop Channel transactions do you see tax collection for, within Zamp? 2) If a specific transaction wasn't the cause of the concern, was this related to differing amounts in the liability review process? 3) To ensure we're comparing and reviewing the same data sources, could you please let us know which Shopify Reports were used in this liability review and reconciliation process? Was it the United States Sales Tax Report , the Taxes Report , or something else? Have a wonderful weekend!

body: Hi Ashley, Here is the spreadsheet that we discussed during our call. As I mentioned, the main goal is to be able to support the liability on our B/S. Currently the only two reports available are the 1) Taxes Collected report and the 2) Tax Liability report. The tax collected report includes taxes collected on marketplace platforms so this report overstates our liability. While the tax liability provides a fairly accurate tax liability for states that are reported monthly, however the tax liability report does not provide the tax liability for states with a quarterly, semi-annual or annual reporting requirement like Illinois which has an annual reporting. Any help on providing a report that would support our tax liability would be greatly appreciated. Thanks, Sandy Jones Iron Clad Consulting Controller

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Sandy, Thank you for sending over these questions! We are happy to address these. Shopify Shop is a Marketplace facilitator which means that they are responsible for collecting and remitting sales tax related to Shopify Shop sales channel. You can find additional information here . While you are not responsible for collecting and remitting sales tax, we do still include these transactions in your sales tax returns and they will be reflected as a Marketplace exemption/deductions (depending on the state's requirements). The transaction IDs (6005407449255 and 6005255405735) are related to Shopify Shop transactions and are reported on your sales tax returns but you are not responsible for remitting the tax collected by Shopify Shop. We are receiving your TikTok transactions via Shopify. However, you are not responsible for remitting the sales tax collected by Shopify as they are also a Marketplace facilitator. I'm happy to gain more information on your additional questions on a call. Feel free to schedule a time that works best for you here . Best, Ashley

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Sandy, Thank you for sending over these questions! We are happy to address these. author: sandy.jones@go-ironclad.com
body: Good afternoon, Client - David Protein We are trying to ensure that all sales tax collected is being remitted to the proper governmental agencies.  In our analysis, we have found transactions that are not being remitted as they should.  I'd like to set up some time to understand why Zamp is not reporting and sending sales tax on the following Shop Channel Transactions and what needs to be done to correct this.  I could not find a way within Zamp to set up a time to discuss these issues so I am reaching out via email. Following are the general areas that I would like to discuss with you: Shopify Payments - the majority of the transactions are flowing through to Zamp with a few exceptions.  For example, transaction ID 6005407449255 - Shopify shows $2.56 in sales tax collected but Zamp did not report these taxes. TikTok - This looks like an integration we may need to add as no TikTok transactions are being reported.  How do we go about getting this Channel added in Zamp? Shop Cash / Shopify Payments - when a customer uses Shop Cash, Zamp is not remitting the sales tax - Is this a separate integration?  Why would this be?  For example, transaction ID 6005255405735 - Shopify shows $6.24 in sales tax collected but Zamp did not report these taxes. How are returns handled?  Do they just flow into the next month's reporting? How do we go about getting the previous month's sales tax reported/sent to the proper governmental authorities? I have copied Sam Bauman, David Protein's Director of Finance, if you need any authorization to speak to me on his account.  Please suggest a few times when we could discuss the above or send me a link to select a time to meet. Thanks, Sandy Jones Iron Clad Consulting Controller (928) 261-0357

author: ryan@zamp.com
body: Hey Andrew, Sorry for the hold up here. I went through all transactions with a note attached and was actually surprised at how many were accurate . For example, 74075 shows all the correct logic, following best accounting principles: - Taxable transaction - Refunded transaction - Recreated transaction as exempt On the other hand, the exact same scenario is a bust for some reason (74018): - Taxable transaction - Refunded transaction - Recreated transaction as exempt - Refunded the recreated transaction as exempt. For some of the other orders where there was an adjustment/change, I noticed we didn't create the transaction with the appropriate change, or it was just left as refunded. This was the case for 140162 and 140425. I had corrected these. In either case, the guys are going to kick a new notice your way that is mathematically sound to the transaction exports I did from BigCommerce. I'm going to take these issues to my write-up for the integration developers. Thanks! Ryan

author: ryan@zamp.com
body: Hey Andrew, Yeah! More to share and a new notice end of week. I shared this with the team internally earlier. I wrote something to handle a comparison where the order notes field was used to look at the records in Zamp. It produces a trail to show all coinciding transactions produced on our end. This also works as a precursor to looking back at old records from before we talked about using the order notes field. The "Difference" log line is a comparison of the "Order Total (Inc Tax)" from a BigCommerce orders export to the Zamp net total after all the records. There are some examples further down the trail where the difference is more apparent. I think there were a total of 14 orders across SSM and PSP that have order notes from April. This work will continue into the end of the week, when I hope to clear getting a new notice your way from our team. As for the actual app and corrections to the integration itself, still getting the details together for the team that manage the integration. We're still closing out some prior work. Thanks for your patience,

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hi Chris, I won't argue too much about whether the /addresses validation is correct or not other than to say that our customer entered a valid address and your API marked it as invalid. Any technicalities or specific configurations that caused it doesn't invalidate the fact that the API got it wrong and caused the customer justifiable frustration. Regardless, we have already implemented such functionality in our checkout process. It displays a simple warning when the address entered is marked as invalid by the inconsistent /addresses validator, and it allows the checkout to continue without sales tax calculation in such cases. Thanks, Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, Thanks for the response! No—I was referring to a slightly different configuration (and likely UI updates) or checkout flow to ensure address validation doesn't prevent the customer from continuing through checkout. I've seen Magento or WooCommerce implement address validation in this way and have heard from clients I worked with in roles elsewhere of similar changes (this might be a big lift, and is not necessarily required.) From our standpoint, the /addresses validation is correct as it was initially built and needs a configuration tweak. Zamp uses more data sources with higher accuracy overall, or at least simply a different way of processing the data (From the Google Maps API), which can result in variance with other address validation services. I hope this helps!

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hi Chris, Are you suggesting integrating into Google Maps API because the /addresses validation is incorrect? Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, Thanks for the update! I understand. In a situation like this and in general, it might be worth implementing some 'select an address' functionality to display the original address and the updated address, if any; if there isn't another address, allow the checkout process to proceed. In general, address validation shouldn't prevent the checkout process from completing. We also understand if this isn't an option here.

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hi Chris, Sounds good. We will be unable to fully utilize the address validation until that is put in place. It shouldn't be a huge deal. Thanks, Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, A quick follow-up here! Our Engineering Team told me that Zamp viewed the address as invalid because of a data and geolocation quality indicator we have in place for address validation. Here's a bit of detail: Zamp's /addresses API endpoint is currently configured to allow only rooftop or parcel address precision confidence levels, and we receive a zip9 response for this address, but we also received an indicator that DPV = 'Y' This happens because Zamp utilizes a different address validation solution than Google, with a broader mix of data. We found a strategy here that would allow addresses with a DPV value of Y for this scenario and cast a wider net for valid addresses, an indicator tied to the data existing within a USPS dataset. We've passed along a feature request that would add the DPV item noted above to the validation ruleset, and we hope to have it released in the future. Once this is released, we'll be sure to follow up!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tracey, Thanks for checking in! We've resolved the differences, and an updated tax-due estimate will be sent out within the next few minutes. The good news is that our filing team will be able to file these returns on time, and there will be no late charges from the states. We keep these dates in mind as we work through various situations, and we'll communicate this more clearly going forward. For Illinois and Iowa filings, we have until 5/15/2025 to file on time, ideally we would file before that date. We looked into this further and found the following items contributed to the differences here: For Iowa , we found that Transaction ID 144 had a date of 4/29/ 26 instead of 4/29/ 25 , causing the transaction to be placed in a future filing period. We have updated this, and we've made improvements to prevent situations like this from occurring in the future. For Illinois , we found that the difference you noted was due to our tax-due estimate automatically accounting for the Illinois timely filing discount (also known as the 'Retailer's discount'), and that estimated amount is $398.00 . The IL Retailer's discount is applied when filing on time and is 1.75% of the sales tax collected. Please let us know if you have any questions. I hope that you have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Heather, Thanks for sending this over! To ensure we're on the same page, are we wondering why the 'Tax Collected' and 'Tax Due' values differ? If the above is the case, I've outlined our findings for the states noted below. Colorado - This difference is due to the CO's timely filing discount. Florida - this difference is also due to a timely filing discount for FL. Illinois - This is another difference due to the timely filing discount for IL. Washington—This difference is caused by the Business & Occupation gross receipts tax (0.471% of all transactions) due when filing sales tax returns in CO, which is 34.97. If the above helps and makes sense here, it appears that adjustments won't be needed for the April 2025 filing period, we can skip the adjustment imports this month, and send the tax-due estimate out, today. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sarita, Thanks for your patience with this! I checked in with our Head of Filing, who noted that if we cannot access the Shipping address details in Target's order exports and sales tax report exports, we can place the Target Plus transactions into a zip code within that state. Ultimately, our primary recommendation is to either implement a third-party tool like Acenda (or something similar, but this isn't an endorsement) or contact Target Plus Seller Support via the Target Plus portal to find a way to obtain an export from Target Plus with the shipping address data. Working with Target Plus Seller Support is likely the best path forward here. It may involve submitting a ticket to them (or emailing them) via the 'Support' section on the left-hand side of the portal, as during our call, we saw that the 'support' option was some chatbot. When you have a moment, could you please share a CSV file with the Target Plus transaction data listed by state? I'm also happy to hop on another quick call if you'd like to discuss any of this or have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: I asked filing about this here: https://zamp-workspace.slack.com/archives/C04QMDBG6G7/p1746647202358879

author: chris@zamp.com
body: I had a call with Sarita about this, today. For the Target data: Possibility: Can we pick a random city, state, or zip code to associate the transactions? They can get totals per state from a sales tax export from Target. The orders exported don't contain addresses, but they contain amounts. The returns export doesn't contain amounts, but it includes a return location, sometimes.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sarita, Thanks again for your patience! We reviewed the Target Plus file and found that while it does contain some of the information we need, it's missing the Ship To Address details. To import and use the data in sales tax filings, Zamp would need at least the Ship To Zip code , or the Ship To City and Ship To State . Also, Zamp would need every row in the CSV file to contain amounts (discounts, subtotal, etc.) and a transaction date. Unfortunately, we haven't had to export data from Target Plus yet, as we haven't received this kind of request in the past. If we find or think of any customers also selling through Target Plus, we'll ask them how they approach it. That said, we did some research here and this is what we've found: The Target Plus Reports do not contain the shipping addresses. A third-party tool like Acenda could obtain an export that includes the Shipping address ( ChannelEngine and other tools don't appear to have this ability, but there may be others). We don't specifically endorse any tool here, as this is new to us. It might be best to contact Target Plus Seller Support via their portal using the help/support features. Target Guest Relations may also be able to direct you to the correct department by calling 1-800-440-0680. Based on our research (what we can find online), it is not easy to get the data Zamp would need for Target Seller Plus sales. If you can see a way to obtain the city and state for the orders within Target Plus, we could use that data, but otherwise, it appears to be tricky to accomplish this. If you'd like, we're also happy to schedule a call with this link to share your screen and see if we can find any way around Target Plus' limitations here. If a time on my calendar won't work for you, please let me know what days and times work for you, and I'll check with other folks at Zamp to see who might be available. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Connor, Thanks for sharing this with us! Is it possible to do this? Yes—we can make an exception here, considering the situation with the missing data. We'll be able to hold the filings until the end of the day Friday, May 9th, 2025. We set this date to ensure the sales tax filings are processed before the state's due date and to keep our internal filing processes focused on efficiency. We may have some wiggle room outside of that as a last resort, as our goal in filing timely is to ensure Hume Health Corp doesn't have any penalties or interest assessed by the state. Please let us know if Friday (5/9) will be enough time here. We'll wait for your approval to start the filing process unless we're told otherwise. We're also here to help if there are any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rodger and Team, Thanks for your patience here! We found a few root causes related to the difference here, and I've outlined those below. Refund Transactions with discounts where the tax refunded was lower in Zamp than Shopify—our engineering team is monitoring this, and an improvement is in progress. Order Edits to Shopify orders via Shopify's built-in return/exchange functionality. Shopify's APIs don't expose much of this to Zamp, and what we've seen in the past has been inconsistent and inaccurate. Our engineering team has this on their list to explore solutions for the future. A couple of edge case-related Shopify voided/canceled orders. This is also on our engineering team's radar. Please note that Shopify's tax amounts (within the US Sales Tax Report ) have changed a bit since the initial email: We've adjusted for the differences here and will send you an updated tax-due estimate. For now and until the features/improvements noted above are released, we'll account for these scenarios before sending the tax-due estimate in the future. Please let us know if you have any questions!

The source for the Zamp data: https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/5679-transaction-export-forced-shopify-reconciliation-offset?company=cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb&connectionId=clyg7k3ma00000al7cqsvdf7g&start=2025-04-01&end=2025-04-30 The filing notice: https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/4194-customer-filing-notice-zapier?company=cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb&filingMonth=2025-05-01 Once we've imported the offset file, just let me know and I'll work on getting a response out to the customer. author: chris@zamp.com
body: @lucas - Thanks for your patience! After looking into the order examples you shared, the differences with these orders occur due to a form of order editing that uses Shopify's native (but newer) return/exchange functionality. We can tell this is the case when orders show removed/added items or note 'partially refunded' OB47903 From looking at the transactions page below, we show a remaining $9 for sales tax, but Shopify shows $7.92, so we're off a bit here; that's likely part of the cause (or all.) https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb/transactions?search=OB47903&date=2025-01-01~2025-05-08 This is likely related to this in-progress feature request (issue..): https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/40979248/card_tables/cards/8390180624 ———————————- OB50115 This one looks like an order edit, but it also uses Shopify's return functionality. We don't even have the correct tax amount because of the order edit (removing an item directly in Shopify's UI): The Zamp transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb/transactions?search=OB50115&timezone=US/Local&date=2025-01-01~2025-05-08 $0 for a return/refund and $26.56 for tax. ———————————————————————— OB49868 This one is a voided/canceled order that is related to a different, known, issue. The order was never fulfilled and was voided, which Zamp doesn't currently capture. Zamp transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb/transactions?search=OB49868&timezone=US/Local&date=2025-01-01~2025-05-08 Related issue: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/40979248/card_tables/cards/8390148844 —————————————- The solution for these: We can take the path outlined below because we don't see negative balances in local jurisdictions using this query (for Georgia at least). We should run the Shopify forced reconciliation script here: https://github.com/zamptax/zamp-technical-success/tree/main/utility/scripts/shopify_forced_recon_offset Then, after we allow an hour for the forced reconciliation adjustment transactions to be factored in, compare the Zamp notice amounts (the MB query here ) against the US taxes report to see if they're closer. I can do that today or tomorrow if that's better, or we can run through it together!

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: Hey @chris , can you help me with this? I've already used the Zamp admin's new timezone filter, and it does not explain the whole tax difference, especially in GA. I ran an analysis and found 34 transactions with different tax amounts when comparing Zamp and the US Sales Tax report. Check the table below: state total_tax_transactions total_tax_us_tax_report abs_diff pct_diff tax_diff_reported full_abs_diff full_pct_diff CA 1332.09 1316.05 16 1.2% 16.04 -0.04 0.0% FL 859.67 817.84 41.8 4.9% 22.29 19.51 2.3% GA 237.6 194.89 42.7 18.0% 23.97 18.73 7.9% IL 280.45 271.33 9.1 3.2% 0 9.1 3.2% MI 189.96 187.21 2.8 1.5% -5.72 8.52 4.5% MN 81.47 71.82 9.7 11.9% 0 9.7 11.9% NC 292.24 287.33 4.9 1.7% 4.91 -0.01 0.0% NV 150.79 137.62 13.2 8.8% 13.17 0.03 0.0% TX 1139.02 1124.42 14.6 1.3% 14.6 0 0.0% When checking some of the transactions with different tax amounts reported, I've got stuck trying to find the reason for the difference. Here are some examples: OB47903 OB50115 OB49868 ps: MN difference is completely explained by the timezone

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Catherine, Thanks so much for your patience here! I investigated this and found that Shopify support is correct here as far as I can tell, unless tax collection was never enabled for California. It seems that Shopify either defaulted to collecting taxes when an in-person CA location was added, or it was turned on at some point. Currently, the CA tax collection appears to be disabled per this Shopify taxes report. This appears to be related to the NC Crane AG location's address in San Luis Obispo County, which can be found in Shopify here . Shopify also shares a bit of detail about this here ,  when viewing this location in Shopify and on the ' Manage tax liability ' page here (also shown below): The tax collection for San Luis Obispo County and the city of CA could be correct based on the various tax rules within CA, as that is where this POS location is currently listed. We share more details about this in our California Sales Tax Guide here . We would call this intrastate sales tax sourcing, but as Shopify notes , it's sometimes called 'hybrid origin' sourcing. This type of tax collection involves collecting the California state tax, the county and local taxes of the in-person location, and the city and district taxes associated with the shipping address. The above would be correct if Semaine Health does have a physical location within San Luis Obispo County, is registered to collect and file taxes in CA, and the ' Hybrid-Origin ' tax setting was selected for CA: Zamp's sales tax API would calculate similarly if we knew that Semaine Health had this exact location. If you're not registered to collect in CA (we don't see that listed as such in Zamp) and aren't filing CA returns outside of Zamp, we recommend refunding the taxes collected to your customers if you haven't done so already. Suppose the CA tax wasn't enabled and the 'Hybrid-Origin' option wasn't selected. In that case, we'd recommend you continue to escalate this with Shopify for further investigation (based on our understanding of Shopify's settings and documentation). I understand that the above is a lot of information, which can be tricky (especially when explaining it to a customer). We're happy to hop on a call to discuss this sometime if you'd like! Do you think the above helps answer the situation here? If not, please let us know; we'll clarify! Please let us know if you have any questions, and have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Connor, Thanks for working with us on this! Unfortunately, the 'Criquet Shirts' Shopify Store access still appears pending. This is very strange, and as far as I can tell, you're doing everything correctly. Here's what we see: Is this effecting our filing process? Yes—we're currently holding Criquet Apparel's filings until we can run a bulk sync to update some items associated with Criquet's Shopify transactions. This is due to some changes made on Shopify's end, which required updating our integration. The good news is that we're on top of this and will be able to file on time for you. To file timely, we need to ensure your sales tax filings are moving into our process by Monday, 5/12/25. If needed, we have some additional time past that date, but we're hoping to keep things as efficient as possible. ——————————————————————————- Next steps: 1) Can you hop on a quick call about this so that we can screenshare? Or could you reach out to Shopify Support? I'd love to and am happy to help figure this out. Sometimes, we see delays in Shopify access making its way over to Zamp's partner account, but that's usually no more than a few hours. 2) Alternatively, could you follow the steps below to add the read_locations permission that the Zamp app now needs? I'm also happy to hop on a call to walk through this. Log in to your Shopify admin and select settings ⚙️ at the bottom left of your screen. Select "Apps and sales channels." Select the "Develop apps" button at the top right section next to the "Shopify App Store" button. Click on the "Zamp" custom app In the header section, click on "Configuration." Once in the "Configuration" tab, click the Edit button on the "Admin API integration" sectio.n Once in the Admin API access scope selection view, type "read_locations" into the search box, which will filter your options. Then, click the box next to "read_locations" and click the Save button at the top right of the page.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tzippy, Thanks for your patience here! I looked into the Order IDs below further in Zamp, and the original order, exchange, and return charges and refunds all looked as I expected here, with no incorrect tax or additional amounts on the exchange or return charges. Parent order: 87533 Exchange: 89426 A refunded return charge: 91851 I've also confirmed, after researching some more, that the ReturnGo app should work well with Zamp. Unfortunately, I was unable to find a pre-built report in Shopify that would simplify partial refunds. Still, it appeared to be possible to build a report using Shopify's newer ShopifyQL Reporting after customizing one of the existing reports to look for: Metrics : Refunded payments. Dimensions : Order ID and shipping address details. Filters : Date range, an Order payment status of 'Partially refunded', and Taxes returned greater than 0. Other items may be useful here in the filters and dimensions area. Have a great rest of your week!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tzippy, Thanks for meeting with us earlier! Here's the Excel formula I showed during our call: =COUNTIF($C$2:$C2, C2) > 1 These are the steps I follow when using this: Download the data from Zamp. Select all of the values in the ' transactionId ' column (C). Select Conditional Formatting and click ' New Rule '. Change 'Style' to ' Classic ' In the dropdown right beneath ' Style ', select ' Use a formula to determine which cells to format ' Paste the formula into the text box and click "OK". Add filters to the 'transactionId' column and filter it by color, selecting the cell color used in the conditional formatting. Delete the rows that are highlighted. The above steps will leave a single row per order or transaction within the CSV file and can help make reviewing and reconciling with Zamp more efficient. The attached spreadsheet is an export from NSG's Zamp account and already has the formula and conditional formatting in place, as an example. We'll follow up regarding the other Shopify order scenarios as soon as we can!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Xenia and Katrina, You're welcome, and thanks for confirming these details! Based on this article , Shopify Tax won't calculate taxes for an order if it contains one or more products with a tax rate override. However , it may work if the 'charge tax on this product' box is checked or unchecked. It might be a good idea to try setting these up as a shipping profile or a custom flat-rate option instead. That said, Zamp won't know how to treat these products (line items within an order) as shipping because our Shopify integration uses the order-level 'shipping' amount details to automatically handle shipping taxability; we don't currently have a shipping tax code due to this. If no tax is collected, Zamp will not remit tax to the state DOR, and that portion of the transaction(s) would be excluded from the filing. If tax is collected, we'll categorize it in our filings according to the proper jurisdictions, as most states only require shipping to be grouped with Gross Sales. Setting the taxability of these shipping products manually could work if they are marked as tax-exempt. However, we wouldn't want to apply a tax override (rate) here, because Shopify likely won't collect tax on the order. This should work with Zamp. Ultimately, I recommend checking in with Shopify Plus Support to confirm the best path and behavior when using Shopify Tax. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, Thanks for the response! Of course! Let's use this link to schedule a call tomorrow. Most of my availability is in the afternoon (EST), but I can adjust my schedule if a morning time slot is better. Is there an API limit that is silently enforced? If so what is that limit? There is an API rate limit, but it shouldn't be silently enforced. Our API rate limit was recently increased by our engineering team last week and should now be 500 requests per minute. Also could you explain why it's returning so many taxes records for a single line item? Sure! This happens because a taxes object is returned for each tax jurisdiction (state, county, district, etc.), and this occurs for each line item within a transaction. The jurisdiction "type" (which can vary from one state to the next) is indicated by the jurisdictionDivision property's value within the object. How do I correlate these back together? Do I sum up for a given line item? This is a good question! In a situation like this, it would likely be best to sum the taxDue amount for each lineItemId if there are multiple line items; otherwise, the taxDue value above the taxes array could be used if there's only a single line item. Regarding the $0 tax due returned for this calculation: This happened in this request's instance because Zamp currently treats line items with the general digital products tax code (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS) as tax-exempt in Virginia. A way to determine if this is the case is if the taxDue amount in the Zamp calculation response is 0 and the taxableAmount is also 0. I'm also happy to take a look at additional examples. As I can in the morning, I'll review some API calls sent to Zamp for the test account.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jason and Bobbi, A quick follow-up here! I've attached a few files for your review, along with the tax-due estimate: Per our usual process, the 'shopify_orders_export_1-edited' file is the source file for accounting for the edited and voided orders. The ' Ravella - Shopify Edit and Void Adjustments ' file is the adjustments file imported into Zamp to account for this. The 'RAVELLA Zamp Export' file contains all the transactions used for the underlying estimates and filings within Zamp. A quick note about the differences you'll see in the last file vs. the tax-due estimate: The tax-due estimate has an amount that is very much an estimate, which does not fully account for all of the CA prepayments already made (our engineering team has in-progress improvements to better account for this), and here's the breakdown of those payments: The total tax collected was $18,116.00 . The January 2025 prepayment was $6,552.00 . The February 2025 prepayment was $7,709.00 . The remaining should be closer to $3,855 . For Washington, $183.94 is attributed to WA's B&O (gross receipts) tax, due when filing returns but not collected from customers. The other states' differences are minor and within the % margin for rounding, timely filing discounts, and other state-specific tax logic. We weren't able to account for refunds that caused negative amounts in local jurisdictions in the past, but we are still tracking this and plan to work that into the May 2025 filing for April 2025. Please let me know if you have any questions. We're still working towards getting this data to you earlier in the month, but we have had some unexpected delays in the last few weeks. I'm also happy to hop on a call if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aleli, Thanks for the question and your patience here! Can you share the process on how you exclude sales though Shop? Sure! Our Engineering Team has implemented measures to account for Marketplace sales through Shopify's Shop app. These measures detect these transactions using Shopify App ID values provided in Shopify's Admin API Orders endpoint data. Our Shopify integration can detect this when your store's transactions sync with Zamp. Zamp will then file the sales tax returns associated with the Shopify transactions where Shopify does not collect sales tax as a marketplace. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any additional questions.

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: @technicalsuccess Could you help explain the process of excluding Shop transactions?

author: aleli@warrenjames.org
body: That's good to know! Can you share the process on how you exclude sales though Shop?

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Aleli, Thanks for reaching out! Shopify is acting as the marketplace facilitator for Shop sales. This means that any transactions through Shop, you will not be responsible for collecting and remitting this tax, because Shopify is handling that for those transactions. This is handled appropriately on our end and no further action is required by you. Please let me know if you would like to discuss this further. I'm happy to jump on a call. Feel free to schedule a time that works best for you here . Thanks, Ashley

author: christine@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD I feel like this is more of an AM conversation since it sounds like they're evaluating Shopify Filing (/ they don't seem to realize that it's a separate product that they'd need to purchase and Shopify isn't currently filing/remitting for them). I am happy to hop on a call with them and you. The calendar I included is our joint calendly. We'll use this for reference regarding Shopify vs Zamp filing: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/39340745/documents/8350965793 Hi Aleli, On the current plan you have with Shopify, Shopify is not remitting or filing the sales tax returns for you. We are happy to hop on a call to discuss further. You can schedule a time on our calendar here . Thanks,

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nicole, You're welcome; thanks for reaching out! Christine let me know that you called, but I was on a call at that time. I'll answer your questions below, and I'm happy to hop on a call sometime if that would be helpful. What I thought was happening is that we overpaid sales tax at the beginning so this was the credits being applied. Is this correct? Yes—this is correct! There were duplicate transactions between a manual CSV import and a QuickBooks Online integration. If so, why are we not taking the full credit for the amount owed each period? Or is it something different? The plan we discussed previously (correct me if I'm wrong, Sadh) is that we would adjust for 10% of the overpaid sales tax each month to prevent sudden changes in Gross Sales and Tax Due amounts from month to month. Another reason here is that some states don't have a tax due amount when we're filing or a filing is not due. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Paul, Great question; thanks for working with us here! As a follow up, what is the cadence of these returns? Sure! Our typical timeline and process (including deadlines) are: We'll send out a request for the CSV data between the 1st and 3rd of the month. We aim to have all CSV sales data by the 6th of each month. We aim to approve all sales tax returns by the 10th of each month (by clicking a button or automatically releasing them by the noted date in our tax-due estimate email). We can be somewhat flexible with the above, especially if there are questions or concerns. Our focus is ensuring timely filing, maximizing timely filing discounts across various states, and efficiency within our teams. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Liz, Thanks for sharing this with us! We'll need to investigate further, but we'll likely want to disconnect the current Amazon integration with Zamp because we have that sales data syncing separately. If the Amazon data flows into Shopify, we won't need the Amazon connection, as Zamp will handle the transactions from either source. Within Zamp, we'll always view transactions from Amazon (either the direct integration or Shopify) as $0 tax to ensure that tax is not remitted twice because Amazon collects and remits as a marketplace facilitator. The good news is that this won't cause any tax duplication but may cause duplicate amounts within Pacagen's Gross Sales amounts. However, we can quickly help sort that out. A few questions: 1) Do we know when this change was made to bring Amazon transactions into Shopify? Was it effective on 4/8/2025? 2) Was this change applied to historical (before X date) data in any way? 3) Could you or the team share examples of Shopify Order IDs synced to Shopify from Amazon? I've found a few, but I'd like to be sure. The examples I found are: #37965 #37961 #37911

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ching, Thanks for the response here; we're happy to help. As requested, we've held Joolca's filings until we have your approval to proceed. Just so you know, we will need to hear back with approval to file by the end of the day (EST) on Friday, April 11th, 2025 , for Zamp to be able to process your filings timely this month. A few states, such as Maine (with a 4/15 due date) and Michigan (for the timely filing discount), have earlier due dates or timelines. I've attached two XLSX files containing the transaction data Zamp used to build these tax-due estimates. Each file includes a sheet showing the tax total per state and overall. The combined tax total across all monthly and quarterly states with due dates this month is $62,015.96 . It's important to note that the Washington March 2025 filing and estimate also include a WA B&O tax (gross receipts tax) filed with the sales tax return; this amount is $342.40 . In addition to the above, Zamp's tax-due estimates have various state-specific logic in place for handling time zones, rounding, and timely filing discounts; we share some details about this here (also here ). I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, Great; we'll look forward to speaking with you tomorrow! What report am I supposed to be looking at? and what report do you use? This is a tricky question to answer, but generally, the Shopify US Taxes report you shared is the better report to start with. That being said, there will almost always be some differences (usually 1-2% but under 5%) between Shopify and Zamp; we share more information about that in this article . The differences are usually caused by rounding, timely filing discounts, or differences in time zone handling (Zamp adjusts for each state's specific time zone). Zamp doesn't use a Shopify Report to build our filings and ingest sales data because we use the data provided by Shopify's API. If we need to reference something in Shopify for a tax-related report, we will generally look at the US Taxes Report. When did you loose access to the Shopify store? Thanks for the access code! I just sent a request over. Unfortunately, we're unsure when the access was lost because Shopify hasn't shown us the date. This is an access that can auto-expire after 90-days. We've started some conversations with our engineering team to find ways to prevent this from happening. The good news is that this only affects our ability to view your Shopify store and doesn't affect Zamp syncing your sales data for filing purposes. I'm still reviewing the situation here but should have more detail before our call tomorrow.

Could you please share an export or screenshot of this report? 2) Could you also please share a couple of amounts associated with the states with the highest differences? 3) When you have a moment, could you please share Kings Loot's Collaborator request codes with us for the for-a-kings-loot and kingslootwholesale Shopify stores? author: christine@zamp.com
body: Hi Patrick, Thank you for your patience, while I connected with our filing team regarding the $0 returns. They confirmed that if you had no sales after the February 2025 returns were filed, then you can contact the states in which you are filing monthly returns and close out the accounts as of 2/28. On the spreadsheet you provided, there were 26 states you said were $0 filings and you were going to close out. Out of these 26, all of the states were monthly except for New Jersey. We are showing that New Jersey has a quarterly filing. We recommend filing one last return here for the quarter, and then you can contact the state to close out the sales tax account. Our team also confirmed that we can mark New York as the final return. In order to close out the account for New York, you'll still need to contact the state after the final return has been filed. Regarding the payment for the Zamp services, if you prefer to wire transfer you can do this in one transaction. Currently, there are 2 invoices due for the amount of $4,032.22 so the total payment that we need you to wire is $8,064.44. Attached are the wire instructions. Please reach out if I can be of further assistance. Thanks, Christine

author: patrick@nisolo.com
body:
Christine, Chris, & Team,

Good morning and happy Monday! I am following up with a few important updates for Zamp related to the tax filings for March transactions. Here are important updates: Now that I understand that Zamp cannot close states for Nisolo, I've updated the "Actions Needed by Zamp" direction by state in column D of the attached spreadsheet, titled "4.7.25 Update to 4.2.25 Copy March Transactions Zamp Nisolo Follow Up Direction By State" and the updates can be seen on the "2.0 Revised…" tab. There are 10 states that we need for Zamp to take action on. These 10 states are listed at the top of the "2.0 Revised…" tab in the spreadsheet. Reuben & I will focus on closing all of the others in green without Zamp support given Zamp cannot help close the states. For the 5 states that need past taxes paid for, refer to the tab "Collected Tax Dates & Ranges" for the total amount owed in each state. Also, note that the "Order Data" requested by Chris for each state for the relevant time ranges where we found past collected tax have all been attached to this email as hard copies, which show the orders within each individual state. Also attached to this email is a spreadsheet that shows all historical sales and taxes collected by month by year for each state (this is the sales data, not the individual orders) I tried to highlight on each tab in teal any states where there was unpaid, collected tax, and I do not think you'll need this spreadsheet. However, note that the "Prior tax to be paid" in column B on the "Collected Tax Dates & Ranges" tab of the "4.7.25 Update…" spreadsheet corresponds with the data from the "Shopify Sales by Month 2019 by Shipping Region sales_2019-01-01_2019-12-31 (1)" spreadsheet. This data in Column B is what we want to make sure gets paid by state in the March transaction filings. Note, there is a discrepancy between the totals in that spreadsheet vs. what you would find in each individual state (order data) spreadsheets, I believe bc one set of tax is Net of Returns and the other is Gross of Returns. For further clarity on the discrepancy, please note the following, which is also outlined on the ""Collected Tax Dates & Ranges" tab: Even though the date range used is the exact same, there is a discrepancy in total tax owed (Ex Nevada $12K vs. $18K) in the individual state spreadsheet data of "Orders" (column E or see hardcopy) vs. the (Column D or hardcopy) "Shopify Sales by Month 2019 by Shipping Region sales_2019-01-01_2019-12-31 (1)" file, we believe because Column E "Orders" is GROSS of returns but the other Column D is Net of returns. Nisolo has had around a 25-30% Return rate historically. Again, the spreadsheet hosting only the individual state's info (column E or in hardcopy) is GROSS of returns, and returns have not been taken out, and therefore tax is higher. Again, the "Shopify Sales by Month" spreadsheet (Column D or hardcopy) is Net sales with tax NET of returns, and therefore is the more accurate reading of tax owed that needs to be paid. Chris, once you have a chance to review this material, please let me know if you have any questions or if this gives you all that you need for Zamp to ensure the past collected tax gets filed on time for March transactions so that we can pay it and close the states on time. Thank you! Patrick

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rachel, Thanks for sending the file over and for these great questions! On the Shopify transactions, can you please clarify how that works with Shopify now remitting some of the taxes for us? It looks like they may not be remitting all of it? Sure! To our understanding, Shopify is now remitting any taxes collected through the 'SHOP' channel, which is tied into a specific payment method and marketplace via the Shop app (I believe this is an Android and iPhone app). They won't remit taxes collected from an order placed on BetterWild's website. This means that shop payments or channel orders can still come through with tax that BetterWild would need to remit via Zamp's filings. A way to see this could be using this Shopify report and adding a filter for 'Filed' under 'Filed by channel' like this: How are you handling those transactions? Our Engineering Team has already implemented measures to account for Marketplace sales through Shopify Shop. You will not be remitting taxes that Shopify has already remitted. Our Shopify integration can detect this when your store's transactions sync with Zamp. Zamp will then file the sales tax returns associated with the other transactions. I hope this helps!

body: See attached for the CSV file for non-Shopify transactions. On the Shopify transactions, can you please clarify how that works with Shopify now remitting some of the taxes for us? It looks like they may not be remitting all of it? How are you handling those transactions? Thanks, Rachel

body: Hi Henry, Thanks again for your time today and your partnership! Regarding the partial refunds and manually edited orders: Starting this month (or soon), for the filings that will be processed in June, we discussed using a CSV template (imported into Google Sheets) that follows Zamp's import template (attached). We will share how to prepare that file in this article . For the April 2025 transactions, I'll run our "forced" Shopify reconciliation script. Regarding editing orders within Loop instead of Shopify: This change would likely involve multiple pieces, and I hope the information below is helpful. Here are some Loop resources that I found about this, and it may be worth triple-checking for best practices from the Loop Support Team: Create a Return for a Customer Return Policy Settings Variant Exchange Different Priced Exchanges Advanced Exchanges Regarding outstanding state-specific items: I've also contacted Amelia about the outstanding items for any remaining states. While researching it a bit, I found that Amelia shared these outstanding items on 4/8/25 at 9:53 AM EST and followed up on 4/28/25 at 12:41 PM EST; the subject of that email was ' Re: Onboarding Call Follow up with Zamp '. I'm sharing this if it helps find the email, but Amelia will follow up as soon as possible. Here's what Amelia shared. I recommend directing any registration/account/state questions about this to Amelia or onboarding@zamp.com (if you have questions before Amelia reaches out). Great! Here is the list of states, contact details, and what we need to be able to file. Missouri - We still need to get the responsible party date of birth and ssn/itin of the person used at the time of registering in Missouri. 573-751-5860 North Carolina- Since there is no apparent registration id number outside of the SST number, you will need to call the state so they can advise steps needed - is the account is still open, next steps based on your current status, etc. You can ask them what is required by you to start filing online via non-SST or if a new registration is needed. NC contact number- 877-252-3052 Nevada- Since the login provided is not the master account login, you will need to call the state and they can advise/update the access to ensure your login is set as an administrator. Nevada contact number - 866-962-3707 Please let me know if you need any clarifications or have any questions on this. Please let me know if you or your team have any questions about the Loop Discount or the other items we discussed. We are aiming to have a tax-due estimate sent your way by Monday or Tuesday next week, after adjusting for the Shopify variances. Have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes: Causes of the differences: They don't have the loop discount turned on. They manually edit orders if a customer calls or emails in, but they don't do that in Loop; it's within Shopify. They sometimes issue partial refunds for issues, discounts, promos, leaving reviews, etc., which ties into Shopify's limitations around partial refunds, which do not account for tax. They already track order edits and partial refunds internally, and can ask the team to enter that into a CSV or in a way that it can be put into a CSV (A Google Sheet most likely.) Henry will: Ask about: loop discount editing orders in Loop This is a process change that will take some time. Tracking partial refunds. The above items will likely start this month for filing in June. For the April 2025 filing, we'll use the Shopify forced reconciliation script. My action items: Ask Amelia to give Henry an update and ask for any action items. Send the CSV article and template, for order edit and partial refunds to be shared with Zamp (for May and onward, until Zamp engineering has something in place and/or the Mod Lighting Team can edit orders in Loop.

body: Hi Jessica, One more follow-up as we head into the weekend! Aside from the two previously missing Shopify transactions, we found that there were some slight variances between Zamp's tax collected and Shopify's due to the manual workaround method we used here. Outside of the above, the difference was caused by the two missing transactions and what appears to be some rounding in Shopify's US tax reporting. Would you have time to discuss this and the plan to resolve it as we move forward next week?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, You're welcome! Regarding the variance between Shopify and Zamp: We're still reviewing some Shopify reports, such as the Q1 2025 Texas Transactions Report , to determine why this difference exists. Part of what we've discovered happened here is that when we used the manual workaround method to import your Shopify data, the two transactions below were missed. CE1005X CE1004X We're still working through comparing the tax amounts between transactions in Zamp and transactions in Shopify to find the remaining difference. This is a piece that should be confirmed by tomorrow. This situation is something that we will help correct and ensure doesn't happen again in the future. If you have some time sometime soon, we'd be happy to hop on a call to talk about this and the path to resolving it. Regarding the Eventbrite transactions: This part of the import process was missed, and we've already taken steps to ensure it doesn't happen again, including adding additional reminders on our end. The good news here is that Eventbrite, as a marketplace , remits the taxes it collects to the state of Texas and other states listed in their article here . This means that while we do still want to import these transactions and report the gross sales to TX , your business doesn't need to remit the tax (Zamp includes this as a 'Marketplace Facilitator deduction' on filings.) When we create these kinds of transactions in Zamp, we do so with $0 tax collected to ensure Dandy Lion doesn't pay the tax twice. Regarding the Amazon transactions: I've found that Amazon transactions did not sync over to Zamp, but I've been unable to find any errors associated with this issue. I'm checking in with Amelia about a couple of items here in the morning. We can take an approach of having our team manually download these transactions each month to ensure they are accounted for as Marketplace Facilitator transactions, similar to Eventbrite. For Amazon and Eventbrite transactions, we can include them in a future filing, such as the Q2 2025 tax filing. We're also happy to discuss this on a call if you'd prefer. We're here to help resolve this and ensure Dandy Lion is compliant; fix these data situations.

I am looking forward to receiving your reply regarding the discrepancy between the Shopify report and Zamp's calculations, as well as the investigation into the Eventbrite and Amazon sales. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, Thanks for the response and the direct feedback. We understand where you're coming from with this and will be sure to improve. We're also happy to hop on a call to discuss this, after we've confirmed what happened. The reason this was a one-time exception and the cause of the difference is related to the email Amelia sent out a bit ago regarding your Shopify store's Shopify subscription and recent limitations implemented by Shopify. The Shopify changes caused Zamp to be unable to import all of your Shopify transactions, so we imported them manually using a workaround. I'm re-investigating the differences between the Shopify report and Zamp; I am also investigating what happened with the Eventbrite sales and Amazon sales. Please note that Amazon and Eventbrite both collect and remit (file) sales taxes in Texas and many other states as a Marketplace Facilitator. Meaning—those taxes are already paid to the state, and Dandy Lion LLC won't need to pay those taxes to the state, but each state (including TX) has reporting requirements for sellers. We share more information in this guide . I'll have an update for you about this today!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Carol, Thanks for the response! Why would we need to know zipcode as these are exempt transactions? Zamp needs the zip code because our system is designed to bucket all transactions into specific local jurisdictions within a US state. (Without it, we are unable to import the transaction data.) That process happens by having either of the below combinations of shipping address data. The shipping city and state. The shipping zip code. Additionally, for some US state sales tax filings, the state Department of Revenue(s) requires a breakdown of wholesale transactions by the local jurisdiction in addition to the state-level tax-exempt amount.

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: Hey Dante, Thanks for your patience. The small difference between your Shopify and Zamp tax reports comes from two main factors: Rounding differences in calculations and per state rules Time zone settings (your Shopify store uses EST, while Zamp uses each state capital's time zone for remittance) Good news! We've just launched a feature that lets you view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. To better compare Zamp transactions to your Shopify store's EST setting, check your March 2025 report in US/Eastern time: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern For more details, see our article: " Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices " Let me know if this helps clarify things!

author: carie@zamp.com
body: Hi @lucas - great draft! I made a few minor changes below. I went ahead and bolded the changes so you could easily see them but please unbold before sending! Also, please confirm that my comments are correct. ;) I also included a more simplified version below, which might be a good alternative but either way! —- Hey Dante, Thanks for your patience here. The slight difference between the reports is primarily due to rounding (related to calculations and state rules) and time zones. Shopify uses a standard time zone across all orders, while Zamp assigns each order to the timezone of the state capital where it's remitted . We explain this in more detail in our article: "Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices" . In the case of your Shopify store, it is set to EST timezone. We recently launched a new feature allowing you to view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. Take a look at how your March-2025 report would appear in US/Eastern: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern . This should further align with the timezone settings in your Shopify store and the transactions associated with March 2025. Let me know if exploring this feature helps clarify things! — Hey Dante, Thanks for your patience. The small difference between your Shopify and Zamp tax reports comes from two main factors: Rounding differences in calculations and per state rules Time zone settings (your Shopify store uses EST, while Zamp uses each state capital's time zone for remittance) Good news! We've just launched a feature that lets you view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. To better compare Zamp transactions to your Shopify store's EST setting, check your March 2025 report in US/Eastern time: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern For more details, see our article: " Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices " Let me know if this helps clarify things!

author: landrade@zamp.com
body:
Hey, @carie I'd like your help here. I'd like assistance in formulating a response to the customer regarding the discrepancy they've observed between their filing and the Shopify report. The difference is less than 1%, and this can largely be attributed to rounding and time zones. I’ve also identified that the customer uses the Order Editing app, which will necessitate further investigation on our part. To ensure appropriate handling of this matter, I intend to focus my initial response on the rounding/timezone issue, deferring discussion regarding the third-party app until an alignment with Chris. Below is the message I intend to send. "Hey Dante,
Thanks for your patience here. The slight difference between the reports is primarily due to rounding (related to calculations and state rules) and time zones. Shopify uses a standard time zone across all orders, while Zamp assigns each order to the timezone of the state capital where it's shipped – this reflects how states expect sales tax reports to be formatted. We explain this in more detail in our article: "Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices" . We recently launched a new feature allowing you to view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. Take a look at how your March/2025 report would appear in US/Eastern: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern Let me know if exploring this feature helps clarify things!"

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: Overall It looks like variances in this case are caused by a combination of rounding, time zone, and order editing. Both reports (US Sales Tax and Zamp Tax Collected) match, in about 80% of the cases, when using the same timezone. The customer can check this with the new 'timezone' feature in the Tax Collected report and the Transactions page in our product. Below is the comparison ( https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?timezone=US/Eastern ) There are also a couple of orders with different tax values collected, some of which were edited via the Order Editing third-party app ( https://admin.shopify.com/store/officialkittyfountain/orders/6146588934364?link_source=search ), and some were simply not collected ( https://admin.shopify.com/store/officialkittyfountain/orders/6142193369308?link_source=search ). I also found that there is no tax collected in DC in US Sales Tax Report Here is the summary table with all my findings: state total_tax_transactions total_tax_us_tax_report total_tax_missing_from us_tax_report total_tax_order_editing_diff final_abs_diff final_pct_diff AK 18.83 17.57 1.26 0 0.04 0.21% AR 341.68 341.68 0 0 0 0.00% AZ 1202.72 1211.15 -8.43 0 0.03 0.00% CA 16149.81 16048.65 5.41 94.73 1.06 0.01% CO 1549.01 1539.77 0 11.28 -2.08 -0.13% DC 77.06 77.06 0 -77.06 -100.00% FL 7976.74 7948.18 0 25.72 2.88 0.04% GA 1257.4 1241.8 6.8 12.4 -3.6 -0.29% IL 2257.31 2241.19 0 15.53 0.57 0.03% MD 1973.54 1958.63 0 14.91 -0.01 0.00% NC 3946.51 3933.69 0 11.59 1.21 0.03% NJ 3025.33 3001.81 0 22.87 0.63 0.02% NV 1340.48 1332.11 2.01 6.68 -0.29 -0.02% PA 5635.83 5609.13 0 25.22 1.48 0.03% RI 161.29 160.74 0 0.55 -0.05 -0.03% VA 1068.98 1064.79 0 3.13 1.07 0.10% VT 569.99 553.39 0 16.6 0 0.00% WA 5812.99 5767.52 2.48 42.14 0.88 0.02% WV 261.02 261.02 0 0 0 0.00% TOTAL 54626.52 54232.82 86.59 303.35 -73.24 -0.13% US Sales Tax Report vs. Zamp Transactions Overall, the report matches, especially when using the same timezone, but below is a comparison between the two, each one using their timezone settings. We can see that the differences are small, less than 1% in most cases, and 0.6% in the overall scenario. It would also be important to get the cause of the variances between transactions, which is equal to the Tax Collected report. and the filing report state total_tax_transactions total_tax_us_tax_report abs_diff pct_diff AK 18.83 17.57 1.3 6.9% AR 341.68 341.68 0 0.0% AZ 1202.72 1211.15 -8.4 -0.7% CA 16149.81 16048.65 101.2 0.6% CO 1549.01 1539.77 9.2 0.6% DC 77.06 0 77.06 100% FL 7976.74 7948.18 28.6 0.4% GA 1257.4 1241.8 15.6 1.2% IL 2257.31 2241.19 16.1 0.7% MD 1973.54 1958.63 14.9 0.8% NC 3946.51 3933.69 12.8 0.3% NJ 3025.33 3001.81 23.5 0.8% NV 1340.48 1332.11 8.4 0.6% PA 5635.83 5609.13 26.7 0.5% RI 161.29 160.74 0.5 0.3% VA 1068.98 1064.79 4.2 0.4% VT 569.99 553.39 16.6 2.9% WA 5812.99 5767.52 45.5 0.8% WV 261.02 261.02 0 0.0% TOTAL 54626.52 54232.82 316.7 0.6% Missing Transactions I found 2056 orders missing from the US Sales Tax Report, and the majority of them are due to time zone differences settings Below is a state-grouped tax report of these missing transactions state total_tax AK 1.26 AR 0 AZ -8.43 CA 5.41 CO 0 DC 77.06 FL 0 GA 6.8 IL 0 MD 0 NC 0 NJ 0 NV 2.01 PA 0 RI 0 VA 0 VT 0 WA 2.48 WV 0 Order Editing Therefore, the majority variances can be explained by timezone differences; some of them are due to other reasons, like the Order Editing third-party app. Below is a state summary of the differences between how much Zamp Transactions got as tax collected and the US Sales Tax report state_abbreviation tax_diff CA 94.73 CO 11.28 FL 25.72 GA 12.4 IL 15.53 MD 14.91 NC 11.59 NJ 22.87 NV 6.68 PA 25.22 RI 0.55 VA 3.13 VT 16.6 WA 42.14 Takeaways The variances in this case are small, less than 1% Rounding and time zone can explain most of the cases, and the new 'timezone' feature can help to evidence it Tax Collected report and Filing report are different, which I believe is due to rounding and/or state tax rules. They use Order Editing third-party app, so we should map this customer and add an offset import step to the import workflow, such as Ghost Golf.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rodger and Team, Thanks so much for your patience and understanding here. A colleague and I investigated this situation and found the following details; please let us know if you have any questions. Regarding the more minor differences: Zamp's tax-due estimate aligns closely with Shopify's US Sales Tax report when adjusting for time zones, timely filing discounts, state-specific rounding, etc; these variances are usually below 5%. The amounts in this Shopify US Sales Tax Report differ from the original list for various states. If you used this Report previously, it's possible it wasn't yet up-to-date, as I'm unsure how often these reports update in Shopify. In general, the differences noted here are mainly due to Zamp's adjustments to file based on each state's specific time zone, while Shopify uses a single time zone. In our article here , we discuss more of the differences noted above and other common differences between Zamp and Shopify. When I filter the Shopify US Sales Tax Report for the states filed monthly and then separately for the states filed quarterly while expanding the date range and summing the tax totals, it is within $78 of Zamp's estimate. Regarding Texas: The above includes Texas because the Shopify US Sales Tax report for TX and an example of the time zone differences here is the order noted below. When adjusting for the CST time zone, Order ID OB48264 in Zamp is reported as 3/1/25, but in Shopify, it's listed with a date of 2/28/25. The Shopify US Sales Tax report shows $1,075.59 in tax collected, which is $63.84 less than Zamp's total, which was recently updated to 1,139.43 (or 5.94%). We couldn't find any missing or extra transactions, and the tax amounts aligned with Shopify. I've also attached an export of the transactions Zamp is using to determine the tax due. I hope this is helpful to you. Please let us know if you have any questions. We'll need to move the filings along into the process by the end of the day tomorrow, April 15th, 2025 , to file by the state's due dates and avoid any penalties and interest. Do you approve of proceeding with One Bed's filings this month?
