author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rodger, Thanks for the response and for sharing these details! Regarding California: Yes—this is happening because Zamp's understanding per One Bed's CA sales tax registration is that the filing frequency is what we call 'Quarterly Prepay,' which aligns with CA's pay monthly and file quarterly filing frequency. This does equal the monthly sales tax due in most scenarios, and we hope to improve our tax-due estimates in the future. We'll triple-check this and share that confirmation in our follow-up. Regarding the large difference you noted for Texas: This is interesting to hear. I have a few questions to help us understand why there is such a difference and the potential causes. 1) Does One Bed use third-party apps for returns/exchanges, such as Loop? 2) Does One Bed use third-party apps to allow customers to edit their orders after placing them? Is that done manually by the One Bed Team or at all? 3) Could you please confirm by sharing a screenshot or an export of the Shopify Report that you're reviewing and comparing against Zamp? 4) When you have a moment, could you please share One Bed's Collaborator request code with us? This will allow us to request access to your Shopify store again because that access expired automatically according to Shopify's policy. This should be under Settings —> Users —> Security.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello, Chloe and Camille, Thanks once again for your patience while we investigated the various situations here. Regarding California: This Fortunate One difference is similar to Hello Molly. This difference happens because Fortunate One makes monthly prepayments to CA and a quarterly filing (a quarterly prepay filing frequency). Here's a breakdown of this for Fortunate One: The January 2025 prepayment was $2,964.38 . The February 2025 prepayment was $4,161.28 . Total prepayments: $7,125.66 . Remaining tax-due estimate: $7,030.88 Combined total: $14,156.54 . Regarding the remaining states brought up here: The following states have different filing frequencies that are either annual or a non-standard quarter: Indiana has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. Nebraska has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. New York has a quarterly filing frequency, but this is within the fiscal quarter date range , so the next return is the NY Q1 2025 return, due in June 2025. Texas: To our understanding, Fortunate One is not currently registered for a sales tax permit or account in Texas. It's possible that the tax was accidentally collected within Shopify if someone accidentally turned it on previously. Still, it does not appear to be enabled currently, as we do not see any tax collection in TX. We'd recommend refunding the tax to the customer if tax were accidentally collected. This can happen when tax is collected on an order, and the address is later changed. If you know the Order ID associated with that order, we can investigate it further within Zamp. We've seen this happen with other companies we work with ( this Shopify community thread has some details), but we do not currently know a solution. We'd recommend that you check with Shopify support about the options here. A follow-up question: Considering the details noted above, do you know if we have your approval to proceed with Fortunate One's filings this month? Once you're ready for us to file, you can also click the blue ' Review & approve filings ' button. Otherwise and if we don't hear back about this, we'll resume filing by Thursday, April 10th, 2025 , to ensure timely filings. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: California This difference is due to quarterly prepay. January 2025 prepayment: $2,964.38 February 2025 prepayment: $4,161.28 Total: $7,125.66 Remaining: $7,030.88 We also see a total of $14k. Additional states: Indiana has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. Nebraska has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. New York is quarterly with a fiscal quarter date range, so the next return is the NY Q1 2025 return, which is due in June 2025. Texas—On Zamp's side, Texas was not included because we understand that Fortunate One is not registered to collect sales taxes in Texas. This can happen with Shopify orders if the address is changed after the order is placed or if tax collection was accidentally turned on for TX at some point.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Kevin, You're welcome! For the states where we have sales tax, can you please confirm that those states tax sales of food products? Of course! So that you know, the taxability of food will vary from state to state and from one product category (type/tax code) to another. To our understanding, the 'Nutrition Bars' category would be taxed in all those states except for those noted below. Washington D.C. —This is a small amount, and it could be leftover from the various product category changes you have been working on. Vermont —This is a small amount that could be related to the items noted for DC (above). Washington —The tax estimate here is mainly due to WA's Business & Occupation tax , a gross receipts tax not collected from customers but due when filing a sales tax return; the remainder could be similar to the two states noted above. The WA B&O tax amount is $461.35. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Confirmed: the difference here is due to Magic Math /Grossing Down, which is happening due to under-collecting sales tax. VA notice: System failed to calculate 1 transaction(s) totaling $118.91, so they were excluded. One transaction was missing: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clr6g73v20006a8lippj6yh3a/transactions?date=2025-03-01%7E2025-03-31&shipToState=VA&limit=100 . It's this transaction: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clr6g73v20006a8lippj6yh3a/transactions/cm9bh5suy000ljo04j8snqfv8?timezone=US/Local&shipToState=VA&date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31 . These NC transactions had the right amount of tax collected: 6538249 - 6594902 The rest of them had under collection that appeared to include only the state rate of 4.75%. Sean will check with the business owner to see if they want to pay the under-collected tax out of pocket; he'll follow up to let us know. I'm providing Sean with the under-collected NC Transactions so that he can contact their rep at GameFound (their sales platform) to see what can be done about this moving forward.

We still have a few items to investigate and test, but it is best to schedule a call sometime next week to discuss this further. I hope that you have a great weekend!

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: @chris I'm working on it and want to share my findings and thoughts. There is no difference between the customer file and Zamp transactions. I believe the variance is related to the magic math. CSVs comparison There is no difference in the tax total, subtotal, and transaction total between the customer CSV file and the transactions in Zamp. I noticed some inconsistencies in some shipping states. When comparing either CustomerSubLocationIsoCode or ShippingSubLocationIsoCode from the customer file to the shiptoState from Zamp, a few of them don't match. However, they have the same zip code in both files, so I believe we're fine in terms of reporting. Magic Math When checking the variance review export and filtering by sectionName equal to 'General State' (the filing section where the gross sales were reduced), we see the exact amount used to file in the taxableAmount (NC = 2987.37) Question: Why was the gross sales amount reduced, but the tax due/ collected remains the same?

body: Hi Chris, Comparing the returns filed with the spreadsheet I sent and trying to make sense of it. For example, when I filter the March CSV I sent to North Carolina and look at the column sums, there's 3550 collected for product, 730 for shipping, and 210.91 for taxes. When I look at the North Carolina return filed, it shows 2,987.37 gross receipts. I would have expected a higher number derived from the preceding numbers. Can you explain how this works out?

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Nick, So the problem with Gamefound is that transactions are not dated and changes are not logged. So there's no way to retroactively find the date of the transaction being finalized. So what I'm doing is running the gamefound report on the last day of the month. When I run the one for April, it will also include everything for March. Which means I'll have to reverse out all the March activity from the April report based on what I recognize in March before I send it to you. It's a pretty big hassle, but BackerKit worked the same way! So I think I would just date everything for the last day of the month, unless you see a reason to do it differently.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Belva, Thanks for the response!! OK, great! We will get the WV invoice 11490 voided, as that will be faster on our end (instead of waiting for a delete request), and that should allow me to send you the updated amounts tonight. Regarding Washington: The difference here is due to WA's B&O tax . The B&O Retailing tax is $870.21 for Q1 2025, including the possible duplicate invoice 11328. Once we remove invoice 11328, the B&O tax amount will decrease because it is a gross receipts tax calculated by multiplying the Gross Sales by 0.471%. After removing this duplicate invoice, a rough estimate shows that the B&O tax should be about $465.41 , and the overall tax should be closer to an estimate of $10,823.47. Considering the above, should we void or delete WA invoice 11328?

I believe I found the issue, and it appears that this may be related to two deleted invoices as that no longer exist in QuickBooks Online: For West Virginia , we have an invoice 11490 in Zamp that no longer appears in QBO with a tax amount of $193.11. For Washington , we have invoice 11328 in Zamp that no longer appears in QBO. Its tax amount is $7,742.08, and it appears to be a duplicate of invoice 11444 . I've attached an XLSX file showing the exports from Zamp and their comparisons to see if the invoice number exists in the QBO export and if there are any differences in the tax collected. The tax collected amounts match, within reason for rounding, but two Zamp invoices appear "extra." Do you think we should ask our engineering team to proceed with deleting invoices 11490 and 11328?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Aman, Ian, and Team, I just wanted to follow up quickly! Regarding the tax-due estimate: The tax-due estimate sent a little while ago can be ignored. There was a mistake in sending it, but we've resolved the root cause. We're working on regenerating the estimate using the March 2025 filing periods, and we appreciate your patience. Regarding your questions: what is the total amount, and when is the latest we can file? We'll send you an updated total amount in the next few minutes. The total is listed at the bottom of the email following ' Estimated sales tax this month: ' The latest we can wait to file this month (as an exception and due to our partnership) is next Thursday, 4/10/2025. Also do you still need / collect wholesale information to reduce the liability? Yes, we do need Wholesale transactions from you if those don't occur through Shopify. If your customers are marked as tax-exempt in Shopify, we'll capture that as well. Please note that, generally, wholesale/resale transactions won't reduce the liability here because sales tax is not collected on them. If tax was collected on a transaction and later refunded due to being wholesale or resale, please let us know and share the Order ID/number; we can help update that within Zamp. We value your partnership and thank you for your understanding. Please feel free to contact us with any questions.

body: Hey Chris, No worries you've been plenty patient with us, so likewise! Honestly, I think that's the perfect way to back into it. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, Thanks! I hope you're also doing well and appreciate your patience! We're both pretty busy, and I'm glad we are on the same page. We appreciate your patience while we worked through some technical hiccups (unrelated to this situation) yesterday and today. This makes sense to me, and after digging into QuickBooks Online's various articles and forums further, I'm seeing what you're saying and found the pattern where it appears currency conversions don't always work with foreign amounts, etc. Can we include the 'Exchange Rate' available in this custom QBO Report export and utilize that as a temporary workaround for part of the process? Our upcoming significant QBO integration release will help resolve much of this and increase accuracy. I've attached a file as an example. The exchange rate is usually 1.34 or 1.35 in this file. We would do this after filtering out non-US 'Bill To' addresses. I'm still happy to have a call to discuss this or any filing/data/QBO-related questions you might have. I'll be around until ~8:00 PM EST today, and have quite a bit of availability next week.

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body:
Hi Chris,

I hope you're doing well! Thanks for your patience.

To answer your questions: 1) We do have a small batch of US customers who actually do request to be billed in CAD. Oftentimes it has to do with three reasons: (1) they have a Canadian CPA employee, or (2) they hold some CAD for FX hedging. Unfortunately, those ones won't have a USD amount inherently - the two possible solutions here would just be to: Accept that the foreign amount is in CAD but just say it's in USD for nexus analysis - it's such a small batch of customers with small amounts that if that's the reason we hit nexus we were going to hit nexus next month Find an average FX rate to convert them at in order to get to the final amount 2) The foreign amount in Quickbooks is the amount in the invoice currency (so typically a US customer's foreign amount will be in USD). Now here's the issue - the tax amount and the net amount are ALWAYS in CAD in Quickbooks and we haven't identified a field that shows those amounts in the invoice currency.

Let me know if you wanna hop on a call to find a workaround or discuss any of this as tomorrow we can definitely make some time!

Cheers,

Bill

body: Hi Bill, Thanks once again for your patience here! I've confirmed we have access to LumiQ's QBO account, and I've created a Zamp Sales Tax custom report . I've asked our engineering team to remove all automatically synced transactions that use the shipping address, and the team I'm part of will manually import this data for now. A couple of quick questions here: 1) I found some invoices with a 'CAD' currency that have billing addresses within the US. Should we ignore those invoices, or is there a way (that you know of) to export them in USD from QuickBooks Online (QBO)? 2) How are the foreign amount, tax, and net amounts configured within QBO? Which one should be the USD amount? I read through this QBO support forum thread , which makes sense. So, the invoices with a CAD currency and amount/foreign amounts that are the same may have been issued in CAD. My goal here is to ensure an accurate and scalable solution in the long term for filing LumiQ's US state sales tax returns accurately. We're almost there! We can also schedule a quick call using this link if you'd prefer to discuss that way!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jason, Thanks for the input here; I understand. Yes, I'm positive it's related to negative amounts in specific jurisdictions because the negative amounts line up with the differences. This scenario can happen anytime the two conditions below are met, and my understanding is that Zamp has behaved this way the whole time (with slight adjustments over the last year, possibly.) In these cases, an item is purchased in one month (January) and returned the following month (February, still within a 14-day or 30-day window). There aren't any other sales to that specific jurisdiction in the following month to fully cover the refund, or there are no sales to that particular jurisdiction. On our side, the transaction export is used to build the filing team's summary totals, but that summary is different; it's a state-specific sales tax internal report used to file the returns. I'm pulling data from the same source. This could also be occurring more often because we're adjusting for edited orders, voided transactions, and items that cause refunds across multiple jurisdictions. These are the Order IDs causing the negative amounts in local jurisdictions: #23832930 #23828180 #23837460 #23830180 #23834760 #23832720 #23836330 #23833050 #23822770 #23821470 #23830810 REF-6115898589436 #23835120 #23832520 #23837570 I hope this helps!

author: jason@shopravella.com
body: Hi Chris, Yes I'm surprised we had these come up again. I thought it would be just from January because of the higher amount of returns from December orders, combined with a seasonal drop off into January. We're definitely sure it's related to the negative amounts for specific jurisdictions right? Because I don't recall this happening at all last year, but now we've had 2 months with this issue. It seems either our transaction list export is missing something, or the filing team's calculation is being done differently this year. Form what I remember last year, the excel transaction list was usually more of an 'export' of the filing team's summary -- and so the numbers would generally match since it was from the same 'source'. Now it seems our transaction export and the filing team's summary totals are from a slightly different 'source', but with the 2 sources. Thanks, Jason

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jason, You're welcome! I hope you had a good weekend! After completing the investigation, I've found that all variances where the estimated tax due variance amount is above 5% are related to refunds causing negative amounts in local jurisdictions within a state. This is the primary cause for CA, CO, GA, and TN. This means that some refunds in the export I shared with you could not be accounted for because, according to the various states' rules (as noted during previous discussions/calls), we cannot file negative amounts in any state jurisdiction. For Texas, due to the low percent difference (~2.13%) and ruling out refunds in local jurisdictions as the cause, that difference is very likely related to rounding at the line item level (per transaction) when summing values for local jurisdictions. It's also possible that I'm unaware of other state-specific logic in place. I hope this is helpful. Do you know if we can proceed with the filings this month?

I may have another update tonight, but I hope to have this sorted out or confirmed by Monday. Our filing team is aware of the situation and noted that, as an exception, we'll still be able to file on Monday on time. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi MJ, Following up regarding the tax-due estimate! We found a way to temporarily adjust to account for the order edit situation and other factors that could lead to your noted differences. We're still fine-tuning this method, but we have surfaced it for our engineering team to explore as a solution to force reconciliation between Zamp and Shopify. I've attached a file showing the tax amounts from Shopify and Zamp; this was used to determine the adjustments needed. We adjusted for the amounts by the difference noted in column F. The variance is slight enough to be related to time zones, rounding, and other state-specific causes; we share more details here . One essential point is that we discovered Shopify's US Sales Tax report does not include tax on shipping (' total_shipping_tax_amount ') in the ' total_item_tax_amount ' column. Shopify's reporting separately buckets shipping and item taxes; this article shares more details . This also means that the variance is a lower tax amount. As we discussed, we still plan to evaluate previous filing periods (including January 2025) and determine the best path forward for making those adjustments. This will start tomorrow and continue into next week. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body:
Hi Husain, You're welcome; thanks for the note regarding urgency here. I have some details to share below that may be helpful for you. Still, we're also escalating this internally to the folks who built this Adobe Commerce Extension for any confirmation or extra details. My findings so far: This event utilizes the Observer in Observer/AddUpdateTaxBlock.php and it can be found here . This Observer watches for specific events occurring with orders, invoices, credit memos, and areas where tax-related items could be displayed. That list is: {
    public const AFFECTED_LAYOUTS = [
        'sales_email_order_creditmemo_items',
        'sales_email_order_invoice_items',
        'sales_email_order_items',
        'sales_guest_creditmemo',
        'sales_guest_invoice',
        'sales_guest_print',
        'sales_guest_printcreditmemo',
        'sales_guest_printinvoice',
        'sales_guest_view',
        'sales_order_creditmemo',
        'sales_order_creditmemo_new',
        'sales_order_creditmemo_updateqty',
        'sales_order_creditmemo_view',
        'sales_order_invoice',
        'sales_order_invoice_new',
        'sales_order_invoice_updateqty',
        'sales_order_invoice_view',
        'sales_order_print',
        'sales_order_printcreditmemo',
        'sales_order_printinvoice',
        'sales_order_view'
    ]; The goal of this observer is to allow tax display customization, consistent tax presentation, and order process coverage (where tax rates are involved). If we hear otherwise or have any performance optimization feedback from our team, we'll follow up right away.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, Thanks for your patience here! We investigated this further and found that the difference is related to the three reasons, noted below. The reasons are: 17 SplitOrder transactions from September 2024 through December 2024 were not previously adjusted for and were brought into the February 2025 filing period to assist in recovering the tax for those transactions. This was for a total of -$59.11 . 19 SplitOrder transactions occurred on 2/1/2025 which were included in the January 2025 filing in February because Zamp adjusts for the state-specific timezone in our filings. These adjustments were brought into the February 2025 filing period to ensure the SplitOrders were accounted for. This was a total of -$57.28 . Depending on the state, the remaining difference is likely related to timezone adjustments of 2/28/2025 through 3/1/2025. This typically accounts for 1-2% of a variance between Zamp and Shopify with tax collected. This would account for the remaining $21.33 difference. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, A quick follow-up to the tax-due estimate. This month's filings for the February 2025 period include all Split Order adjustments like we handled in February for January. Additionally, this estimate and the February 2025 filing period includes all remaining Split Order adjustments for the September 2024 through December 2024 and Q4 2024 filing periods. Lastly, any Indiana 2024 Split Order adjustments with a date of 2/15/2025 are included, and these adjustments will be filed with your IN 2025 filing processed in 2026. Lastly, our engineering team is considering improvements to handle the differences created by the SplitOrder third-party Shopify app with Zamp's Shopify integration. We do not yet know if this is an improvement path that will be taken or when it will be released. Our engineering team is also considering different avenues of improvement that may improve this situation, without adjusting directly for the SplitOrder app. Until then, we will adjust for these split order situations each month before sending you a tax-due estimate. I hope that you're having a good week!

body: Good day, I'm trying to submit a transaction, and either I don't understand, or maybe the API's validation is off? Here is the payload: { "id": "33714404", "name": "CBI-202407-850", "transactedAt": "2024-07-09T11:00:00+00:00", "isResale": false, "discount": 989.9, "subtotal": 3960, "shippingHandling": 0, "total": 2970.1, "taxCollected": 0, "shipToAddress": { "line1": "210 Lomas Santa Fe Dr. - Ste. 500", "line2": null, "state": "CA", "city": "Solana Beach", "zip": "92075" }, "lineItems": [ { "id": "272948882", "amount": 0, "quantity": 1, "discount": 0, "shippingHandling": 0, "productName": "Hourly Training USD Yearly", "productSku": null, "productTaxCode": null }, { "id": "272948883", "amount": 3960, "quantity": 1, "discount": 0, "shippingHandling": 0, "productName": "Pineapple Academy Training Hour USD Yearly", "productSku": null, "productTaxCode": null }, { "id": "272948884", "amount": 0, "quantity": 100, "discount": 0, "shippingHandling": 0, "productName": "Training Monthly Active User USD Yearly", "productSku": null, "productTaxCode": null } ] } The error I get back is: [{\"code\":\"custom\",\"path\":[\"subtotal\"],\"message\":\"SUM(lineItem.subtotal) − transaction.discount = $2970.10 (not $3960.00)\"},{\"code\":\"custom\",\"path\":[\"total\"],\"message\":\"Subtotal + shipping + tax = $3960.00 (not $2970.10)\"}] Seems to me you have the total and subtotal validation flipped? If subtotal is supposed to be $2970.1... Then there is no way total would be $3960, else the discount is only applied on the subtotal? Thanks, Scott Pucket Chief Information Officer Pineapple Academy, Inc. 816.503.1569 pineappleacademy.com This electronic message transmission contains information from the Pineapple Academy which is privileged, confidential or otherwise the exclusive property of the sender or intended recipient.  If you are not the designated recipient, please be aware that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited.

Stripe sends webhook events to your server to notify you of activity in your Stripe account, such as a completed payout or a newly-created invoice. The URL of the failing webhook endpoint is: https://c69b-2401-4900-881c-a542-6dd8-4846-f7e6-9fc3.ngrok-free.app/api/webhooks/stripe/ You (or someone on your team) configured your Stripe account to send events to that URL. You can change your account's webhook endpoints from the Dashboard . In most cases, a failing webhook does not impact your payments or payouts. However: If you use subscriptions we rely on your webhook endpoint to notify you of new invoices. These invoices may be delayed for up to three days if your endpoint is unable to successfully receive them. If you use Checkout and rely on the checkout.session.completed event as part of your purchase fulfillment process , you should review your completed payments to ensure you have fulfilled all recent purchases. We've attempted to send event notifications to this endpoint 9 times since the first failure on March 9, 2025 at 11:58:10 AM UTC. If this endpoint is important to your application, please try and fix the issue. If you do not need this webhook endpoint, you can remove it from your Stripe webhook settings . We will stop sending event notifications to this webhook endpoint by March 18, 2025 at 11:58:10 AM UTC. Here is the summary of errors we received while attempting to send webhook events: 9 requests returned HTTP 404, indicating the URL doesn't exist. You should verify the endpoint URL is correct in your Stripe webhook settings. You need to return any status code between HTTP 200 to 299 for Stripe to consider the webhook event successfully delivered. For more details on these errors and to review your account's recent activity, you can find the full set of events and request logs on the Dashboard. For more in-depth information on how to use webhooks, we recommend reviewing our documentation . Yours, The Stripe team This email relates to your Auto Advocate Inc. Stripe account. Account ID: acct_1HD5cSEDecUQ1oup Need to refer to this message? Use this ID: em_kj1qtl2whgb172joe31lm8lpu3ubix Stripe, 354 Oyster Point Blvd, South San Francisco, CA 94080 You are subscribed to Webhooks emails. Manage your communication preferences .

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Amy, No worries at all; thanks for sending this over! Can you confirm this is what you need? Yes, this looks like what we need. Could you please confirm if the points below are correct to ensure we understand the data correctly? The 'Talbots' invoices should be imported into Zamp as wholesale transactions with Greencastle, IN 46135 as the Ship To address. These invoices are: 10983 10984 10985 10986 10987 - this invoice did not have a Delivery state or postal code. 10988 - this invoice did not have a Delivery state or postal code. 10989 - this invoice did not have a Delivery state or postal code. One of the ' Talbots ' invoices (10990) would be attributed to Pataskala, OH. We'll import the ' Wholesale - US ' customer group invoices (Urban Outfitters) as wholesale with the provided delivery details. The ' Wholesale Australia ' invoices would not be imported as they're delivered to locations within Australia, or other countries. The exception appears to be this invoice delivered to Florida: 10917 Based on the data we've imported into Zamp in the past, the above is likely the route to take here (outside of the 'Wholesale Australia' invoice to FL) but we wanted to confirm just in case. I was curious because I have not seen any sales tax payments being made. Just wanted to double check that's correct? As far as we know, this should be correct. Within Zamp, we can see that Standard Procedure is registered to file quarterly in California. Zamp has filed the Q2, Q3, and Q4 2024 CA returns; with Q4 2024 filed in January 2025. The payment date for the CA Q4 2024 return was 1/24/2025. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sean, Thanks for your patience here! I've reviewed the transactions and our API logs. So far, I don't see any missing transactions, but I'd like to be sure. From 3/1/25 through today (3/6), I found 8,383 API transactions, and since 12/6/2024, I have found 116,956 API transactions. Regarding the 500 errors from yesterday: I've attached a list of affected transactions for that period. We've confirmed that all of these transactions are in Zamp. During our review of the situation, we also found that each transaction in the file I've attached was created within Zamp, likely due to retry logic implemented within your integration. We're happy to discuss this further if you would like. Please confirm the dates you're most interested in us reviewing, and if those are all of the dates listed in your earlier email, we can work on that. If you have any questions, please let us know!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sean, Thanks for reaching out! Yes, we can help investigate this and confirm that the data you've sent us is accounted for within Zamp. We'll be sure to follow up to confirm. So that you know, the email below was sent out regarding this situation, and I wanted to share it with you as well. ———————————— We wanted to provide a quick update about a minor API service interruption that occurred earlier today. Our team has already resolved the issue, and all systems are now fully operational. Your account was identified as one that had transaction-send failures. Please be assured that we have handled any missed transactions, and no action is required on your part. If you would like a list of the transactions that failed to originally post into Zamp, please let us know.

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: @technicalsuccess @ryan Sending this your way!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Troy, Following up! Our engineering team confirmed that the API call for calculations failed here due to a temporary and rare service disruption within Zamp. We're closely monitoring these situations, and various improvements are being made to prevent this from happening in the future. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: I escalated some questions about this to engineering here: https://zamp-workspace.slack.com/archives/C086YJW42SW/p1741317431455839

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Troy, Thanks for your patience here! After investigating this further, we found that tax wasn't calculated here because a 500 'internal server error' status code was returned. Since then, multiple improvements have been enabled within Zamp better to avoid a scenario like this in the future. I'm confirming this and checking with our engineering team for additional details as this is potentially related to a recent database migration aimed at scaling our services; this shouldn't happen again. As soon as we hear back, we'll follow up immediately. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body:
Additional research: I finally found the API calls associated with the calculation and it appears there were multiple at these timestamps: Mar 04, 18:50:33 Mar 04, 18:53:50 Mar 04, 18:58:38 Mar 04, 20:56:17 Mar 04, 20:56:39 Here's one of the responses: {

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Michelle, Thanks for bringing this up! Yes—this can happen, and I usually like to bring up/cover this item. Is it ok to report the last month's transactions to Zamp so that any refunds can be reported successfully? What is the recommended way to handle this? Yes, this is 100% OK! Zamp generally recommends importing sales data back to January 1 of the previous year (in this case, 1/1/2024) for nexus analysis. If refunds are involved, it's best to do this via the API instead of a CSV to ensure the relationship can be made between refunds that can occur in the future (depending on when orders sync to Zamp.) We'd recommend backfilling (syncing) transactions from last month directly with our /transactions API endpoint. Still, we recommend keeping the request volume to 2-3 requests per minute to avoid any rate limits. There are plans to increase or scale this in the future, but those are further down the line after additional database improvements, various internal decisions, and roadmap priorities. Typically an async/await pattern with a delay will work here. Here's a basic JavaScript example I've shared to handle this kind of sync while ensuring to be under the rate limit: await new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(resolve, 300)); This could be done using an existing integration if your integration supports it, or we'd recommend building a separate but related feature to handle this kind of logic (a manual sync/backfill feature can be helpful if needed). Do you think the above helps here? Can we assist with any other questions related to these refunds or the approach to take?

Our engineering team is working through various items to improve the handling of voided/canceled Shopify orders and exploring a recently discovered alternative improvement for dealing with edited Shopify orders. The improvement of the edited Shopify orders is in a highly exploratory phase. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Heather, Thanks for your continued patience! Regarding the items remaining from the revisions you noted: For the transaction ID R-971545706558 shipped to California, we did not import a revision because the original transaction occurred within January 2025, and tax was paid for that order. $62 in tax was remitted to the state for the January 2025 because the original order on 1/25/2025 was included in that filing. $62 in tax is deducted from the filing for the February 2025 period because the refund was processed on 2/18/2025. Regarding R-972121866302 also shipped to CA: This transaction's revision or offset was accounted for with transaction ID 6975365513278-adjust in the CSV file I shared. We'll denote this more clearly the next time we need to make adjustments like this. Thanks for your understanding! Regarding R-970141925438 shipped to NY: This transaction's revision was accounted for with the transaction ID 6937431703614-adjust within the CSV file I shared. Similar to R-972121866302 , we'll improve handling these situations from now on to make it more straightforward. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Heather and Bijan, You're welcome! Thanks for the follow-up and your understanding. Regarding the adjustments: I'm investigating this again, and I believe I left out some explanations for why I didn't offset them, but I will follow up today after I confirm. Regarding order edits: Our Shopify integration does not know when these order edits happen or the changes made because of how Shopify's Admin Order API is designed; our engineering team let us know that order edits are unsupported. Additionally, Shopify's order exports (from this page) do not show these order edits and retain the order's original amount. That said, we understand the business side of this situation, and it's a tricky balance with Shopify between being understandably customer experience focused and ensuring revenue retention. In these situations, and for now, we could help adjust if we are informed that an order edit happened, and the amount differences are shared with us by transaction ID.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Heather, Thanks again for your patience. We've completed our review and the work to adjust for the differences that you've noted. Most of the transactions were voids/cancellations, and our engineering team is working to improve that (we're happy to help adjust for this). One item listed in the sheet was R-971545706558 and I left this transaction as it is because it was a refund for a January 2025 order ( HOS4524365218 ) which ended up in the February 2025 period due to the date it was refunded. This one fully refunded the tax associated with the original transaction. Please note that Order ID 6949117952062 (Shopify Order: HOS4524395718 ) was an edited order. While we understand that editing orders typically provides the best customer experience, our integration is unable to support these because Shopify's APIs do not expose all of the necessary details surrounding order edits to our integration. This means that we highly recommend against editing orders and instead creating a full refund and a separate order. We can adjust for these occasionally to help, but we won't be able to do it regularly if the volume of those kinds of edits grows. I've attached a file that was used to adjust for these differences, and we'll soon send out a tax-due estimate. Please let me know if you have any questions. Have a wonderful weekend!

body: Hi Robert, Thanks for adding us to QBO! We've created a custom report that gathers the details we need for sales tax filings. The report can be accessed here . I've also attached a version of it to this email. A couple of quick questions: For Zamp or any sales tax compliance solution, we need an address associated with an invoice to report the invoice properly within state jurisdictions. 1) Should we use the billing address for the invoices without a shipping address, or would your team need to update the shipping addresses? I'm asking because many invoices, including those with sales tax collected, do not have a shipping address. Sales tax calculations and filings are based on the shipping address for physical products. 2) Also, is it correct that your invoices without sales tax would be considered wholesale/resale or tax-exempt for another reason? These questions will help us understand your data and ensure we file your January 2025 sales tax return accurately. Once we hear back about this, we'll import the data and let our filing team know to proceed with your CO January 2025 filing.

author: chris@zamp.com

After the February filings progress, we can examine past filings and determine the path forward. We'll keep you updated!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: After talking through this with @carie - the plan to solve for this is: Export the taxes transactions Shopify report for all states, from Shopify. Compare that file's tax amounts to Zamp by Order ID (or order name) and find the difference. Sum the tax amount by order id. Sum the net sales amount by order ID. Create a refund transaction to offset the difference between Zamp's transactions and this Shopify report. Copy over all the transaction details and use the amounts from the Shopify report as the refund (or positive) amount. This includes the PTC and address details (those are important to continue to include.) We should do this for February to get the filing moving. Then, figure it out for historical periods where we filed. cc: @lucas - we could use your script for inspiration here and I also have some ideas.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Fix for March: Fix manually using Shopify tax transaction export vs Zamp? Goal: make sure we're filing correctly for now. For the more minor differences: It's OK to adjust for these in future periods without checking % decreased in tax. For past already filed returns: Figure out the amount over-paid, using the same method as march. Determine how to move forward based on the amount, by state.

author: crispin@goodmerchonly.com
body:
Hi there,
If you're able to copy data from our sheets into templates we could happily provide our ongoing tours each month. Would that be easiest? My only concerns here are that until we scale and staff properly, we may make mistakes. The best way is to can ensure we do this properly would be to send links to all our ongoing tours monthly. Is that manageable? Each shoed would look like the attached screen shot below.

Some months we have several tours and some months there will be none! As it stands there's only 3 tours on our schedule for the year and 1 is about to wrap up on Saturday (the one in the screen shot below)

Here's what this email would contain: Good Kid tour Rare Americans Tour NSP Tour (Hasn't started yet) Crispin Day (he/him) GOOD MERCH ONLY WWW.GOODMERCHONLY.COM 416-473-4632

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Crispin, This is interesting to hear. I will review the various email threads (and notes) regarding past situations, and then I can share some recommendations. One way could be to have a separate sheet (or file) containing the tour merch revenues completed for the month by the 1st to 3rd of each month. This approach should be OK, but one sure way to avoid any differences would be to use our CSV template and provide us with the data each month (after any currency conversions and validation on your end). We could also share the data with you after processing and before importing into Zamp (if preferable.) One item we'll do on our end, is ensure we only copy/export/record data for the current month using the 'Date' column and the data highlighted in the screenshot below:

author: crispin@goodmerchonly.com
body: Ok that works. There have been instances of errors being made when calculating tax owed in the past for our touring revenues so if there's any methodology we can use to create checks and balances and verify the amounts being remitted that would be ideal. As an alternative we can focus in on a system on our end to facilitate accuracy here. Let me know what you think. Crispin Day (he/him) GOOD MERCH ONLY WWW.GOODMERCHONLY.COM 416-473-4632

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Crispin, Thanks for sharing this with us! We understand that handling this for a full tour would be more efficient and a preferred path here. That said, Zamp would need the data monthly because the states noted below require Good Merch Only Inc. to file monthly, and we'll need the data to process filings accurately each month, keeping compliance in mind. These filing frequencies can change as each state's Department of Revenue determines them. As of right now, the monthly filing states are: AZ CO DC GA IL PA TX VA For this month, we'll pull the data for February 2025 to ensure that is included in the tax-due estimate and filings. We can continue to do this in the future as well.

author: crispin@goodmerchonly.com
body: It's up to you, my plan was to provide the full tour once it was completed. Would you prefer to handle things on a monthly basis? On our end from an administrative and process standpoint it would be a bit tidier to send over the completed tour vs looping Zamp in each month on our ongoing tours? Crispin Day (he/him) GOOD MERCH ONLY WWW.GOODMERCHONLY.COM 416-473-4632

body: Hi Mandy, Thanks for following up and for your continued patience here. After investigating this further, I see that this situation appears to be limited to the address used. If so, I can include those in my escalation and further investigate myself.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Siddharth, Thanks for the follow-up and great questions! I'll have more detail to share tomorrow and can likely share a broader data set this week. The heart of the situation here will be that Zamp uses multiple time zones in our filings because our team found that adjusting for the state's time zone was the most technically compliant approach regarding sales tax filings across all states. This means that Zamp would use a PST time zone for CA, an MST time zone for CO, a CST time zone for IL, an EST time zone for OH, etc. Shopify uses a single time zone for its store, which is usually the primary location for the store. We share more information about this in our article here . Zamp extracts data from the 'baby bub' Shopify store when an order is placed. We do this via Shopify's Admin Orders API (and possibly a few other API endpoints). We receive the data in UTC and have some checks around dates/time zones. Then, Zamp adjusts for the state's specific time zone and various state-specific sales tax requirements. This means lining up data 1:1 between Zamp (and many sales tax compliance solutions) will be tricky. However, this will be simpler if we focus on a single state, California. We're happy to help explain the various pieces and share the data. We appreciate your patience and understanding! A couple of quick questions: What time zone is your Shopify store based in? This will help me understand the potential differences. Also, when you have a moment, could you please share your Shopify store's collaborator access code ? It appears Zamp's access auto-expired as that can happen every 90-days.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Albert and Team, Thanks for your patience here! I've attached an export of your California November 2024 transactions, which were used to calculate the California prepayment amount for that same month. A few items to note about this file: The tax used in our calculations is listed in column J ( transactionTax .) This is an export that I modified as a one-time exception to be what we call "transaction-level," which means that it does not have the usual line items shown in our exports. This was done to simplify summing the tax and other amounts, but we can share a line item file if you'd like. (Note: line item files have order IDs and transaction-level (tax, subtotal, discounts, etc.) repeated; summing them in Excel can be tricky.) The Transaction IDs shown in the file are in column B ( transactionId ), and we have access to this ID via Shopify's API. Within Shopify, this ID is available in an order's URL, and you can still search for orders via these IDs in Shopify Admin. In a Shopify order export, this ID is included in column BD (titled Id .) The date listed in column L ( transactionDate ) is a UTC date and our filings convert these dates into the state's specific time zone; we share more details in this article . I hope this is helpful to you. Please let us know if you have any questions! We're happy to schedule a call if needed as well. Have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - this is normal because the order itself was sold/processed through the SHOP app / Shop Channel: https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/online-sales-channels/shop/sales-tax Starting on January 1, 2025, the Shop channel will automatically collect, remit, and file taxes for all orders shipping to or within the United States. The Shop channel collects taxes on orders in all states (including the District of Columbia) that administer statewide sales tax, as well as Alaska local sales tax. For more information on how these taxes are calculated, refer to the US taxes reference page.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Michael, Thanks for following up here and for your patience! We looked into this within your Shopify store using the Zamp view here , which filters all orders to a destination of GA and found that tax was collected on this transaction ( 2663 ) because, as of 1/1/2025, Shopify collects sales taxes as a marketplace facilitator on all orders processed through the SHOP App. Shopify shares more details about that in their article here . Shopify specifically collects sales tax on all Shop channel sales shipped to customers in the US if the state has a sales tax (state-level or local-level.) The above also means this is normal within Shopify as of January 1st. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Steps to troubleshoot this: Log into BigCommerce - this login is under 'Login' within 1P, and I usually find it by searching 'BigCommerce'; it's the filing@zamp.com login. Navigate to Apps —> Zamp —> Logs , enter a log date, and download the log to a PDF. Search the PDF for the address involved with the quote or order. Review details after the calculation request to see Zamp's response. Review the initial API call for anything that might cause an error (status code) to be returned if one was returned. Logs: Error:

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tyron and Team, Thanks for your patience here! We looked into this, and after reviewing the Zamp logs within BigCommerce, we found that a BigCommerce fallback rate of 10% was used because a phone number was entered for the shipping address zip code. The BigCommerce fallback rate kicked in when Zamp's API returned a "bad request" status code for the calculation because it could not process or recognize the zip code. Here's where this can be seen in the quote : Once this quote's zip code is updated, the sales tax calculated should be 6% instead of the fallback rate of 10% because Zamp will recalculate the tax when that change is made. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aleli, Thanks for your patience here! After reviewing the stores involved again, the Shopify sales data syncs on our end, and we have confirmed with our engineering team the causes of the missing Shopify data. Those causes are: The transactions were missing for the Chuckle Sandwich store because the initial bulk sync for historical data from Shopify only included 1/1/2024-1/28/2024; it was a typo when initiating the sync; we'll catch these better in the future. For the Flashgitz, the missing transaction (#FLG8425) failed to sync to Zamp because of an invalid address. During our transaction sync process with any Shopify store, we attempt to confirm that the address exists. If it does not, we cannot import the transaction (this happens very rarely). The above also means that this is not a systemic issue and should be a one-time situation. Lastly, I've also audited all of the historical imports for the stores noted below (these have been connected since 12/1/2024) to ensure this kind of date-related typo scenario hasn't happened with other stores, and we're all set, in the clear, with these. Cinna Clooless Layze TommyInnit OnlyFangs Warren James - Cancelled Podcast Fears to Fathom Gabi Belle thesketchreal brettcooper RoyalPear Turtle With Hat Whispering Willow Please let us know if you have any questions!

body: Hi Jackie, Thanks for your continued patience. After investigating this further, the amounts shown for the payments to the various state DORs are correct and match the sales data within Zamp for Oats Overnight. This applies to each state noted in the screenshot: AR, SD, RI, GA, and TN. The reasons for these differences vary: For Georgia, the difference was a $4.32 vendor's compensation credit/discount from the state of GA for timely filing. RI matched the initial notice. The difference was primarily caused by Shopify Transactions imported after the tax-due estimate was sent for AR, SD, and TN. These transactions occurred within January 2025 but were imported on 2/4/25 or after. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Differences: AR  - notice: $2,005. - payment - $2,012, matches return and report . SD - notice: $2,497.94 - payment - $2,556.34, matches return and report . The discount is listed on the report but not taken, likely due to when it was filed or if the discount doesn't apply. RI - notice: $147.80 - payment - $147.80, matches - didn't look at return/report. GA - notice: $144.00 - payment - $139.68, matches the return and report . The difference is due to a $4.32 vendor's compensation (timely filing discount.) TN - notice: $14,229 - payment - $14,306, matches the return and report . So far, while I'm unsure of the cause of these differences, it is okay and normal. GA, at least, was due to a timely filing discount. Looking at the attached exports, we can see with the zampcreateddate and the zampupdateddate , that there were quite a few transactions imported between when the notice was sent (2/3) and when the filings happened. This appears to be the main cause.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi LizAnn, You're welcome; thanks for your continued patience here. We worked with Ryan and updated a few items that helped us solve this situation. To avoid this confusion in the future, we'll work on updated documentation and improved scripting on our side. I've imported your January 2025 data, and you should receive an updated tax-due estimate within 1-2 hours. I've attached some files to show the data we exported from QBO to accomplish this and the file we imported into Zamp. Here they are: The first file, " file.xlsx ," is a combination of QBO exports; we used this as the source data. The second file, " TechTradeSolutions - QBO Export - 01JAN2025-31JAN2025.csv ," is the file we're importing into Zamp to rebuild the tax-due estimate. After reviewing the data, all missing invoices were present except for the TX invoice ( 30099 ) because, within QBO, it's dated 2/5/2025. This means we'll import that invoice next month for the February 2025 TX filing due then. As soon as we send you the tax-due estimate, we'll need to hear back from you about approval to proceed quickly today or tomorrow to ensure we can complete the various state sales tax returns by the due dates. Florida has a tricky set of due dates and payment expectations, so we hope to move sooner than others.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Angela, Thanks for checking in and for your patience here. Unfortunately, on the Zamp side, we haven't run into this error recently. Any memories of resolving similar errors are from a while ago (at different roles/companies); only vaguely remembered. Currently, Zamp does not have an integration with Google Merchant Center. That said, it does appear that it could be worth double-checking the following items within the Google Merchant Center: Please ensure the prices within Google Merchant Center are not tax-inclusive, meaning tax is excluded. Confirm or update the tax settings within Google Merchant Center to match your BigCommerce store's. This will ensure that both stores enable taxes for the same states. In this article , Google shares how to access the tax settings and some basic steps. Confirm whether the product or tax categories match those of Google Merchant Center and BigCommerce. Here are the states that we'd want to ensure are enabled within Google Merchant Center: We're also happy to hop on a call to review this with you, and a call can be scheduled with this link: https://calendly.com/chris-zamp/30min .

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes from the call w/Ashley and Talia - ~1hr: Talia was super understanding about the Shopify Order address change situation; we checked 2 to 3 orders live on the call and confirmed that Zamp had the updated (correct) shipping address. She'll work with the client and their processes to decide how to handle this address change/tax issue from an accounting perspective. Get a transaction export to them for all 2024 transactions; it must be run in Metabase. Talia needs this because our data is more accurate than Shopify's and they're trying to do a year-end close. In the future, they'll reconcile monthly, making it more smooth. We'll likely want to do this in chunks as it's ~300k transactions, and Excel will probably crash. We're making This one-time exception for Talia to help with Look Optic's messy sales tax/accounting situation. I'm closing this with a snooze to re-open next week when Nick or I can dive into this further.

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Talia, We are more than happy to jump on a call to discuss this further. Would you like to select a time here that works best for you? Talk soon, Ashley

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - We should hop on a call with them to discuss this further. Unfortunately, there isn't much we can do other than escalate it to the builders to see if they have any ideas, but I doubt that will go anywhere, although it would be great to solve this. This is ultimately something they'd need to bring up with Shopify. One possible resolution is to cancel the original order before payment or process a full refund. Then, a new order with the corrected address could be placed. However, this isn't a good or efficient process, and they likely wouldn't like the customer experience involved. Others are aware of this, as far as I know. Matt Grattan brought this issue up with one of his Shopify Product contacts during the various calls/emails about MUDWtr issues.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - This is something they'll need to contact Shopify about. Unfortunately, Shopify does not re-calculate the tax or remove tax calculated for another state when a shipping address is changed on an order. Shopify keeps the tax initially collected. So, ultimately, they should refund the tax here because OR doesn't have sales tax. The order shows up in OR within Zamp, but with tax collected because of how Shopify handles this.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Thanks for checking in! I believe that I answered this through another email thread with Becky, and I've shared that answer below. Please let me know if you have any questions! I'm jumping in to help answer the outstanding API question. So that you know, any API (or technical) questions can also be directed to support@zamp.com ; those questions can also be routed to the team I'm a part of. 🙂 How would a refund transaction affect reporting for the following month? Would it just be netted against the transactions of that month? For example, if a Jan 26th transaction is refunded on Feb 6th, that negative amount on Feb 6th would be used to offset the transactions in Feb. Yes, if a refund transaction is created within Zamp on February 6th, 2025, it will be netted against the transactions for February 2025. The other option is not to create the transaction within Zamp. Instead, someone on the Wayo team would file an amended return with the state associated with the transaction to recover the refunded sales tax.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, I'm following up with a quick update here! We reviewed the differences you noted between Washington and Nevada and found they are expected. I'll share more details below. Overall, the cause of the difference relates to state-specific sales tax logic built into our tax-due estimates (and, by extension, our filings) that are not accounted for when looking at a raw tax collected amount within BigCommerce, Shopify, Volusion, or other systems. Regarding WA: You noted that $1,376.30 was collected in tax, and the tax-due estimate from Zamp was $1,492.27 . The difference here is $115.97 . While reviewing the filing details associated with the WA January 2025 return, we found that most of this difference is due to the WA B&O tax. This gross receipts tax is not collected from customers and is due when filing sales tax returns. This amount was $147.39 . Please note that state-specific rounding and time zone differences ( noted in this article , which mentions Shopify, but these scenarios can apply to other platforms/carts/systems as well) are likely responsible for the overall difference. Depending on the number of transactions and the state, these two items can cause variances of a few dollars up to hundreds of dollars. Regarding NV: You noted that $617.61 was collected in tax, and the tax-due estimate from Zamp was $660.10 . The difference here is $42.49 . We reviewed all of the Nevada transactions from multiple angles, looking for any potential missing transactions or situations that might cause differences; we could not find anything that raised concerns. The difference for NV is also likely related to rounding or a time zone difference between the transactions you're viewing in your reports and the time zone Zamp uses. In NV, Zamp's estimates and filings adjust for transactions that fall within the Pacific Time Zone (PST), which can cause transactions to occur at the beginning or end of a filing period (the first or last day). I've also attached an export containing all transactions synced with Zamp shipped to customers in Nevada; the amount is close to your initial amount. We also share some details about our filing notices and tax-due estimates that may be helpful in this article . Do we have your approval to proceed with the Dorm Company Corporation's filings for January 2025?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: WA - The difference is $115.97; Zamp has a higher amount. The difference is likely just B&O tax plus rounding. The customer's noted difference is $115.97, and B&O is 147.39, which is $31.42 greater than the difference here, and that small of an amount is likely rounding. NV - the difference is $42.49; Zamp has a higher amount. After exporting NV transactions, we get an amount of about $621. The differences here are likely related to rounding and time zone.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Kayley, Jackie, and Team, Thanks again for your patience! We looked into this from multiple angles and found that the primary cause of differences in the January 2025 filing processed in February was related to two items, which I'll note below. The first item concerns a limitation of Shopify's reporting, and the second concerns the Loop Discount being disabled within Loop, as AvaTax requires (which is the opposite of what Zamp needs). The Shopify Sales tax by Region Report does not appear to include POS or in-person store sales. This accounted for $47,110.05 of the difference. The Loop Exchange orders were duplicating tax on a small subset of orders, ~80 orders in January and another ~80 in February. This accounted for $3,737.42 of the difference. The above means that $3,737.42 in tax was overpaid out of the initial estimate of $50,001.50 . The good news is that we're adjusting for that this month for any monthly filings and in future filings for any non-monthly filings. Here's a breakdown based on the original figures shared from Zamp and by Jackie in February: Regarding the Shopify Sales tax by Region Report : When we exported transactions from Shopify, we found that there weren't orders missing within Zamp when comparing a Zamp export to the Shopify export. Here's what we did in this Report to sort this out: When we sorted the 'Is POS sale' column descending so that 'Yes' was at the top, we found that there were only two indications of this at the top for FL and CA. Here's what this looked like: We also found that the number of rows with 'Is POS sale' did not increase or change when we grouped by the Order ID: In the above screenshot, it appears to account for only two orders. The query powering the Shopify Report likely needs some additional tweaking or filtering. This report is a newer release from Shopify using their ShopifyQL option, and we're still learning more about it. This could be related to the lack of a billing or destination address for POS orders, or some specific quirk to how Shopify built/queries this report. We could help you determine the best way to deal with that report and improve the data it returns, but Shopify Plus Support can likely help more efficiently. Please let us know if you'd like to schedule a call with Ashley and me. Regarding Loop Exchange orders duplicating tax: As we discussed on our call, this is a situation in which Zamp needs the opposite of an AvaTax setting requirement. We will raise this issue as a feature request to our engineering team and ask them to explore accounting for it in future improvements. For now and in the future, we will adjust for this manually by creating 'refund offset' transactions to remove the duplicate tax, and we'll eventually have a way to exclude these transactions altogether. I've imported adjustment files to offset the duplicate tax from Loop Exchange orders into your Zamp account for both of the months below: January 2025 - recovering $3,737.42 in sales tax. February 2025 - ensuring $3,165.80 in sales tax is not duplicated. Once the adjustments are processed, we will send you a tax-due estimate either tonight or tomorrow (3/13). Please let me know if you have any questions. If it's better to talk through this, I'm happy to hop on a call .

body: What we need to do here for filings this month: Find all Loop transactions with 'EXC' in the externalName column and create offset/refund transactions to remove the tax for those orders. These transactions duplicate the tax, inflating the tax amount paid. Sum the tax associated with all POS location (in-store location) transactions from the Shopify export for January and February. Do that by state to share with the customer. Compare against the sales tax by region Shopify report—the suspicion is that this report doesn't include POS/location sales. This is likely a limitation of Shopify's reporting. Going forward and after this week: Investigate the differences between the Zamp variance review and Shopify exports, and figure out why. We want to figure this out for January and previous periods to see if there's a larger issue.

All transactions for February 2025 - including international. We'll need to filter out transactions shipped to a non-US country for this export. There might still be differences between files; some rows in the Shopify export don't have the ship to address as they're line items (we need to sort out a good way to filter those). Maybe the strategy before processing/data review: Filter the file for non-US Shipping locations. Before deleting those rows, copy the order name or ID. Store those IDs in another sheet. Delete the non-US shipping rows. Use VLOOKUP or similar to find rows that match the stored IDs. Delete the rows matching the IDs. Happy to help with this as well!

body: Hi Jackie, Kayley, and Team, A quick follow-up here! We're still working on this situation and hope to update you early next week. Have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: My notes pre-call: Differences in reporting: It appears that Shopify's report doesn't include POS transactions. Loop discount is enabled, but they use AvaTax, and that's needed there. (Adjustments or switch to Shopify tax until Eng can account for the loop discount if it's disabled, although that's not a guarantee.) Time zone differences, which includes refunds. ————————————————————————————————————————- Notes from the call with Jackie, Kayley (Shopify/Ecomm team), Tasia (analyst/ecomm team, and Carina (Cult Gaia CS) -45 minutes. Jackie said she's probably OK with adjustments and they want the refund for the extra tax paid. She wants to know the amount for the past overpayments and needs to share this with her CFO. They're not going to switch from or go off of AvaTax, they just upgraded and signed another contract (from the sound of it.) They'll let their CFO know. They use AvaTax with other countries as well. Shopify apps: They use NetSuite, which goes from Shopify to NetSuite via Celigo. Loop should be the only other one. NetSuite/Celigo —> Shopify: They don't have a flow to edit orders from NetSuite to Shopify. author: ryan@zamp.com
body: Hi Mike & Eric, Chris is currently out of the office, so I'm stepping in to assist. Do you happen to log your requests to our /calculations endpoint, or associate them with the transactions on your side? If so, do you have a .txt export by chance? It would be great to see the request bodies on calculations and compare to the transaction data. For an explanation on timezone handling, here are a few key highlights: We ingest transactions and save them via UTC. So for example, if you pass to us a transaction  that you've localized the 'transactionDate' for as '2025-04-01T06:00:00.000Z', we will treat that as 6:00am UTC, which is technically 2025-03-31 as a reported transaction date. We now allow viewing transactions by a specific timezone in our Transactions interface when logged into Zamp, so you could view it in PST if you chose to. We file and localize transactions based on the state's timezone . When it comes down to states that span multiple timezones, we get even more specific and go by the timezone of the state's capitol . Timezones and compliance (in any industry) are always a bit of a monster, but we try to simplify it by always suggesting giving us the transactions in UTC, and offsetting to whatever standard you follow. For example, perhaps you treat all transactions (regardless of where they occur) as a realized sale based on PST. Hope this all makes some sense, timezones can be tricky!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @nick @ryan @lucas - when you have some time, could any of you help look into this? The issue: The customer was expecting to see a tax payment of $40,575 for the remaining tax due for the Q1 2025 CA period (after January and February prepayments). The report they shared above (starting with 'RPT_Mike...') shows 40,720.24. They're based in CA, so it's unlikely that the cause is a time zone difference, but it could be (if they run their report in UTC vs. Zamp filing in PST, or some other edge-case difference). This is also an API customer, so we'd expect what they collect to match Zamp's calculations. So, this is a bit different from a Zamp vs Shopify reconciliation. For Zamp API customers, we set transactionRecalculate to true by default when creating transactions in Zamp; we always file based on taxDue not taxCollected (which is the opposite of what we do for Shopify/other non-API integrations.) What I've found so far: We see very little under-collection in the CA report ($0.22): https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clv2utyjn037p145m09arkdas/state-reports/CA/2025-Q1 These are all of the Q1 2025 CA transactions, $133k: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clv2utyjn037p145m09arkdas/transactions?date=2025-01-01~2025-03-31&shipToState=CA We see $42,455.63 for March 2025: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clv2utyjn037p145m09arkdas/transactions?date=2025-03-01%7E2025-03-31&shipToState=CA This is still higher than the initial estimate. Looking at all their transactions for Q1 2025 in CA, I don't see any transactions that likely caused this difference overall (in Q1 or March 2025) because they were primarily created or updated within the same period. Query: https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/6436-transaction-export-by-a-state-list-with-reportedon-and-zampcreated?company=clv2utyjn037p145m09arkdas&start=2025-01-01&end=2025-03-31 This export is attached. I don't see any concerns or significant variation between taxDue and taxCollected when exporting the variance review query here ; an export is attached. We may look at March 2025 for CA on its own, but I don't see causes for concern here. Overall, my theory is that there is a difference in reporting between their system and Zamp but I can't quite prove it yet.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Mike and Eric, Thanks for sharing this with us! We're investigating these differences, and I've started looking into it. On the Zamp side, we aren't seeing an indication of under-collection in sales tax, so the difference is likely related to the date and time values used for the transactions, or something else entirely. That said, we want to help sort this out and ensure we're all on the same page moving forward. When you have a moment, could you share the records or an export of the transaction data used to build the XLSX tax jurisdiction report you shared? This way, we can compare directly and confirm the causes based on expected behavior. We can also share an export of the data within Zamp if it would be helpful; our goal here is to sort out the differences in a way that saves you all time.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tra, Thanks for your continued patience here! We looked into this further and found that the refund (#GILS1477) from the Gils Arena store was imported into Zamp; I've attached an export from Zamp showing this. This export can also be requested by logging into your Zamp portal and navigating to the Transactions page here with state and date range filters. Here's how to request an export: Just so you know, this screenshot was taken within a test account, and you will see something different within your Zamp account. Here's what I see within the Underdog Sports Holdings Zamp account: Here's what is happening with this refund: Within Zamp, a refund Transaction is not accounted for within the tax-due estimate if it will cause a local Jurisdiction to become negative (e.g., '-3.91' in this transaction's situation). The above means that this refund transaction (#GILS1477) caused the local jurisdiction of HAMPTON CITY to be negative, as there were $0 in sales to that jurisdiction. Most states do not allow sales tax returns to be filed with negative amounts. Please note that the Virginia Department of Taxation can issue a refund or credit. Their PDF documentation outlines how to submit such a request . Next steps: Do we have your approval to proceed with your sales tax filings for the January 2025 filing period this month? If Zamp is to file for Underdog Sports Holdings this month, we must hear back about this approval by Friday (2/14/25).

author: amoore@zamp.com
body: @chris Hi! Here's a refund transaction ticket affecting current period VA filing. I tried to do as much research on it as I could. The customer says that a refund is missing from their VA filing, but the refund does appear in our system and the report is zeroed out for associated jurisdiction. My guess is that they might be expecting the total $3.14 due in VA to be offset by refund #GILS1477 (-$3.91). The sales posted to VA this month are in other counties than where the refund is posted. I remember hearing that refunds are magic mathed to zero out, but I'm not familiar enough with how our system handles them. VA filing https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clz38bhkz012tkqe6ykleqfv5/state-reports/VA/2025-JAN Issue Per customer: VA is missing Refund #GILS1477 Research #GILS1477 is included in the period https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clz38bhkz012tkqe6ykleqfv5/transactions?from=2025-01-01&to=2025-02-04&shipToState=VA Took a look at Metabase : Jurisdiction is HAMPTON CITY for the tranx Note - my access in metabase for this table is view only Compared to our VA report Jan 2025 Hampton City is zeroed out across all fields. Two other orders posted to this period were in FAIRFAX COUNTY & FAUQUIER COUNTY Original order Does not appear in the Jan 2025 period I think it's #GILS1477 that was reported with the Dec 2024 return Tranx list for Dec 2024 & Jan 2025 https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clz38bhkz012tkqe6ykleqfv5/transactions?from=2024-12-01&to=2025-01-31&shipToState=VA

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Adam, A quick follow-up! We've completed removing all automatically imported QBO transactions. We then imported the data manually via CSV after requesting an export from QBO using this Zamp Sales Tax custom Report. Zamp's tax-due estimate amounts for Texas, Illinois, Alabama, and Indiana are now in line with your expectations. The differences here appear to be related to state-specific sales tax rounding, time zone differences between how Zamp files returns and QBO reports tax amounts, and state-specific timely filing discounts (which are included in most of our estimates.) Illinois's estimate is not $5,875.00. Texas' estimate is now $10,345.16. Alabama's estimate is not precisely $2,156.42. Please let us know if you have any questions. We'll need to get these filings started today to have them filed by or before the state's various sales tax filing and payment due dates.
